TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I remind the Senate that the Minister told the Senate yesterday that `Immediately after the Channel 9 interview concluded' he realised he had made a mistake by casting doubts on the Budget's growth forecasts. I ask the Minister how this can be true when he then went on to repeat those same doubts in a second interview on the Ten Network half an hour later when he said, `whether those targets will be met is really too early to say'. Why did the Minister mislead the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Short wants to talk about misleading the Senate, he can do that very well by taking things out of context, which is what he has just done. As to the particular quote to which he refers, I said in the course of an interview—which was five minutes after I appeared on the Channel 9 program—that it was a question of when the Budget forecasts would be attained. That is quite consistent with what I said yesterday. I said:

ANSWER.PARA: That's been slower than we would have wished—
that is now—
but I think it will have its effects and the question is when. I'm not saying that it's impossible to attain the budget figures for a moment.
I repeat:
I'm not saying that it's impossible to attain the budget figures for a moment.
Selective quotation is very helpful, but I would not have thought there was anything more explicit than that: `I'm not saying that it's impossible to attain the budget figures for a moment'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I again ask the Minister: why, in light of his saying that he had immediately realised that he had made a mistake on the Channel 9 interview, did he then go on to repeat that same mistake on the Channel Ten interview shortly thereafter? Also, did he speak with any other Ministers or their staff about the doubts that he had expressed on the Channel 9 program as to the Budget growth forecasts before repeating them in his interview with Channel Ten?
—As I said yesterday, I subsequently put out a press release—
—That is not the point.

—Let me decide what the point is; I will answer the question. I subsequently put out a press release which I initiated myself after leaving Channel 9 before I spoke to any Minister. I said that yesterday, and if Senator Short can work that out he will see that the answer to the question is quite clear: I did not speak to any Ministers or their staff before I initiated a press release.
—What about when you went on the next one?

—Look at the sequence in which the things follow. I went to Channel 9; I left Channel 9; I spoke on Channel Ten; I initiated a press release; I had not spoken to any Minister at that time. That is the answer to the question. If any of those opposite, instead of interjecting stupidly, can find any inconsistency with that, they had better get up and point it out—but there is none.

PARA.TAB: This attempt to elicit some mileage from what I said on the Channel Ten program is answered by what I have just quoted to Senator Short. I will quote it again: `I'm not saying that it's impossible to attain the budget figures for a moment'. And that is what I have maintained throughout.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is too early to say.

—It is too early to say in the sense that in October 1992 it is too early to say, when one is contemplating growth rates through the year, what they will be at any precise point. But I am talking about the Budget targets. If Senator Short does not understand what the Budget targets are, they are for 3 per cent through the year. That is what the Budget target is and that is what I believe will be attained. That is what I said here and what I said yesterday.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate about the current situation regarding the Commonwealth Observers Group in South Africa? What will Australia's role be in that group?

—The Australian Government has agreed to participate in the Commonwealth Observers Group in South Africa. We have also invited the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, Professor Duncan Chappell, a very distinguished Australian, to be the Australian participant in that group which is now being formed. He leaves today to join the group now convening in South Africa. He is a respected criminologist with particularly extensive experience in issues of violence and community policing and as such is a particularly appropriate choice for the task in question.

PARA.TAB: The proposed Commonwealth group, which consists of 15 members from a wide range of Commonwealth countries, will be working in close association with members of the South African National Peace Secretariat, which was established under the national peace accord agreed by all parties in South Africa last year. The Commonwealth observers will also work closely with other international monitors, in particular, from the United Nations and the European Community.

The Commonwealth group will have a four-fold role: first, advancing community relations through meetings and discussions with community groups and individuals; secondly, attending rallies and demonstrations to ensure the Commonwealth's visibility and, of course, to observe events; thirdly, attempting to do something about any incidents of violence witnessed by observers in close consultation with the National Peace Secretariat; and, finally, observing and attending meetings of the local and regional dispute resolution committees in those areas where the group would be located.

The presence of international observers who are acceptable, as these Commonwealth people certainly seem to be, to all the parties should help to promote reconciliation and improve the prospects for a negotiated settlement within South Africa. We can only hope so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. How can the Government justify the imposition of up-front fees for the open learning initiative which will discriminate against the very students it claims to benefit, namely, those students from traditionally disadvantaged backgrounds? Secondly, as the open learning initiative is being financed by $53m worth of public funding, does the Minister agree that it should be governed by the rules that apply to other publicly funded education institutions, especially in relation to education standards and student consultation? Finally, how will the Government ensure that quality is maintained in degrees acquired through open learning?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have trouble with the word `discriminate' in this question because, apart from half a dozen pilot courses which have previously operated, this is an entirely new initiative. We are introducing something here that did not apply before. In that sense, it does not discriminate; it confers an advantage on the community, particularly an advantage on people who, because of geographical isolation, do not have access to university or higher education, people who because of work and family responsibilities cannot attend or people who are in socially or physically disadvantageous situations. `Discrimination' is hardly the right word to apply to a new scheme that did not operate in Australia before.

PARA.TAB: It may be that the word `discrimination' is being used in this sense in relation to the fees. I do not think it can be said that the fees are genuinely a disincentive. There are 3,762 paid up participants in the pilot program at this stage. That exceeds the expectations of the Department and the Government when it first put forward this initiative. Broadly, the fees are no greater than the fees that would ordinarily apply under HECS. In that sense, there is a level playing field.

The other questions that Senator Sowada raised are about quality. The quality of education in this case will be assured because we are using the existing universities. All of the existing universities are jealous, and rightly so, of their reputations for quality delivery and they have to protect those. It is not the same as the system that would have applied in the United Kingdom; so we cannot extrapolate from that example. We have also used the lessons learnt through the distance education centres in how to provide these services in a way in which they can be received and appreciated by the users.

Indeed, a major purpose of the initiative is to tap the economies of scale available from this teaching mode for the thousands of distance education courses currently available. The tendering process the open learning broker will use to purchase these materials will, by definition, ensure that the best courses are selected. Moreover—and I think Senator Sowada would be aware of this—last October the Government announced a quality assurance and enhancement initiative aimed at ensuring that all universities continue to seek to maximise the quality of their teaching provision. Since courses being offered by open learning will be drawn from the existing university sector, the Government's quality framework will be as relevant to open learning as it is to other aspects of higher education.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Justice advise the Senate of the role being undertaken by the Australian Federal Police contingent which constitutes part of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia? Where is that contingent located and what type of work is its officers doing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was in early May that a group of 10 AFP officers visited Parliament House prior to being deployed to Cambodia where they are now forming part of the civilian police supporting the United Nations Transitional Authority in that country in its attempt to provide a peaceful and lawful environment in which elections may be held so that enduring peace, good order and good government may be brought to that very troubled land.

PARA.TAB: The AFP contingent, under Superintendent Bill Kirk, has been deployed to an area in north-west Cambodia. I understand that the contingent's patrol area covers some 2,500 square kilometres and has a population estimated at 82,000 people, although this is growing at a rate of about 1,000 per week as refugees return to Cambodia from Thai refugee camps.

The time of arrival was the dry season when everything was very barren. But now, with a change in season, I understand that much of the area is often impassable and patrolling in the muddy areas is extremely difficult. But the Australians have set up a camp and have already established extremely good relations with all of the various factions which operate in their area. They have set about their law enforcement tasks with great vigour and have received plaudits from many, including Senator Newman who was able to visit them on one occasion during the winter recess. I know she was very impressed by their professionalism. I will quote from a military report by a senior Australian Army officer who recently visited the police contingent. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I am thoroughly impressed by the AFP members' professionalism, enthusiasm, sense of purpose and achievements. They appear to have achieved more than any other civilian police detachment in Cambodia.
I understand that that view is held by senior United Nations officers in Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: At night, the team conducts English classes for the people in the area. It is establishing virtually the only written law for that area at the moment. The Australians are establishing extremely good contacts with the children—the hope for the future—in the areas that they patrol. I believe that as they patrol that area they are certainly achieving a lot for Australia's reputation and deserve the goodwill that is evident towards them, which is being manifested by the local inhabitants. Out of their own personal funds they have built and constructed their accommodation, which is quite extraordinary. At the end of the term they intend to hand over that housing and accommodation complex to the local population.

I am extremely proud of the contribution of the Australian Federal Police to the United Nations Transitional Authority efforts. I know that that view is shared by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. I know that it would be shared by all members of the Senate and, indeed, the whole Parliament. I wish it well in its endeavours in that troubled country. I am confident that it will continue in its efforts to bring about peaceful and lawful conditions where there can be a lasting and enduring peace achieved on behalf of those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to comments made over the weekend by Dr Tony O'Reilly, President, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of H.J. Heinz globally, concerning a comparison of Australian and New Zealand manufacturing costs. How does the Minister respond to Dr O'Reilly's comments that New Zealand manufacturers have a cost structure generally 75 per cent of that of Australia's and that Australia's micro-economic reform performance can only be seen as grossly unsatisfactory? How can Australian and international business be expected to invest, develop and expand in Australia when it is so much cheaper to do business in New Zealand?

—Dr O'Reilly's company has bought a significant company in New Zealand in what is a very obvious strategic move, in that the company was for sale and is in Dr O'Reilly's area of business. That does not mean for a moment that the Heinz operations will not be maintained in Australia. In fact, Dr O'Reilly, the Chairman of Heinz, has affirmed that Heinz will continue to be a major producer in Australia.
—For Australians.

—I repeat that Heinz will continue to be a major producer in Australia. Dr O'Reilly has, in my presence, said that himself when referring to the problems that it has had in this country. Some companies complain of external problems which cause them difficulties; other companies in exactly the same businesses do not have those problems. —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Does the Government support the decriminalising of marijuana?

—The Federal Government has a position in relation to drugs which, to my knowledge, is endorsed by all governments around Australia and certainly by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy, which is a meeting of health and police Ministers held around Easter of each year.

PARA.TAB: In relation to marijuana, there has been no change in policy. Australian governments have a two-pronged approach, that is, to use law enforcement agencies to try to interdict supply to deal with the supply side. In particular, of course, the Australian Federal Police has a role in so far as there may be plantations, for example, in Papua New Guinea and there may be an attempt to bring marijuana products or cannabis products from those plantations across Torres Strait or from elsewhere overseas into North Queensland and then distribute them throughout Australia. State jurisdictions have their own responsibilities in so far as marijuana plantations might occur within their jurisdictions.

But the use of law enforcement and the criminal law is only a very small part of the effort to deal with drug abuse. Perhaps the more important part is the education and health rehabilitation side of dealing with abuse of drugs, whether legal or illegal. In that respect, Senator Reid may be interested to know that in Tasmania the gold medallist, Stephen Hawkins, the double sculls winner, has been appointed a drug offensive ambassador and is visiting most of the schools in Tasmania, encouraging our youngsters to understand that to smoke any product, whether it be tobacco or marijuana, would impair their health and their sporting performance and is therefore to be avoided.

So, in short, the Federal Government's two-pronged approach to the question of the use of cannabis products and marijuana in this community will continue and I believe this is a policy which has the full support of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy.

PARA.TAB: That has been acknowledged in all Australian jurisdictions as being compatible with the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy drug offensive program and is compatible with Australia's international law obligations in so far as the use of marijuana is concerned—in other words, personal amounts for personal consumption.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications inform the Senate of any measures that the Government has taken to ensure that Australians in rural and remote areas benefit from the telecommunications reform process?

—The Government is committed to ensuring that all Australians benefit from the Government's reform of the telecommunications system, not just those in highly populated areas. Tangible benefits of the Government's policy include a reduction in long distance call charges as competition is introduced. The Government has insisted that Optus extend its network coverage to the whole of Australia by the end of 1997 so that the competition provided by Optus to AOTC will be a reality no matter where one lives in Australia. The Government has also imposed a price capping regime on AOTC, which will mean that prices will be pegged to rise at 5.5 per cent below the CPI for a basket of services.

PARA.TAB: AOTC has introduced a new pricing policy for the connection of telephones which will ensure that the vast majority of new customers will pay less. In rural areas customers on properties will save money by being able to dig their own trenches rather than having to pay AOTC to do it. Most importantly, the Government has imposed a universal service obligation on AOTC to require it to provide a basic telephone service and pay phones to all Australians. Austel has the task of ensuring that this obligation is met.

This arrangement was put in place following the announcement in 1990 that the Government's policy is based on the maintenance of community service obligations, particularly to rural and regional areas, pensioners, and people with disabilities. At present 94 per cent of Australians have access to the telephone. This is very impressive by international standards. But as Robin Davey, Chair of Austel, has commented, `Ninety-four per cent is only good for 94 per cent'. The Government is committed to ensuring that the remaining 6 per cent get access should they want it.

In order to ensure that this commitment is being met, the Government has asked Austel to investigate whether and to what extent there are unmet needs in rural and remote areas in relation to the standard telephone service. The investigation is to provide an assessment of the current arrangements for ensuring the delivery of services throughout Australia, especially to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities which, of course, are amongst the most remote communities in Australia.

Austel has announced that it wants to hear from as many people as possible to assist in making recommendations to the Government. To this end it will conduct a series of public seminars in rural centres beginning in November. I have also asked Austel to conduct a separate investigation into the adequacy, location and accessibility of pay phones. Again, public comment is eagerly sought and seminars are going to be held by Austel for this purpose. Both of these inquiries will focus not only on ease of access but also on the quality of the service. It is no good having a phone if it is constantly breaking down and cannot be repaired. Both these reports are due to be delivered to the Government by the end of December this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations: what was the level of industrial unrest in Victoria at the start of this month?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the ABS produced the statistics for industrial disputation in Australia for the month of June and there are four quick points I can make about them. Firstly, the figures over the year show a continuing downward trend in industrial disputes in Australia under this Government. Secondly, the figures would have been better had it not been for the poor performance in New South Wales, particularly in October last year, when, because of the New South Wales Government's industrial relations legislation, there were major disputations in that State which pushed what was a low performance for Australia higher than it needed to have been had that Government adopted a more cooperative approach to industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, the figures for Tasmania show a huge spike upwards in the graph, which indicates the massive dislocation in that State under the Opposition style industrial relations practised by APPM at Burnie; and, had that dispute not occurred, the figures would have been even better. Fourthly, it shows that the level of industrial disputation in Victoria—which is the point of this question—is off the bottom of the graph; that is to say, at record low levels.

The next point I would like to make in response to the question asked of me by Senator Cooney concerns comparisons with the Australian average. For Australia, the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees for the period was 194, the lowest since September 1990. However, Victoria reported 82 working days lost per 1,000 employees. Comparing the Victorian figure with the Australian average indicates that, certainly in the last months and generally over the last few years of the Kirner Government in Victoria, industrial relations was well handled, disputes were very low and there was a great deal of industrial harmony.

It is important to note those facts as there is now a change of government in Victoria and the new Government is embarking on what it calls, I think wrongly, industrial relations reform. One of the major differences between the two major parties in Australia is this: we have an ability to deliver industrial harmony and a peaceful industrial relations outcome; the Opposition has a high disputation, big confrontation industrial relations approach. In terms of foreign investors looking at this country, it is now becoming increasingly known abroad that Australia as a country is a good risk because industrial disputes are low. This could be jeopardised if the confrontationist approach of the Opposition were to be followed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity to lecture Senator Button about the English language. I refer to his use of the English language. Having said `I could not be absolutely certain about the growth targets' he then acknowledged that—
—I didn't say that. Get it right.
—It is close enough. Would the Minister like to give me the exact words by way of interjection?
—`I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those now. . . '.
—Yes, he said `I am not absolutely confident that we will achieve those targets'.
—I said, `. . . that we will attain those now. . . `.
—I will quote what the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we gave growth figures in the Budget forecasts. I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those now but as we move towards them employment will improve.

He used the words `towards them'. He then admitted that that use of English was unsatisfactory because he then said, `I have not expressed it very well'. That is an admission that whatever he said then was clearly not satisfactory—he had not expressed it very well.

PARA.TAB: So in order to make certain that his English was understood he went away to Channel Ten and, as he said quite properly, when asked a question he replied, `I think so'. But he only thought so. He did not have any confidence, because he then went on to say, `. . . whether these targets will be met it's really too early to say'. This is how he corrected his expression. Having not expressed it very well, he went on to say, `. . . whether those targets will be met it's really too early to say'. So he did not say it. He only thought that maybe, perhaps they might be. Of course, he then said that this was not incompatible with their being met. Who knows, if we are terribly lucky and if the Government is extraordinarily lucky, maybe they will be met.

The fact is that his correction, if it was a correction, very clearly restates his uneasiness about achieving those targets. Anything this man who is cornered comes out with is seen as nothing more than semantic nonsense. I invite Senator Button's attention to the Australian Financial Review of today and to an article written by Mr Geoff Kitney, a man who I understand has been known to be quite friendly with both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). Many of his stories appear to come closely from that source.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are well sourced.

PARA.TAB: After a telephone call from Mr Dawkins, Senator Button released a statement reversing his comments . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is what Mr Kitney says, and I presume Mr Kitney had some knowledge of the view of both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. Then we notice an extraordinary use of the English language by Senator Button today when he said, `I had initiated a press release'—not `I put one out' but `I had initiated a press release straight after Channel 9'. The big question is: did he in fact speak to the Treasurer before that press release went out? It was interesting to see the way he resiled—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Exactly. The answer is yes, he did. The facts are that before he put out the press release he got caned and was told to put out a correcting press release. There is a big difference between initiating a press release—in other words, thinking, `Gee, I did mess this up'—and fixing it up. (Time expired)

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling on 13 October 1992 relating to Aboriginal self-government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note that, in answer to the question on the constitutional conference in Darwin last week and a paper given to that conference by Senator Margaret Reynolds, Senator Collins today acknowledged that the Norfolk Island self-government situation cannot be used as a precedent for Aborigines or Torres Strait Islanders in any future application. That was an important acknowledgment. However, I was very concerned that Senator Collins weaved and ducked and shrugged when it came to answering how compatible Senator Reynolds's comments were with the policies of either the Federal Labor Government or the Australian Labor Party. Senator Collins had the opportunity, both in answer to the question and in answer to the supplementary question, to come forward with clear answers on that matter. We are all well aware that this is an important point because of the recent Mabo decision which has very important implications for the future. A number of initiatives are coming from indigenous people's conferences throughout the world and also, of course, from certain land rights and legal issues in Canada. A number of people are arguing very strongly for changes in this regard.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned that Senator Collins would not dissociate either the Federal Labor Government or the Australian Labor Party specifically from Senator Reynolds's comments, which I have no truck with her holding as a personal individual, although I would disagree with many of her comments. I have noted Senator Reynolds's full paper. I have noted some of the precedents that she calls for and the examples she gives in many of these political areas.

I also take issue totally and fundamentally—and I took issue by way of a point of order—with the comments of Senator Collins when he said that I had denigrated Aborigines. I have certainly raised many issues in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio that go to the heart of accountability and scrutiny—I do not give a damn whether a person is black, white or brindle; a crook is a crook is a crook—and I will conbtinue to ask questions in all circumstances where I believe there is a lack of accountability or proper scrutiny in the expenditure of money. Where something is wrong, it is the Aboriginal people who are missing out on the benefits that are very properly provided by this Parliament, the Government and State and Northern Territory governments.

Certainly, Aboriginal funding programs are an issue that concerns me greatly because of the very large number of Aboriginal constituents in the Northern Territory and we do need to ensure that benefits that are provided by taxpayers reach the community in the way they properly should. However, the issue canvassed today in the question related to the very essence of the paper of Senator Reynolds. Certainly it is important that the issue be discussed in a constitutional conference context, but it is important to note that Senator Collins would not give the views of either the Federal Labor Party or the Federal Labor Government on this most important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on this motion to take note of an answer given by Senator Collins, I am absolutely appalled that Senator Collins should say, in the way he has, that the Opposition has denigrated the Aboriginal people.
—Not true. `Senator Tambling', I said. He has a 15-year public record of that.

—Senator Collins said `Senator Tambling' and he also referred to the Opposition. How he can say that after a decade of his Government, with the Aboriginal community in the appalling wretched circumstances it is presently in, I find remarkable. Senator Collins had an opportunity to do something about it and he did nothing. There were hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue lost to the Aboriginal community in respect of the Koongarra project that his Government, for crude, political reasons, would not agree to.
—You can't sell the stuff—and I'm an advocate of the industry. You can't give it away.

—That is an argument for the marketplace, not an argument for government. The same thing applied to Jabiru. Senator Collins might like to tell us about Coronation Hill. Is he trying to tell me that we cannot sell gold, we cannot sell lead? Of course we can. The bottom line is—Senator Collins knows it, and his Government knows it—that that project should have gone ahead, but it did not go ahead for crude, political circumstances in an endeavour to get themselves across the line for the last election. Hundreds of millions of dollars have been lost to the Aboriginal community which could have gone to their welfare, their health, their education and their housing. It was put aside in the vain hope that it would cause those opposite to be re-elected.

PARA.TAB: We have a million unemployed in Australia. Which is the end of the market that is having the most trouble getting a job? It is the unskilled end. Of course, the Aboriginal community will be in wretched circumstances, unable to find employment or any prospect of employment, as long those statistics are hanging over them.

One only has to look at Western Australia in terms of health. In the Kimberley there is 30 per cent of Western Australia's population 90 per cent of the venereal disease and most of it in the Aboriginal community. What is being done about their health by this Government and the State Government of Western Australia? Absolutely nothing. What is being done about alcohol rehabilitation centres? Absolutely nothing. What is being done about education? Absolutely nothing. What is being done about housing? Absolutely nothing. What is being done about the care of the Aboriginal community? Absolutely nothing.

If Senator Collins wants to argue about land rights, if he wants to argue about manipulating votes and getting to the polling booths—like booth fodder—on the day to get his Government elected, that is his priority. But when it comes to care and compassion, and changing their lifestyle, changing their circumstances, changing their prospects of living past 40, there is absolutely nothing on Senator Collins's agenda. They have been a political and social experiment for the Government for the last decade and nothing looks like changing until there is a change of government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Campbell on 13 October 1992 relating to tariffs on four-wheel drive vehicles.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button came into the Senate after Question Time and finally admitted, after three questions and three denials of having received any representations or correspondence on the matter of four-wheel drive tariffs, that he had indeed received four letters during the past six to seven weeks. I reiterate that he did so after denying this three to four times in the Senate in the past few days.

PARA.TAB: This whole saga about the tariffs on four-wheel drives, and the `based on lies' phrase that Senator Button used with respect to certain elements of the mining industry and members of the Opposition, came out of a specific reference to a speech made by Hugh Morgan in Perth only a few days ago wherein Mr Morgan, quite properly it seems now, asserted that the Federal Government was giving consideration to increasing the tariffs on four-wheel drive vehicles. Senator Button said last week in the Senate that that assertion by Mr Morgan, the head of Western Mining Corporation, was `based on lies'. Senator Button has come into the Senate today and informed the Senate that he has received no fewer than four letters specifically dealing with the increase in tariffs on four-wheel drives. Indeed, one need now ask: who was the one who was lying?.

Senator Button has today revealed that he has covered up the fact that this Government has received specific representations on increasing tariffs on four-wheel drives. The public now has a right to know not only the fact that he has just received these letters and these proposals to increase tariffs on four-wheel drives, but also which companies and which people have written to the Government in regard to increasing the tariffs on four-wheel drives. Senator Button has said that this assertion was based on lies, that the Government was not considering increasing tariffs on four-wheel drives. What the public now needs to know—and what I call on Senator Button to reveal—is who the companies are that are lobbying the Government to increase the tariffs. That is the question that requires an answer.

Senator Button, as the third most senior Minister in this Government, should also have the grace to do more than merely come into the Senate and say, `I made another mistake', or, `Sorry, I tripped up again', or, `I got things wrong', or, `It was my office's fault or my Department's fault. Gee, I am sorry, Senator Campbell; even though I denied it and said that I had received nothing in the last six to seven weeks, I made a mistake'. He should come into the Senate and apologise to the Senate for misleading it.

There is no distortion as to how someone can semantically look at a transcript for Senator Button to argue that he has not misled the Senate. On three occasions he has told the Senate explicitly that he had received no correspondence and no submissions from the vehicle industry seeking to increase the tariffs on four-wheel drives. He has now come into the Senate and said that in the last six to seven weeks he has personally received four letters specifically dealing with that subject. The Senate is owed an apology. The public of Australia is owed the information as to which companies are now asking this Government to increase tariffs on four-wheel drives.

The other point that needs to be made is that Senator Button has this afternoon said that there will be no increases in tariffs on four-wheel drives. This, again, totally contradicts what he said on Thursday, 8 October, in the Senate. He said that from time to time the Government received submissions on tariffs—even though he denied receiving any on four-wheel drives. Of these submissions, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: They will be considered, as they have been in the past, in light of the developments in the automotive market.

We know that the automotive market changes month to month, year to year, and that there are significant changes in the four-wheel drive market. So Senator Button must now clear up what he means: whether there will be no increases, or whether there will be increases, and whether he is considering them. I call on Senator Button to clear up this matter. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the time for debate today and that the speaking times during the debate will be as follows: Senator Alston, 20 minutes; the Minister, Senator Collins, 20 minutes; Senator Bourne, Australian Democrats, 15 minutes; Senator MacGibbon, the second Opposition speaker, 15 minutes; Senator Schacht, the second Government speaker, 15 minutes; and Senator Powell five minutes. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of this motion need little elaboration. Indeed, in many respects the facts speak for themselves. Perhaps the only criticism that one could genuinely concede is that we have understated the extent of the policy flip-flops that we have seen over the last four to five months in particular. Senator Collins of course, as probably the longest serving Minister in this portfolio over the last couple of years out of about four or five predecessors, is in a position to be acutely aware of many of those policy changes because he has been on the receiving end of most of them and in almost every instance has been comprehensively rolled.

PARA.TAB: I go to the question which, as Senator Collins was kind enough to suggest, we should be debating now—and that was obviously why he declined to answer it when it was asked of him a short while ago. But all sides of politics, I suspect, would like to see digital compression introduced as quickly as possible; in other words, digital technology applied in the introduction of pay television. The only question, of course, that has always been around is: what would be the lead time? The purpose of my questioning Senator Collins was that he was on the record, in his usual mild and modest manner, comprehensively bagging anyone who dared to suggest that it might be possible to achieve it in the near term. Of course he was at that stage claiming that it was at least four to six years away.

We do not have any quarrel with the proposition that, if it is around the corner, that ought to be the start-up technology. But I think it would be useful to all concerned if we could indeed have the correspondence, to which the Minister has referred, tabled in the Senate so that proper and objective judgments could be made about these matters. Senator Collins said, for instance, that Optus had recently tendered certain advice. Well, Optus of course was on the record several months ago in its submission to the Senate committee. What I think we would be interested in knowing is: what has changed since that time to persuade the Government from a position where, until yesterday, it had been resolutely defending the contrary proposition?

Indeed, the Department of Transport and Communications has been consistently tendering advice which has been very questioning of the proposal that digital technology was just around the corner and, if indeed this latest policy change is based on departmental advice, I would have thought we should hear about it in the same way that we heard from the Department during the committee hearings. Otherwise, of course, it simply indicates that the Government is making decisions to suit itself rather than trying to make policy fit the facts.

Therefore, I invite the Minister to provide the Senate with a lot more information that would justify this decision. As I say, we are quite happy to support it, but we would like to be confident that consumers are not simply going to be asked to take another 12 or 18 months or even a couple of years breather before pay television comes along. As I recall, MPEG2 is not scheduled to be discussed until March of next year. No-one can assume that that will then result in the immediate adoption of a standard transmission technology and, therefore, I think we ought to know what the latest information is.

One does not have to go back much beyond June to be horrified about the changes that have taken place in the Government's policy on pay television. No doubt Senator Collins is going to trot out the sort of nonsense he trotted out in Question Time to the effect that somehow we had a different policy position. The fact is that as Senator Collins has—

TALK.START.PARA: —You had six.
—We now know that Senator Collins has almost completely, whether willingly or unwillingly, come around to all the major elements of our policy position.
—Which one?
—The four that Senator Collins adopted last week at FACTS, for a start, but all the essential propositions that we ran with throughout the Senate committee hearings.
—I wonder why we did that. Do you think it might have had something to do with the fact that we want to get it through the Senate, Richard?
—Ah, very interesting. So it has nothing to do with the merits, nothing to do with whether it might work—
—Do you not think it has merit?

—Nothing to do with whether it is right for Australia, nothing to do with whether consumers are going to benefit from it. It is all for the sake of being able to say that those opposite can trot something out in the run-up to an election that will work. That must be the ultimate cat out of the bag, I would have thought.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Minister, Senator Alston has the call.

No, it is all in order for the Government to get something through the Senate. I can understand politics to a certain extent, but I would have thought Senator Collins would not have been quite as up front and barefaced as to concede that.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Alston. Minister, I notice you are next on the list. TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair is trying to save Senator Collins from himself. Senator Collins has dug himself so far in that anyone who for the slightest moment—and they really would have to have come from Mars—thought that somehow the Government had some integrity in its policy approach to pay television will be completely and utterly disabused of that position as a result of what he has said. So I am grateful to him for his interruptions to that extent.

PARA.TAB: Let us just look at some of the basic issues. The role of the ABC has been one in which we have consistently argued from the word go that the ABC ought to be mandated a place in the sun. Of course, if we were starting on analog, that would mean a transponder. For all intents and purposes, `channel' and `transponder' are interchangeable, are they not? But if one is talking digital, of course one is talking about a channel, unless one wants to give it at least four channels. We have always said that the ABC ought to get a channel.

If we go back and find out what position the Government has adopted on the ABC, it is quite extraordinary. The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in June last—and that is only a few months ago—was reported as having vetoed a Senate proposal that would have guaranteed the ABC a role in pay television. This is the sort of thing he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is part of the ideological manic determination of the Liberal Party to push the ABC onto pay TV, off free to air—

The Prime Minister would not have a bar of it; over his dead body would the ABC get a guernsey. What did Senator Collins say? He was reported, as recently as the seventh of this month, as saying that while he supported the ABC's involvement in pay television, `you run into real difficulties if you think about mandating a role for the ABC'. End of game because, of course, that is precisely where we now are. The ABC is going to be given its place in the sun.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they?
—Well, are they not?
—Good, I am glad of your support.

—Senator Collins knows our position and ought to be aware of the consistency of our position. If he is now telling me that all the newspaper articles over recent days have once more got it wrong, I am appalled that he has been so modest in not correcting them and indeed putting out press releases in spades. So we are left, I would have thought, to proceed on the basis that some of these reports at least have a scintilla of accuracy. For example, they all say:

SPEECH.PARA: The way was cleared for pay TV to begin when the Government and the ABC agreed yesterday to a deal to allow the broadcaster to bid as part of a consortium. . .
Of course, that story of compromise was furiously denied in the following days because we then had the following story:
Mr Keating was said to be furious about the proposal last week by the Transport and Communications Minister, Senator Collins for the ABC to join a consortium to allow it to bid for the first licence.

That is the starting point of this week's flip-flop. Senator Collins is out there arguing that the Corporation ought to be part of a consortium, but Mr Keating is saying, `No way. I am not going to let the ABC in—full stop'.

PARA.TAB: Now the latest is that the ABC will be allowed to get its own licence. That is what Mr Keating told the Centre Left faction and no doubt Tom Burton was there at the meeting, because he has quotes.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are always the centre of attention.

—The Senator is, indeed, and I was going to ask Senator Collins to respond on Senator Schacht's behalf today, because I would have thought that in many respects Senator Schacht would be claiming most of the credit for these policy changes.
—You could talk under 10 feet of wet cement!
—Look who is talking! As I said, Tom Burton was clearly at the meeting last night taking notes. He got it right. He quoted Mr Keating who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the system should provide the ABC with a single dedicated channel.

In other words, Mr Keating has now dropped his opposition to the ABC getting automatic access to a pay television channel. That is what he told the faction. If that is wrong, let us hear about it once again. Margo Kingston says:

PARA.TAB: The move follows a veto by Mr Keating of a deal struck between the Communications Minister, Senator Bob Collins, and the ABC last week, which would have allowed the ABC to participate in a bid for the first licence.

SPEECH.PARA: The deal was to have been discussed in Cabinet last night, but Mr Keating's opposed this. Government sources said Senator Collins had agreed to the latest plan as a way of extending the ABC's service without harming its free-to-air service. . .

What is extraordinary about all this is that, unless these articles in every national newspaper are a complete figment of the imagination of some of the leading journalists in the country, then a lot of people have been leaking like sieves. I would not want to suggest that Senator Schacht in any way answers the telephone unnecessarily, but the fact is that we have all sorts of very detailed reporting of what has been going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never unnecessarily, Senator.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Schacht, if you want to interject, you must return to your seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —If none of this is true, it is really wasting a lot of valuable time for the poor unfortunate readers who are being consistently misled, the poor old politicians who somehow think it represents a reasonably accurate report and the poor bunnies in the Centre Left faction who thought they were being told the truth as well.
—Most of it is wrong.

—Most of it is wrong? I would have thought that now is the opportunity for the Minister to set the record straight. That will be just another version of events until we finally see the legislation. How could anyone in his right mind have confidence that what Senator Collins might tell us today represents the Government's final position?
—It is not.
—That is right. Another cat out of the bag. The Minister is really trying to make a virtue out of being wrong.
—A blinding piece of information that is! It has to go back to Cabinet.
—The Minister for being wrong! Let us imagine what Bob Mansfield might be saying today as he sits behind his desk at Optus, because this is what he said a couple of months ago:

SPEECH.PARA: The series of government backflips on pay-TV policy has left Australia looking like a circus economy. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht, you must return to your seat if you want to interject.
—I am!
—You cannot do so on the way. It is just unacceptable.
—He is another one who cannot help himself. A couple of months ago Bob Mansfield said that the latest turnaround was needed:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . like a hole in the head. . . It made us look like a joke overseas, decisions like that from the Government.

Honorable senators can imagine what he must be saying now! I would not be surprised if he was told to pack up and give it away. How can anyone ever make sensible commercial judgments on the basis of decisions that change daily? It is very charitable to suggest that there have only been four changes over the past four or five months. We have had a whole heap of stories about Senator Collins accepting advice from those in the industry. I think Aurora's was about the only one out of 67 submissions that actually said that the 12-month exclusivity had legs. Of course, Aurora had an interest in saying that.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that it was never going to get off the ground and Senator Collins knew that. He was telling the Prime Minister as hard as he could but, as usual, no-one would take any notice of his advice, because Senator Schacht was doing the Prime Minister's bidding. He was going along with this 12-month nonsense, even though he did not believe it. He said so himself at the start of the proceedings that he thought we needed at least the five years that Richo thought was a great idea. But, of course, he came around to do the Prime Minister's bidding and duly signed on for the 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the evidence, you fool.
—No, it is not the evidence at all, because if the Senator wants to go on the evidence, it was for a lot longer than 12 months.

—That is exactly right. That is why Senators Beahan and Faulkner argued for three years and Senator Bourne for about five years. No-one supported 12 months except Senator Schacht and the Prime Minister. Collins knew it was dead in the water and told the Prime Minister accordingly. No doubt that is why it has now been scrapped.
—Senator Collins to you!

—Senator Collins; I am terribly sorry. That is why it got the chop. It never had the slightest hope of working and the Government was terrified that it might find itself going to the election with everyone in the industry saying that they would not even bother putting in a bid because the scheme was so preposterously hopeless. That is why it has now been thrown out.

PARA.TAB: I could go on to talk about all these policy changes, whether it is foreign ownership or equity interest for current commercial players who were to be frozen out for the first 12 months until last night. Now they are back in the game with a vengeance. As most of the commentators say, it is very much in line with the approach that we have maintained consistently for many months—that is, that all players ought to start up simultaneously.

I would be very interested to know how the Government can now justify one player having three transponders, which I presume means 12 channels, when the other two, apart from the ABC, will presumably get only one transponder—four channels each. If that is not the case, then the Government is getting even closer to us, because the logic is that each of the six, apart from the ABC's channel, ought to be auctioned off simultaneously.

We are now in the position where no-one really has the vaguest idea of the ultimate shape of the policy proposal. All we know is that there has been a plethora of competing and conflicting models touted around in the media in recent days, presumably deliberately, because these things just do not make themselves up. No matter what one might think of the media in this country, I do not believe for a moment that some of these journalists go out and dream it up. It is done on the basis of discussions they have with the major players and they are being told all sorts of conflicting stories. If these reports are in every paper in the country, then it is no coincidence. All I can say is that, if Senator Collins somehow thinks he is in control of the debate, then he ought to—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a dangerous theory.

—If the Minister had any sense of being in control, he would have to concede that over the last week or so it has been a shambles. What is any intelligent commentator—let alone interested party—to judge from all that has taken place over that short period, let alone over the last four months?

PARA.TAB: I suppose the ultimate is to go back to where we started on that notorious Sunday when Mr Keating was out there ripping up 16 years of committee inquiries and careful analyses by the Department and everyone else who had an interest in the subject. He was trotting out something that Senator Schacht was widely reported as saying had stunned Senator Collins.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixteen years! The technology has changed a lot in 16 years.

—That is right. Indeed, it has changed in 16 years, but not to the point where the Government can suddenly put something on the table which trumped both the current Minister and his predecessor, shocked everyone in sight and then had to be changed comprehensively within a couple of days. All this had to be justified by a Prime Minister who boasted that Greg Louganis had won a gold medal for his backflips. At least he had the grace to go on and say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . provided they are done with the appropriate degree of panache and style, they serve a very useful purpose.

I do not think anyone could claim to have done that in this instance. All those backflips have done is cause a lot more injury to the Government than was ever caused to Greg Louganis, who hit his head on the way down. All I can say is that the Prime Minister must have smashed his head on the side of the pool well before he got to the water. I do not think it would be a fair contest between Senator Collins and a diving board, but at the moment he is very much out of his depth in this whole area. I hope he will at least take the opportunity now to provide some sort of coherent explanation of where the Government is going on pay television.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, since I notice that you asked Senator Alston to refer to you as `Minister', it may be appropriate for you to use the appropriate title in respect of him in your interjections and in your forthcoming speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry for calling Senator Alston, `Richard'.
—There is a standing order, Minister.

—I retrieve that piece of friendliness. Madam Acting Deputy President, as I said by way of interjection, I get very few laughs in the Senate, but Senator Alston provides most of them. The Hansard will indeed give me another laugh tomorrow when I read it.

PARA.TAB: The Government introduced its position on pay television in a very substantive fashion; that is, by way of legislation into this Parliament. Of course, this situation does not just apply to pay television. It applies to every single piece of legislation that the Government has in its program. We have a two-House system of parliament, a bicameral system of parliament, which I understood the Opposition supported.

The Opposition has said some very nasty things about people who want to abolish the Senate, but we started this debate with the absolutely nonsensical assertion by Senator Alston that the Government has committed a dreadful act in moving to make changes to its position on pay television in order to get the legislation through the Senate. That is what Senator Alston said.

I just point out to Senator Alston the blindingly obvious truth that that is indeed the very function of this chamber. That is what we do with Bill after Bill after Bill. We have a new system under which Bills are referred to special committees set up by the Senate—this Bill was in fact sent to a special committee—in order to seek common ground between the three major parties and the Independents so that legislation can be passed through the Senate. If we did not do that, none of the Government's legislation would be passed. I hate to point out that blindingly obvious truth to Senator Alston.

Pay TV was excised from this Bill as a result of a motion moved by Senator Alston. As I said during Question Time, in terms of po-faced hypocrisy Senator Alston takes the cake. The Government is criticised in the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Alston for changing its position on pay TV. Yet the motion to refer this section of the Bill to a committee of the Senate in order to change the position of the Government was moved by Senator Alston himself.

It is an absolute nonsense that Senator Alston is putting to this Senate. Indeed, as I have commented publicly, it is a fact that since part 7—that is, our position on pay television—was taken out of our Bill and removed to a Senate committee, we have been dealing with this matter assiduously. We have been dealing with this matter in a way which will produce a result which provides firstly, a viable pay TV model; secondly, one that is acceptable to the Government; and thirdly, if it is to see the light of day, one that will receive the support of the Senate. I did not think something as blindingly obvious as that would have to be restated for the benefit of Senator Alston.

I cannot believe that Senator Alston ever actually appeared in court as an advocate. I will repeat for Senator Alston's benefit: `as long as it gets through the Senate'. That will not be the case, Senator Alston. I will repeat the three conditions: the first priority is to establish a model for pay television which is viable and which works; the second is one which is acceptable to this Government; and the third is one which of necessity has to get carriage in the Senate. They are the three criteria that the Government has used.

The facts are that the Government has not been dealing only with pay television. Pay television in fact has been a relatively small part—it is certainly the one that has received most media attention—of the very substantial initiatives that this Government has taken in broadcasting legislation. We now have in place in this country a fundamentally restructured telecommunications regime where active competition is in place and more is on the way. I might add for the benefit of the Senate that the tenders for the third mobile licence for this country close tomorrow.

We have in place a complete revamp of broadcasting legislation for this country. A new authority has been set up under new legislation, the Broadcasting Services Act, and is now actually functioning. Pay TV was just a relatively small part of these initiatives in broadcasting. Pay TV was taken out of this broadcasting legislation by the Senate, not by the Government. But the other sections—the most important sections—of the Broadcasting Services Bill have not only been passed by the Senate and enacted, but also the new authority is now in place and is actually functioning.

I have just announced major reform of spectrum management by which the vast range of users will have better and more national access to spectrum. Spectrum management is unglamorous but it is the very fundamental base on which all broadcasting in this country is based. The spectrum management changes that the Government has announced are a significant part of its micro-economic reform agenda.

So this Government can point to, firstly, an overhaul of telecommunications arrangements that dated back to Federation; secondly, a revamp of broadcasting regulation which was 50 years old; and, thirdly, reform of spectrum management arrangements which also dated unchanged from Federation. All of these areas have involved the Government having to deal with complex issues and conflicting interests.

Pay TV is just one part of this very large package of reforms. It is an important part, but only one part. Notwithstanding the complexity, we are the only group of people to have worked out a pay TV regime. We tackled it after other people had dithered with it for 12 years. We are the ones who put the framework together. We are the ones who consulted manufacturers, the television and film industry, program providers and the rest.

The Government's framework was introduced into this Parliament as part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Bill and it was the Senate that took it out and insisted on changes. That is not a unique thing in the Senate. Despite Senator Alston's surprise, it actually happens every day.

In fact, as I commented on in Question Time today, the process involved the Leader of the Opposition, Dr John `take-no-prisoners' Hewson, sitting in the advisers box, hauling out poor old Senator Alston into the corridor and nailing his ears to the wall. He also hauled out Warwick Smith, the honourable member for Bass, who was also in the chamber. In order to accommodate at least six distinct shifts in policy changes by the Opposition from midnight till 2.30 in the morning, we agreed—the only time I have seen it done in here—to bring on the adjournment debate to allow them time to sort out their position. It was bizarre; it was straight out of Monty Python's Flying Circus.

Of the almost 100 amendments introduced into this place by the Opposition, only eight were supported; and some of those were wrong and had to be fixed by the Government. We all remember—I know Senator Powell will—the amendment that the Opposition moved to protect journalists' sources. That amendment had the effect of ensuring that judges would be put in gaol for asking journalists to disclose confidential sources. As honourable senators will recall, the Opposition even put it in the wrong section of the Bill.

The amendments to give the ABC a free transponder for pay TV were similarly ill-considered, appallingly drafted and totally unworkable. What this Government is about is producing good public policy in the interests of not just the industries affected but, more importantly and most importantly, the Australian consumer.

What is the Opposition's policy on pay television? Is it reflected in the continuing stream of statements from the Opposition's spokesman on communications? No, it is not. The real agenda for the Opposition in referring this matter on the question of the ABC to a Senate committee and derailing it, was purely and simply to try to take attention away from the fact that it is committed in its Fightback document to emasculating the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I will have a bit more to say in a minute about the Opposition's illustrious Leader's amazing public statements about that. The Opposition is hell-bent on dismantling the national broadcaster of this country.

In regard to channels—Senator Alston talked about channels and transponders—as far as the Government is concerned, pay TV licences must be able to cater for any technology, be it satellite, cable or MDS. It is the service provided and not the technology used that is the concern of the Broadcasting Services Act and the consumer. The licensing of access rights to transponders was proposed in part 7 as a system neutral method that allowed the licensee to determine the transmission system and, hence, the capacity of the transponders. Optus has since said it will only offer channels, not transponders, for lease.

Senator Schacht interjected and said, `It is a fact that Optus has changed its position'. The very purpose of the meeting yesterday between Optus, myself and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was to enable Optus to tell the Prime Minister that it had fundamentally changed its position. It was the changed position and the advice that the provider of the satellite which is linked to this service gave to the Government that caused us to examine the current model that we are examining now. Despite contrary arguments, the model has great merit.

To sensibly regulate licensed pay television, one must clearly define what is being licensed. The two transmission technology options for satellite services—digital or analog—could offer widely differing numbers of services. While a transponder-based regime could cope with either, the number being licensed would be uncertain. The Government therefore sees considerable merit in moving to license channels, as Optus wished, as a way of providing a flexible regime that is technology neutral and allows for the appropriate regulation of ownership capacity.

As far as digital compression is concerned, I want to say this. Senator Alston said, `Table the document that has brought the Government to the position of making this decision'. We will table the report of the Senate Committee that Senator Alston served on. It is a fact, and it was agreed upon by every commentator whom I saw, that in terms of the disparity of the evidence given and the wide diversity of opinion in the reports that were being delivered, that Senate Committee report fundamentally took the debate back to square one. It fundamentally said to the Government, `At the end of the day, it is still your decision; make it'.

Many of the serious bidders for pay TV licences to whom I have personally spoken say that they intend to start their services with digital technology. Irrespective of whether one agrees or disagrees with the commencement of digital technology, it is a fact that we are reaching the end of the analog era and the beginning of the digital technology era. Like optic fibre cable to the home, CDV, as it is called in the business, is clearly the way of the future for satellite services. There are many advantages—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you say four to six years ago—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Alston, the Minister was good enough to restrain himself to a certain degree in terms of interjections. It would help if you could reciprocate in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, there are pros and cons to both sides of this debate. On balance, because of the firm position that Optus has now taken, it is clear who the advantage now favours in terms of coming down with a rational policy. There are advantages—
—Were you wrong?

—No, of course not. I refer Senator Alston to the Senate Committee report, because there he will see the diverse range of opinions on this subject. There was no subject with a more diverse range of opinion in terms of evidence given to the Committee than on this question of technology.

PARA.TAB: There are advantages for Australia if digital technology is adopted from the outset. Australia would have the world's first digitally compressed, direct-to-home satellite pay TV service, as was recently pointed out by Bruce Gyngell. It would increase the number of channels per transponder on the Optus satellite fourfold and it would allow a more pro-competitive licensing regime. It would solve the problem of cost to the consumers for any transition from analog to digital technology, which was one of the matters that was of great concern to the Government and which we were trying to address in a number of ways.

Industry development packages on Optus and the licensees would create manufacturing opportunities with export potential for Australian industry. It would be a catalyst for upgrading the nation's communications infrastructure with state-of-the-art technology. More than one multi-channel operator could emerge to provide greater diversity and choice for the consumer of in-home entertainment. It would allow the networks to participate without dominating the service and to structurally adjust from the outset to this new medium and technology. Finally, it would allow the participation of the ABC in this service in a sensible way.

As I said before, Senator Alston really takes the cake. The Government introduced its model for pay television as part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Bill. The Act came into force last week. The pay TV industry could have been well on its way now had the Opposition not chosen to block the passage of this Bill in the Senate during the last sittings. Who moved the motion to block its passage and refer it to a Senate committee? Senator Alston, the one who is now complaining that the Government has indicated that it is prepared to change its position on pay television in order to get this industry established and to get the Bill through the Senate. Why was the Bill hived off to the Senate Committee? As I said before, it is obvious to anyone that the coalition is anxious to allow the ABC into pay television so that it can cut off its funding.

The debate on pay television has clouded the true agenda of the coalition. The average member of the public may not yet be waking up to what is going on, but the ABC is in no doubt as to what the coalition has in mind for this unique national broadcaster. The coalition is proposing the biggest single funding cut ever in the 60-year history of the organisation. This statement, which was put out by the ABC Board, is what the ABC had to say about the potential effects of such a cut. If this Fightback cut is ever imposed on the ABC, it would mean:

SPEECH.PARA: .significantly reducing Australian content on ABC TV, e.g. Australian drama, documentaries and education programs;
.closing down State based production,—
That is very important in places like the Northern Territory, where I come from. Locally based production is always the first thing under the hammer. It will be cut down, as will:

PARA.TAB: . . . the 7.30 Report, local news and sport);

SPEECH.PARA: It would also mean:
.radically cutting the number of hours broadcast per day—
that is, the total number of TV transmission hours. The statement continues:
.closing down at least one of the three national radio networks, either ABC FM, Radio National or Triple J;
.significantly reducing local and regional programming, e.g. closing metropolitan, regional or local stations.
