PARA.TAB: In the Andrew Olle ABC radio program only a couple of months ago in Sydney—this was replayed on Lateline only a short time ago—in the context of cuts to the ABC's funding by the coalition, the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that you have an organisation called ABC TV Marketing. I think you will need it.

If any evidence were needed—not that it is—to nail down precisely the real agenda of this Opposition, which is to emasculate the ABC, that is it. It thought that it was doing a clever little political stunt when it attempted to set the Government up by weeping crocodile tears for the ABC during the Senate debate on pay TV and trying to position the Government as the enemy of the ABC because we were opposing its involvement in pay TV.

PARA.TAB: I have news for members of the Opposition, and I know that they are dismayed by it: that ploy will not work. We are proposing a model for pay TV that should ensure, considering what position the parties have adopted in here on previous occasions, that this model will get the support of the Senate and will become law. Therefore, the coalition's position on this will be stripped bare. The real enemy of the national broadcaster of this country—the coalition—will become apparent once again.

The Government has currently agreed to look at a number of fundamental changes to its position on pay TV in order, as I said at the beginning of this debate, to provide a pay TV regime which is viable and will work, which the Government is prepared to support and which at the end of the day, if such a regime is to see the light of day, this Senate will also support. I am confident that when the legislation is reintroduced into this chamber, the model that will be brought back here will be supported. Indeed, from the comments made already by Senator Alston, we can be confident that if such a model appears in here it will be supported. The position currently is that the matter is still being examined by Government. I intend to take a submission on this matter to Cabinet next Tuesday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few months we have seen a great deal in the newspapers about what is supposedly happening with pay TV policy at any one time. This morning the latest thing we saw in the newspapers referred to a system which we have not heard anything about from the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) and very little about from Senator Alston. I would like to know whether the system that was mentioned in the papers this morning is the final one that would be given to us. I expect to get a briefing from the Minister's office.
—You will.

—I hope that briefing will say that that system is not the final one. I will spell out the system that was mentioned in the papers this morning. Four channels will be given to an outside broadcaster who was not involved in any way. Only one channel will be given to the ABC, which will be used for news. Four channels will be given to a current media operator within Australia. There are some real basic problems with that as far as the Democrats are concerned. First, it is very unfair to the ABC. If we give the ABC one channel and make sure that it is used for news, there will certainly be very good news and current affairs on that channel. But if we give four channels to another media operator and to an outside bidder, surely one of those four channels will be news. It will probably be CNN or BBC.

PARA.TAB: There are a lot of news channels out there waiting to get into the Australian market. Those news channels do not show Australian news. When I was overseas recently I looked at the CNN broadcasts and the BBC Asian broadcasts. There were two Australian stories on both of those in a two-week period. One was on dolphins on the north coast and one was on the Qantas jet which had been ordered to go back to where it was by Americans. Those are not substantial stories as far as Australia is concerned. They are not substantial enough to have an entire Australian news service based around them. I do not want do see that as my news. If the ABC puts up decent news, which it would—the Minister has agreed to that—it will have only that one news channel. If the ABC is to be mandated with this it should be given the same rights as any other station coming into this market right at the beginning. It should be given four channels and be able to do what it wants with them.

The other basic problem we have with this issue relates to cross-media ownership rules. We believe that there are too few people in Australia today with far too much power as far as the media—newspapers, television and radio—is concerned. I believe that is a general view held by the public and held by most of this Parliament. There are far too few people in Australia at the moment with far too much power in the news media. Giving four channels—nearly half of what we want to give out in this first licence agreement—to a current media operator would be a very bad move and a very regressive step for Australia. We are just giving concentration of more power in the news media to too few people.

We are concerned that Australia's pay TV policy is becoming as chaotic as was Britain's when subscription television was introduced there in the mid-1980s. The Minister shakes his head. I hope he is right. The way it looks at the moment is that decisions are made just before the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) goes before television. Decisions are made at meetings of the Centre Left. Decisions are made in the oddest possible places and are then broadcast—

TALK.START.PARA: —They never make a decision about anything.
—I am glad to hear that.
—The Australian Democrats of the Labor Party, they are.

—I am absolutely horrified to hear that. These decisions are broadcast and then the Labor Party has to wear it. That is what it looks like to the outside public. That may not be the case and I certainly hope it is not. That is the way it looks to the general Australian public. That is the way it looks to us. If the Minister can tell me that it is wrong and he can show me that he has a better system, please do. I will be really looking forward to it.

PARA.TAB: At the moment I am in the middle of reading a book called Dished: The Rise and Fall of British Satellite Broadcasting, by Peter Chippindale and Suzanne Franks. It is the story of British broadcasting looking into subscription television. It is a horror story to rival Dracula. I am sure if the Minister has read it—I believe he has—that he will agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a horror story; it is a comedy.
—It is a horror story. I do not want Australian subscription television to turn out like this. At the moment that is the way it looks like it is going.

PARA.TAB: In a perfect pay TV world we would see several goals. The first of them would be digital. We would like to see everything go out in the beginning in digital. As the Minister said—I think he is completely right—there would not be any necessity for the general public to move from analog to digital. I think that is something that we all agree with and is the only positive aspect in what the Prime Minister announced last night.

The second goal is to see that the ABC is given a fair role. We do not believe that it has been given a fair role if what was announced last night is what is going to end up happening. The third goal is obviously cross-media ownership. We still believe, as I said, ad nauseam, that there is far too much power in the hands of far too few people. Foreign ownership is also important. We do not want to see too much foreign ownership; we want to keep it to the levels that are already established—that is, under 35 per cent.

Local content is very important. No comment was made on that. I hope the Minister can enlighten us. He is nodding his head. We would like to see local content in a perfect pay TV world not only on drama but on news and every channel. Anyone who wanted to have less than 20 per cent—I think 20 per cent is a reasonable minimum—would have to go to the Australian Broadcasting Authority and get an exemption to go under 20 per cent. I am talking about any channel; children's programs, drama, news, comedy, light entertainment and movies.

Manufacturing content is another important aspect. That was certainly not mentioned last night. The report of the Senate Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services has recommended that manufacturing content should be high, Australian, mandated and put into the legislation. That is something that we still maintain ought to be done. That was maintained by everybody.

Exclusivity is the other issue that we have been talking about. We still believe that if we start off with one player in pay TV, or even two, we will need some exclusivity period before everybody gets into it so that these people can actually get their act together, can get under way, can use Australian manufacturing and not have to go to Korea to get pieces and can actually get going and make some money. Everybody knows that the famous J-curve applies to pay TV. It has done around the world. We start pouring money in and then we get money back. That is why we need an exclusivity period.

I was very pleased to hear the Minister support the work of the Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services. I can recommend to him the tables in the report that show that the exclusivity period ought to be somewhere from three to seven years. I am referring to the ones on Australian content, which go from 60 per cent up to 70 per cent for manufacturing and 25 per cent up to 50 per cent for programming. I also recommend them to the Opposition.

The Minister made one very important point in his speech which has to be taken up—that is, the fact that the Opposition is saying that it supports the ABC but in its Fightback package it is saying that it would cut down on ABC funding by 10 per cent, which is outrageous. The Democrats could not possibly support that, would never possibly support that, and I am very encouraged by what the Minister has said that the Labor Party would not support that either. The ABC does a very good job on very little funds. It does not need to have them cut back any further. It cannot have them cut back any further. I am horrified to hear that that is what would happen in the Fightback package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With such a diatribe against the Opposition, the government to be, I thought we were set for half an hour on that speech. This afternoon the Senate has before it a motion that was moved by Senator Alston. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's continuing policy shambles in the area of Pay Television as evidenced by yesterday's announcement of its fourth policy position in the last four months.

With the greatest of respect to the speakers who have preceded me, apart from Senator Alston, the point at issue is not the Government's policy on this but rather the great plethora of changes. We simply could not be precise in attacking a policy position of the Government because, frankly, we do not know what it is. It changes all the time and the Government obviously cannot even brief journalists with the leaks in a consistent way so that one story can get in the press. It is no wonder we have a mess in the policy area when we have a speech like the speech we just had from the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). He made a number of points which I will pick up in the course of my speech. I am glad for his sake he is going; he never likes punishment.

PARA.TAB: He made a long diatribe about this being a bicameral legislature and somehow or other we did not understand that fact. I can assure him that the Liberal Party understands very well the position of a Senate in a bicameral legislature and the position and the importance of checks and balances on a legislature. We certainly never wanted to get rid of this chamber the way the Labor Party did.

The Minister was making the point that he was changing his position constantly because somehow or other legislation had to pass both chambers. That really is dissembling. He is saying that the Government is groping for a position which will be acceptable to this Parliament. It does not have any policies of its own; it is just stumbling along trying one theme after another, one change after another, so that it can try to get something through the Parliament. There is no fixed philosophic or technical position in what the Government is proposing. The great number of policies that it has run through this Parliament on pay TV is witness to that.

Senator Alston made the point that there were four positions. I understood Senator Collins to say, by way of interjection at Question Time today, that there were only three. Having just looked at my file and found this great heap of papers outlining government policy over the years, I believe there were far more than three. But how many policies there are does not matter; the point is that there should have been only one.

When the Government came into the chamber with its legislation it should have known precisely what it wanted to achieve. Instead, as I said before, it is just groping for a solution to a problem which I do not think it understands fully. Those opposite do not understand fully the technical ramifications of it, they certainly do not understand its implications in relation to industry policy and the Australian community, and I do not think they really understand its implications for the existing players in the field—the free to air television people.

I think this is one of the reasons for the malaise in the country. It is not only in the area of television that the Government does not know where to go, but also I do not think it knows where it wants to go on any point. If there is one thing the community needs at the present time, having got into all of the difficulties we are in under the Labor Party, it is a clear direction as to where we are going and how we will get out of the mess we are in. We see right across the spectrum of the Government's activities a total inability to know where it is proceeding.

This is particularly important in relation to business. I do not carry a brief for business. I am no Engine Charlie Wilson, the head of General Motors in the 1930s, who said that what was good for General Motors was good for the USA. But I do believe business has an important place in the community and the Government cannot be negligent of its interests. Unless we have profitable business in the country we will have high unemployment and falling community standards. So the welfare of business is very important.

In dealing with business, the Government does not have to make commercial decisions on its behalf, but it does have to get rid of the fog of obscurity as to what its policies might be. Business is well able to cope with difficulties in the marketplace. What it cannot cope with is the uncertainty of not knowing what the rules will be today and what they will be tomorrow. Business needs to know whether it can invest money, go to the banks and underwrite loans so that it can see a way in which to carry on. Certainty of government is one of its key requirements. It is one of the fundamental failings of this Government that at the moment it is providing absolutely no certainty at all for Australian business.

The television inquiry, which I was a part of, and the way in which the legislation has been handled is witness to the fact that the Government does not know where it wants to go or how it wants to get there. We were promised at the early part of this Parliament that pay television legislation would be introduced, and it only came in before the winter recess at the very last moment. The reason it came in so late was that, even then, the Government did not know where it wanted to go.

But it is not correct for the Government to view pay television as it does: as just a small segment of the entertainment industry. Quite clearly, the Government, the Minister or the Cabinet do not understand the importance of pay television in the scheme of things in the Australian community. It is not merely a matter of entertainment, as they see it; it is part of the whole communications industry which is one of the most central industries in a modern industrial society. So many things turn on this: the whole business of data transfer, information technology and transfer, the machinery of providing that, and the business of writing software programs. All of these are very high value added activities and there are many spin-offs in the communications industry other than the ability to sit down, throw a switch and watch a movie or a sporting event. In this decision the Government is absolutely blind to all of these other elements

It is an area where very rapid and exciting changes are taking place. There is a possibility of linking houses and buildings together—even units within the buildings—and being part of what is known as the interactive communications area, with people talking, transferring data and all the rest of it. This is all part and parcel of the larger picture and it is something to which Australia cannot close its eyes. We have to be part of it or we will be paying, and paying heavily, for other countries to provide those services.

Another thing the Government has not considered in its policy is the relationship of the free to air providers—the three established channels and the ABC—to the introduction of pay TV. We are a small country with a small population. While the introduction of a new format in the form of pay TV will clearly increase the number of people watching television, one can be quite certain that there will be a diminution in the audience which is at present watching free to air television—channels 7, 9, 10 and the ABC—because a competitor will be introduced into the pool.

That will have a marked influence on the profitability of the present free to air commercial stations. The days are long past when those stations had a licence to print money. Times are now pretty competitive for them and, while they should be making a profit, I do not think they have too much room to move in their commercial activities before they get into a great deal of trouble. Whilst I do not think it is the Government's business to guarantee their viability in any way, I think, having set up the legislative framework under which these channels were established, the Government clearly has an obligation not to do anything which makes precipitate change to their continued existence.

I now turn to where we have gone with these policies. I have said that the introduction of the legislation was very tardy because the Government did not know where it was going with it. When the first announcements were made about the legislation, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), at the behest of his friends in the industry, made ex cathedra statements right over the top of his Minister at the time who was responsible for the legislation which was coming into the Parliament. The legislation was brought into the Parliament and the Senate simply could not agree on what was being presented. The Government then made overtures to the Australian Democrats and others around the place and tried to get something done. The Prime Minister came in again with further amendments to policies—all done on the run.

If one goes through the files one will find that all sorts of positions have come from the Prime Minister. He has advocated a position whereby there would be no advertising on pay television, but he walked away from that. He then came up with the proposition that the first four transponders would go as a block, they would have 12 months breathing space and then the other two channels would go. We then had the Senate pass legislation which went to the House of Representatives. We had another position from Mr Keating and then we had the Senate inquiry. We then had a prohibition from the Prime Minister on the ABC being a part of the program. It now seems that all of that has gone.

I want to deal for a moment with the claim—which was made falsely by Senator Collins—that there is a war between the ABC and the Opposition. The honourable senator made all sorts of allegations to the effect that we wish to cut off funding and drive the ABC out of business. That is not our intention at all. When we are in debt to the tune of $6 billion—I am not sure whether that is what it is this year; it is probably going up day by day and adding to our internal Budget deficit—we obviously cannot go on living beyond our means. There is nothing sacrosanct about the ABC. If we are going to cut back the defence budget, as the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) indicated in the Budget, and get rid of expenditures for what are fundamentally important departments, the ABC has to take its place along with the rest of them.

I would like to quote a few things that, purely by chance, I have with me. I was not going to use them, but since Senator Collins brought the matter up I will. I have here a transcript of an interview with the Prime Minister by Maxine McKew on 3 June. She asked him something about the ABC getting into pay TV and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well they are out of one to four, because I think everybody is tired of the old faded and jaded players, they want some new entrants in the Australian media. That's what the Caucus wanted, they wanted a new media player who has not had its antecedents in the newspapers, or in existing television networks, but a new set of players. And the arrangement the Government has now introduced, or will be introducing, is for the first four transponders, we'll see in a new medium of media—
that is a strange phraseology—
a new set of players.
If anyone is opposed to the ABC, Mr Keating fits the said bill. There are plenty of views on this. I have here a quote from Mr Tom Burton in the Sydney Morning Herald. I quote one paragraph:

The complete opposition by Mr Keating, who seems to have an almost obsessive hatred of the ABC, to any concession for the Corporation means that there is now a very real chance that the Government will not be able to secure passage through the Senate of its pay TV legislation.

That was earlier in the year. I have also found an interview with Mr David Hill, the Managing Director of the ABC, on the AM program of 1 June. I would like to read one of the paragraphs which is in context to that which I am saying where Peter Thompson asked him about Mr Keating's position. Mr Hill said:

Frankly, no. I must say in fairness to Keating, as a new Prime Minister, this communications policy is very complex. As a new Prime Minister, I think he has the right to feel comfortable about the way it's been developed. But if you think about this, the arbitrary five-year moratorium on pay expires in October; we've been debating the detail of this for at least two to three years; we've had six Cabinet Ministers; untold changes to the rules; and here we are at the 11th hour with, we understand, the proposal going into Cabinet today. . .

That is all very true—untold changes to the rules. I return to where I started. We have a situation where the Government simply does not know what it wants to do. It briefed a whole series of journalists last night. I have read most of those accounts. The inconsistencies of those accounts illustrate the fact that the Government still does not have a coherent policy. Until the Government knows what it wants to do, there is no hope of it being able to come into this chamber and put a clearly reasoned and coherent argument before the Parliament, and then the Parliament can decide whether to support those policies for the introduction of pay TV.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance brought before the Senate by Senator Alston concerns the Government's policy on pay television and the introduction thereof. I speak as a person who has been involved in pay television, as Chairman of the Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services and as a member of the Labor Party's Caucus committee in this area. Pay television is an important issue, but it is obviously not the major or even one of the major issues before the Australian people. But it does attract an inordinate amount of interest amongst aficionados of the media in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Over recent weeks and months, I would have thought that the amount of space given in the printed media in particular but also in the electronic media to discussion about pay TV has been extraordinary. I would like to have a dollar for every time any one of the following journalists have tried to ring me or have rung me for views about pay television. This is in no sense a list of honour, but I think they ought to be given a mention because they have often given me a mention, sometimes without even speaking to me. Joanne Grey, Tom Burton, Bina Brown, Peter Wilson, Deanie Carbone, Fred Brenchley and too many to even list from the ABC have all been persistent in wanting to write, discuss and talk about pay television.

Obviously, much of their interest is because it is in an area of their own employment, their own interest, and because of their own concerns about issues relating to the existing television networks, newspapers, the ABC, telcos and so on. I do not blame them for having that interest, but I reiterate that in my time here in the Senate I cannot recollect a specific issue that has attracted so much attention from journalists. I will not decry it; I think it is very good as part of the public debate because there are important issues about the structure of the operation of pay television in Australia.

I refer to some of the remarks made by previous speakers and some of the general comments made in the community. First of all, Senator Alston quoted Mr Mansfield, the Managing Director of Optus, in his remarks some weeks ago criticising the Government's policy as announced and brought into this chamber on pay television, saying that it was a disgraceful way and it was inconsistent and so on. Mr Mansfield has never mentioned that, in Optus's first submission to the pay TV Select Committee, it argued for a restrictive form of pay television: one licence holder to have an exclusive licence for seven years in which to operate a very restricted system—mainly, I suspect, the best way, Optus thought, to get a return on its transponders in the satellite.

Then just two or three days before the completion of the Senate Select Committee's work Optus suddenly announced that it had done a 180-degree turn. It no longer argued for any exclusivity, it no longer argued for a limited number of licences; it said, `Let us go straight to digital and, in that, anyone who wants a licence to broadcast in pay television via our satellite will get one'. That is the dramatic change Optus made. It was a 180-degree turn in just 2 1/2 weeks from when Optus personally gave evidence before the Committee at the beginning of our hearings to that which it then announced at the end of the period in a document circulated to the press. So I am a little bemused by the criticism of Mr Mansfield in his comments on Government policy.

Then we come to the comments made by the Opposition. It has been criticising the Government on the structure of and the Government's discussions about pay television. Let us have a look at what the Opposition is up to. When the Opposition debated pay television in this chamber, we found Senator Alston sitting at the table being tapped on the shoulder every three seconds almost from the adviser's desk by Mr Warwick Smith, the shadow spokesman on telecommunications, changing their minds on any number of issues, particularly the role of the ABC, as they tried to work out an arrangement with the Australian Democrats to get the matter referred to a select committee. It seemed, certainly from this side, a very belated interest in the ABC from the Opposition.

However, when Opposition senators actually came to write their report, it was not surprising to the Government members of the Committee to find that they had put in a dissenting report. They basically dissented from everything. When we get to the bottom line in their dissenting report to the pay TV Committee's report, they basically have no policy at all. They have no industry policy. They have no policy on industry, on what participation there should be for Australian industry to get its share and to ensure that we can develop a manufacturing industry based on pay television in Australia. They do not want a bar of that. They do not want a bar of rules that establish a minimum level of Australian content for pay television. That has all gone by the board. So, again, another part of Australian industry is wiped out. They do not want to have any cross-media ownership rules. It does not concern them at all. They just raffle off, auction off, the six existing transponders for whoever is the highest bidder to do with them what it likes. They do not want any cross-ownership rules, content rules or industry.

Certainly, in their questioning in the Committee they showed no concern at all for any question of commercial viability. They did not accept any level of exclusivity. They were not concerned, in discussions with any of the people who came before the Committee to give evidence about how to establish pay television, that commercial viability, in any way, should be a concern of the Australian Parliament, the Government or anybody else. As far as they were concerned, if people want to make an investment and the whole thing falls apart, that is their problem.

Those opposite said here today that the Government does not have a policy. The Government did introduce legislation into this chamber, passed by the House of Representatives, outlining a model for pay television. The Senate did not carry it because the Opposition and the Democrats referred that section to the pay TV Select Committee. But we did come up with a model. The only model that we have before us from the Opposition—because we certainly cannot rely on what Mr Smith has said as being a model—is what is in the report, and there is no model at all in the report. The Opposition says, `We are not interested in any rules whatsoever'.

The final thing about the role of the Opposition towards providing a mandated channel for the ABC is its own view towards the ABC. Senator Bourne said that they want to cut $50m off the ABC budget. That is a reduction from $500m at the moment to $450m. That will do much more damage to the ABC than providing it with a mandated pay television channel.

I was bemused the other day in Adelaide to be involved in a radio debate on the ABC with Alexander Downer, a senior shadow Minister for the Opposition, when he was questioned about the impact of the $50m cut backs for the ABC outlined in Fightback. He said, `But, of course, the $50m can be recouped by the ABC because of the money they are going to make out of pay television'. Nobody in any of the hearings we had or any of the evidence before us said that the ABC was going to make $50m a year from year one of the operation of pay television. That was the paucity of the argument and the knowledge the Opposition has about the ABC and, above all else, about pay television. Everybody believes, and gave evidence, that it would take a number of years for pay television to start making a profit, but Mr Downer says that from year one the $50m cut back in Fightback for the ABC can be covered by the profits from pay television.

The issues still to be resolved in pay television are the basic issues that we have been debating for so long now. No matter how you argue or juggle them, there is always going to be an argument about the balance between the three basic issues. I have said this before in the Senate in previous debates. We have to balance exclusivity to help commercial viability, with diversity of ownership to provide a more diversified media in Australia, vis-a-vis providing competition so consumers get a choice. Viability, diversity and competition are principles that are in conflict with each other and we have to balance the three to get a workable model. In doing so, we have to make some concessions and compromises on the purity of each of those positions.

The final argument that has to be resolved is an issue that is vexing everybody—and I defy anybody at the moment to have the perfect answer—of whether we should start with an analog technology or wait a bit longer and start with digital. In the Committee that I chaired, we got absolutely conflicting evidence. Some people said start with analogue because digital is too expensive. Others said wait till digital, because it will provide a wider capacity and a more profitable system because it can provide more channels.

But we cannot get agreement from any of the experts as to exactly when the digital standard will be established world-wide. We cannot get any agreement on the cost of a digital decoder—black box—system to operate for the consumer. The general figures are agreed that an analog so-called black box would be around $200 to $300 for the consumer. Figures for a digital black box are now ranging between $800 and $1,400. Everybody says that that will affect the commercial viability for pay television to operate because that cost to consumers is such a substantial amount they may not be willing to make that investment. If the operators themselves want to provide it as a leasing option, the investment figure for them is so high that it still may make pay television in the opening years of digital such a loss making operation that it cannot even start.

That is one of the arguments that has to be debated and carefully considered. It should not be done in an ideological manner or a point scoring manner. It is a matter of extreme technical complexity of whether we should start with digital or whether we should start with analog and migrate to digital. Even this afternoon, I have had further submissions put to me by interested people pointing out that digital will certainly cost in excess of $1,000 and will take more time to develop, but everyone agrees that ultimately digital will be the technology.

The other issue that has to be dealt with is what level of encouragement we give to the manufacturing sector of Australian industry to produce the equipment that is internationally competitive in both price and technology. Then we can develop an industry that not only provides the equipment in Australia but can also get into providing equipment for the export market in the biggest expanding market of all for pay television, which is our own region, the Asia-Pacific region.

Finally, I turn to Australian content. If we do not have some rules for Australian content in pay television, it will be overwhelmingly derivative from programming content from other countries. That will not encourage Australian producers to produce content—not only for Australian pay television, but also for sale to pay television in other parts of the world. In both of those areas I believe we need a model that establishes rules for manufacturing industry and for Australian program content. I believe that the Australian content rules should encourage individual production houses not in-house production, because in-house production is much harder to define and keep tabs on as to how much is being spent.

The debate on pay television has obviously gone on for a lengthy period. I believe that we will get a decision to come back into this chamber in the very near future where this Senate chamber will decide the issue politically about the model of pay television. The Government introduced a model here previously, the Opposition parties and the Democrats opposed it and it went to a select committee. We will have to deal again in the very near future with a model with further amendments to get a political outcome to a decision that this chamber created two months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a short time to speak on this motion moved by Senator Alston in which he complains about four policy positions in four months by the Government with regard to pay TV. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Visit by Prime Minister to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) relating to his recent visit to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move a motion relating to the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: VISIT TO JAPAN, SINGAPORE AND CAMBODIA
Mr President
I take this opportunity to inform the Senate of the outcome of the visit the Prime Minister made to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia between 20 and 26 September.
This overseas visit was his third since becoming Prime Minister.
All three visits have been to Asia-Pacific countries.
All three visits have helped put a sharper focus on Australia's relations with the region.
A primary objective of each visit has been to talk with other regional leaders about how we can work together to respond to the fluid outlook in the region.

But just as importantly, the Prime Minister has also wanted to underline to both Australian and foreign audiences how much the Australian economy has shifted towards an international orientation, especially an Asia-Pacific orientation; how much Australia has already achieved in the region; and how much our future depends on successfully carrying forward this engagement.
More than is sometimes appreciated, the Asia-Pacific region is in the midst of a period of profound transition.
The strategic consequences of the end of the Cold War are still working themselves out.
The regional security outlook is generally favourable, but less predictable than before.
The peace process in Cambodia, which involves an ambitious role for the United Nations, confronts a serious test of its sustainability.
Fluidity in the international trading environment is increased by uncertainty about the outcome of the Uruguay Round.
Whatever the outcome of the Round, we shall probably see an increasing trend towards regional, subregional, and bilateral trade arrangements.
Regional governments are now required to develop policy responses to what could well be a rapidly evolving pattern of trade alignments.

Asia-Pacific countries also need to consider how international and regional institutions can better reflect the growing weight of the region in world affairs, and the increasing importance of intra-regional linkages.
Mr President
The Prime Minister's visit to Japan was very worthwhile in consolidating with the Japanese Government the strong community of interest we have with them in responding to these important questions.
The Australian public understands very well Japan's significance in our external relations.
Japan is the world's second largest national economy, accounting for about 14 per cent of global output.
It has been our largest trading partner since 1970.
Perhaps more than is generally appreciated in this country, Australia is also an important regional partner of Japan.
We are Japan's third largest source of imports and sixth largest trading partner.
The bilateral trade relationship, now worth around 24 billion Australian dollars, is one of the principal sinews of economic interdependence in the Western Pacific.
The close dialogue between the two governments on regional and international issues reflects the habit of friendship and cooperation that has grown up between the two countries in recent years.

Certainly, the warmth of the Prime Minister's reception by the Japanese Government and the quality of his discussions with Prime Minister Miyazawa and his Ministers attest to the maturity of the relationship that we now enjoy with Japan.
The comments of Mr Miyazawa and his Ministers reflected, I think, a realistic view of the international scene.
There was cautious optimism that the Japanese economy would return to a stronger growth path from the end of this year.
There was a determination, which the Prime Minister supported, that Japan should play a more active role in international affairs.
The Prime Minister affirmed Australian support for Japan's permanent membership of the United Nations Security Council so that the world body can better reflect changed world circumstances.

He welcomed Japan's decision to participate in United Nations peacekeeping operations, and the opportunity this provides for our military and civilian personnel to work together in support of the Cambodia peace process.
Mr President
The Prime Minister discussed international and bilateral trade issues with both Prime Minister Miyazawa and International Trade and Industry Minister Watanabe.
They acknowledged an uneasiness in Japanese political and business circles about the increasing trend to preferential trade arrangements.
Prime Minister Miyazawa expressed the personal view that an open and non-discriminatory multilateral trading system could be maintained despite these developments.
He made clear his government's deep commitment to a cooperative relationship with the United States, and its support for an early and successful outcome of the Uruguay Round.

In underlining the importance of the bilateral trade relationship with MITI Minister Watanabe, the Prime Minister said that Australia would not be party to any trade arrangement which was directed against Japan.

This commitment was reciprocated by Minister Watanabe's assurance that Japan would conduct its trade on a commercial basis without discrimination against Australia's interests in any arrangements with third countries.
Minister Watanabe reiterated this undertaking in the particular case of Australia's exports of automobile parts to Japan.

In discussing the outlook for the Uruguay Round, the Prime Minister urged Japan not to hold back on the rice tariffication issue, because otherwise it ran the risk of being portrayed by others as a final obstacle to a settlement on agriculture.
The Japanese Government acknowledged the responsibility it faced.

The Prime Minister's discussions with Japanese Ministers also covered the need for expanded bilateral air services to cater for the expected increase in tourist traffic, MITI's support for Australia's trade promotion in Japanese regional centres, and Japanese involvement in the MFP project in Adelaide.

In a general discussion of defence relations, the Prime Minister confirmed the Government's satisfaction with the current moderate level of activity which includes high-level visits and dialogue on strategic issues.
Mr President
The Government attaches considerable importance to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation or APEC process as an essential mechanism for promoting open regionalism.

The Prime Minister explained to Prime Minister Miyazawa the thinking behind the Government's proposal for establishing over the medium term a process for periodic heads-of-government meetings based on APEC membership.
Such meetings would add political weight and status to the APEC process.
They would fill a significant gap in institutional arrangements in the region, enabling leaders to consult together in a way which has become familiar in European and trans-Atlantic relations.
The Prime Minister was encouraged by a marked firming of Japanese support for the proposal.
Prime Minister Miyazawa welcomed the initiative and agreed that the idea should be pursued further in consultation with other members of the region.
Former Prime Minister Takeshita also firmly supported the proposal.

A special feature of the visit was the Prime Minister's agreement with Prime Minister Miyazawa to issue a joint statement setting out for the public record an account of the regional perspectives which figured prominently in our discussions.

The statement demonstrates convincingly the extent of parallel interests we share with Japan in regional strategic and economic issues, and the potential we have for working together productively in the region.
It also makes clear that the cooperative relationship we aim to pursue with Japan is by no means an exclusive one.
Rather, it is directed towards broad-based cooperation with other countries in the Asia-Pacific region, including especially the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I table a copy of the statement and a copy of the joint press statement issued by the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister of Japan on Asia-Pacific perspectives. I move:
