TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak on the Cambodian element of the Prime Minister's statement. I was fortunate enough to spend six days in Cambodia immediately before the Prime Minister (Mr Keating); I left on the Tuesday morning and he was there on either the Friday or the Saturday. I went there on a private visit as the Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I had an absorbing and fascinating visit to that country.

PARA.TAB: Cambodia is described in the textbooks as a very poor country, and that is certainly true, as one sees when one gets there. It is a country which has suffered very much over the years—over the millennia, in fact—because it is a buffer, in one sense, between the Vietnam state on the eastern side and the state of Thailand on the west. Over the last few thousand years, waves of invaders from either side have swept over it.

It does have a very rich core, running north-west to south-east. The Tonle Sap lake and river provide a very fertile rice belt. In earlier times, a very highly developed culture flourished there, to which the temples of Angkor Wat and the others in that region bear testimony. Cambodia was supported by an agricultural economy that placed a great deal of emphasis and sophistication on water retention and water management.

The capital of the country, Phnom Penh, is described as one of the most elegant towns in Asia. It certainly would have been that but for the vicissitudes that have befallen it in recent years. The principal of those was the emergence of the Khmer Rouge regime under Pol Pot, which was one of the most barbaric regimes ever to control any country. While we have all seen pictures of the ossuaries and things like that in magazines and on television, until one goes there and sees the torture chambers, the torture instruments and the rest of it, one really does not appreciate the full significance of the barbarity of that regime.

The other consequence of it was that the Khmer Rouge killed off anyone with any education at all. I do not mean only people who went to university; anyone who was literate or had any semblance of education at all was killed off. Anyone related to foreigners, anyone who spoke a foreign language, even anyone who had glasses, was killed off. The consequence of that is still with the country today. Every person with any skill in the country between 1974 and 1978 was killed off. It has left a terrible legacy. On Christmas Day 1978, Vietnam invaded Cambodia and displaced, but did not destroy, the Khmer Rouge. For the past 11 years, there has been a government there, the State of Cambodia Party, ruling the country with Hun Sen as the President.

Throughout last year, after many, many years of negotiations, an agreement for several things to occur was reached. This led to the United Nations force going in this year to be a transitional authority. The four parties to that agreement agreed that there would be cantonment and disarming of the armies of the four relevant factions; that there would be border checkpoints set up at a number of places in the neighbouring countries of Thailand, Laos and Vietnam; and that voters would be registered for free and fair elections in May of next year.

As a consequence of that, UNTAC, the United Nations Transitional Authority of Cambodia, was set up. Today there are some 22,000 United Nations personnel in the country, of whom something like 15,000-odd are military personnel. Australia makes a very significant contribution to those and that is why I was in Cambodia. The Australian service contingent there has a strength of about 550 service personnel—men and women—providing all the communications for the United Nations force. Cambodia is a country where that facility is absolutely crucial because civilian infrastructure throughout most of the country does not exist.

The Australian contingent in Cambodia is providing all the communications: the VHF/ HF radios, the data transmission, microwave links, facsimile and telex services, telephone services and even a courier service. The Australian contingent extends throughout the whole of Cambodia. The principal attachment is at a place called Pettea Australie, which is halfway between Pochentong, the airport for Phnom Penh, and Phnom Penh city itself. There are about 150 Australians there providing communications for the capital city.

The next big detachment is at Battambang. The rest of the Australian contingent is distributed elsewhere—sometimes in groups as small as three soldiers living entirely by themselves and supporting themselves right out in very distant parts of the country. The general opinion of the Australian contingent is extremely high. Everyone to whom one talks in the United Nations is very praiseworthy of what the Australians are doing in Cambodia. Indeed, I was intensely proud to see them—they are well-disciplined, their morale is high and they are providing a very professional service. I think they are providing far and away the best service of any of the 30-odd nations that make up the United Nations military contingent. It is very rewarding to see members of the Australian contingent going about their job with great professional skill.

Cambodia is not an easy place in which to live. There is very little water in the country that is fit for drinking. The Australian contingent has a great advantage in this regard. Two patented water softener or water purification plants have been developed for the Australian defence forces. They have been a brilliant success. One at Pettea Australie and another one at Battambang provide a voluminous supply of fresh water. As a result, the troops have not only unlimited supplies of water for drinking and for cooking but also plenty of water for showering and for other activities. Every week troops in outlying posts, including the two or three personnel in the most remote parts of the country, get resupplied not only with food but also with drinking water in jerry cans. So that side of the exercise is very well handled.

In the best traditions of the Australian Army, the Australian contingent is cleaning up the campsite at the old barracks at Pettea Australie. Again, the Australian personnel are doing the best they can with respect to hygiene and building in creature comforts so that the camp can operate efficiently. Their service equipment, much of which is designed in this country, is all Australian.

Great success has been achieved with the Raven radios with which the ADF is now becoming equipped. These high frequency radios have worked brilliantly well in that environment. They have worked as they were designed to do. The Raven series of radios, which are a world leader, were built to a specification drawn up by the Australian defence forces, and it is very pleasing to see them performing the way their designers intended them to do.

We are also using the Australian Perentie vehicles up there—the Landrovers and the Unimogs. Of course, the troops are wearing their DPC, disruptive pattern clothing, with the new webbing and they are equipped with the new personal weapons. It is all very impressive. As I said earlier, the Australian personnel are very highly spoken of, and well they might be.

I would like to put on the public record my thanks to Senator Ray, the Minister for Defence, who supported fully my visit to Cambodia. I was basically under the aegis of the Department of Defence, not the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade as would be the normal practice when visiting a country such as Cambodia. Senator Ray, as he has on all previous occasions, gave me the full cooperation of the Department. I have written to him privately thanking him for that. I would like to take the opportunity now of publicly thanking him for the support that he gave me.

I would like to thank the land commander of the Army, General Murray Blake, who is responsible for the Australian contingent deployed as part of UNTAC, and Lieutenant-Colonel Ayling, the CO of the signal regiment up there. When I said there were 550 Australians up there, I did not mention that that number includes 20 New Zealanders. As well as the Army signallers, we have about 20 signallers drawn from the RAN and from the RAAF.

My final word of thanks goes to Colonel Chamberlain, the defence attache at the Australian Embassy in Phnom Penh, whom I found to be quite an outstanding officer. He looked after my visit. There was not one wasted moment in the six days I was in Cambodia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) relating to his recently completed trip to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia. I want to say a few words regarding his visit to Cambodia. I also feel obliged to say something on the Prime Minister's discussion of Australian trade policy.

PARA.TAB: It is an unusual statement in that while certainly the first half of the document is in the normal form of relating his experiences and telling the Parliament what he contributed to the various bilateral relations, the second half seems to be an attempt to justify his Government's trade policy. By the time one reads that part of the statement, the result is greater confusion than before reading it.

The Prime Minister, with respect, seems to be all over the place on trade at the moment. I presume that he decided that this statement was an occasion to raise the trade issues because he chose his visit to Japan to attack the United States trade policy, and in particular the initiatives of President Bush in Detroit when he was looking at ways in which NAFTA might be linked with other Asian states.

Some little time ago we decided that it was appropriate to speak in a critical way of certain protectionist policies in the United States, and in particular the EEP policy. We in the Opposition were condemned by the Prime Minister for taking that action. Interestingly, by contrast, at that time he welcomed the speech by President Bush in Detroit, which he said could have a liberalising effect upon trade. That is the position that we had pretty much adopted. But then, strangely, when the Prime Minister left Australia on this trip and reached Japan, he had completely changed his position and, as I said a moment ago, he decided that that was an appropriate time and place to attack the United States on its trade policies.

As I said at an earlier time, I cannot think of anything less appropriate for an Australian Prime Minister to do than to enter into what is a very difficult trade debate between Japan and the United States whilst in Japan. I cannot see, anyway, how that could contribute to good relations between Australia and the United States, particularly when we have got ourselves into some difficult trade issues with the United States.

The next step in the sequence was the United States expressing concern at the actions taken by the Australian Prime Minister in Japan. No doubt, when one reads this statement it becomes apparent that, reflecting upon those criticisms, the Australian Prime Minister decided that this was an appropriate time to seek to cement the Australia-US trade relationship. And, interestingly, he makes an incredible about-turn and even now speaks in reasonably positive terms about the possibility of bilateral agreements with the United States—something that until today he had been dismissing out of hand. He says in this statement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government would want to consider seriously any offer of a bilateral agreement with the United States which would reduce import constraints on those items of most concern to us—particularly beef, dairy products, sugar and steel.

Until today, he had condemned that approach.The Prime Minister went on to say that he felt Australia would be unlikely to achieve these concessions. But the point is that unless we try we will never know. That is what we in Opposition have been saying to this Government—that particularly in the bilateral area the Government ought to be out there trying to gain concessions in a bilateral way. Of course, this Government has put so many of its eggs in the multilateral basket in the hope of achieving a satisfactory outcome in the Uruguay Round of the GATT. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) has come into this place many times and said that that is the ideal and the best solution that is open to Australia.

PARA.TAB: But the point is that, if that solution is not being achieved, surely a country such as Australia which so desperately needs to increase its trade should be looking at other less perfect options. As I said, until today the bilateral option—in particular, the discussions which have revolved around the United States—has been dismissed by the Prime Minister. But suddenly today we see that it is being embraced.

Interestingly, the Prime Minister also goes on to look at the possibility of Australia being part of some regional trading arrangement. As far as I can recall, it is the first time that he has floated that idea. He said—and I guess this is to try to mesh this new approach of his with what the Government previously has been saying and, in particular, with what Senator Evans has been saying—that perhaps the way to do that is through APEC. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: APEC is already evolving into a regional trade arrangement with a useful agenda of trade-liberalising measures.
It finally has an agenda of trade liberalisation, but I would have thought that it was premature to be talking about it as a regional trade arrangement. In fact, he continued:
If thinking and practice in the region evolves towards the idea of a trade pact, we would very much prefer that it be APEC—

that is, the APEC model. The implication in that is that Australia is giving some support to the notion of a trade pact within the Asia-Pacific region—although APEC, of course, covers an enormous geographical area, far beyond Asia, and, as APEC expands presumably to take in Mexico next year, it would include the whole of North America and Mexico. But certainly for the first time we see the Prime Minister speaking of the possibility of a regional trade pact.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line of all this is that the current trade policy position of Australia is very confusing. In his typical style, the Prime Minister sought to attack us, because that is what he does best; in fact, to attack anyone who puts a different position is his preferred approach. But now, being forced into a situation where he has to address what seriously should be Australia's trade policy in a very difficult international environment, and an international environment where the multilateral ground is not achieving the perfect outcome that the Government has sought, he has been forced to look at the sorts of options that we previously had been talking about.

I doubt whether an apology from the Prime Minister will be forthcoming, but it is important that this confusing situation he has created be clarified so that Australia, and particularly the Australian investing business community, can understand what is to be this Government's policy in relation to trade during its last few months in office. To the extent that we have at least provoked this Government to start thinking about some other options—rather than simply relying on, as I said, putting all its eggs in the multilateral basket—there is no doubt that, from opposition, we have made a worthwhile contribution to this important area.

As I have said, that was not the principal reason for my rising. I wanted to address the issue of Cambodia and, in particular, the one page of this statement that the Prime Minister allows for the important question of Cambodia and the major commitment that Australia has made both in manpower, in the size of its defence force commitment, and financially to help the Cambodian people find peace.

It is disappointing that, on a major issue such as this and in a situation where the Prime Minister has been prepared to visit Cambodia—and I was pleased to see that—there is really no thoughtful analysis at all of what is occurring in the country or any detail at all on how Australia is reacting to the difficulties that have been confronted in the Paris peace process—or, in fact, on what is now the policy of Australia in a changed environment. That is not only disappointing, but it also seems to me to be a breach of an undertaking that was given to this Parliament by both the Prime Minister and the Australian Foreign Minister that we would be kept fully informed of changes that were occurring, particularly changes that might affect the position of our Defence Force commitment. The Government has not done that, and certainly it has not done it by means of this statement, in which, as I said, it allots only one page to the complex Cambodian issue.

With Senator MacGibbon, who spoke prior to me, I was pleased to have the opportunity to again visit Cambodia, with the support of the Australian Government and the Australian Foreign Minister, before visiting the United Nations some few weeks ago and, in fact, just before the Prime Minister visited Cambodia. I wanted to set foot again on Cambodian soil because I think it is fair to say, certainly from my perspective, that the principal issue that concerns us with which the UN is dealing at the moment is the Cambodian issue.

There is no better way to get a clearer impression of that country's affairs—compared with that which one gets simply from reading the mass media and in the light of the few statements that we get from this Government—than to have a few days to talk with the faction leaders in Cambodia; to meet with the aid organisations that I have met with before; to meet with the Defence Force people; to meet with Mr Akashi, the Secretary-General's special representative, and other UNTAC officials with various responsibilities; to meet with Lieutenant-General Sanderson, who is heading up the UN military force; and to try to understand the current state of the peace process and what might be the difficulties that it faces.

I found those few days particularly worth while and, like Senator MacGibbon, I would like to put on record my recognition of both the professionalism and goodwill of the Australian mission in Phnom Penh. I visit many Australian missions abroad and I was most impressed with the personnel and their attitude in a difficult environment—and Australia is clearly well respected in Cambodia—and also the professionalism and dedication of the Australian Defence Force. I was privileged to see them at work and to meet many of them during my short visit to Phnom Penh. They are a credit to Australia in not only their professional standing but also the attitude that they display and the help that they willingly give the Cambodian people beyond the call of duty.

Having said that, where is the Cambodian peace process at the moment? It seems that, as a result of meetings between the P5, Japan, Thailand, Indonesia, France, Germany and Australia in New York, the Security Council is expected to formally decide this week to proceed with elections no later than the May 1993 deadline as set down in the Paris agreement. I understand from what I read that it is likely to give the Khmer Rouge until 15 November to begin cooperating by outlining a series of measures designed to meet some of what are seen as the more reasonable Khmer Rouge concerns.

These concessions, I understand, are likely to include more administrative power to be shifted from the Hun Sen Government to the UN administration and the SNC. I find it difficult to see how that is going to occur. It coincided with my visit that UNTAC in fact took over the national bank. That area of finance is just one of the five key portfolio areas, and clearly UNTAC is taking considerable responsibility.

There are those within the states that I mentioned who clearly feel that more effort should be made to appease the Khmer Rouge. It looks as if some further steps might be taken in that direction. I understand that, if the Khmer Rouge does not cooperate by 15 November, the Security Council is then expected to pass a resolution formally declaring the Khmer Rouge outside the process.
Senator Gareth Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister will have the opportunity to respond, because, as I said, the Minister tells us very little about the Cambodian process or Australia's role in it. We tend to hear what the Minister says offshore when briefing the press, rather than what he advises the Australian Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether or not sanctions will follow. I was told in Phnom Penh that our Minister—and this is the embarrassment of it all—Senator Evans is in favour of sanctions. In fact, Mr Hun Sen said to me that he was pleased at Senator Evans's position in supporting sanctions and hoped that Australia would go further than simply applying sanctions to the Khmer Rouge. He hoped Australia would actually encourage UNTAC to play some peacemaking rather than a peacekeeping or peace-enforcing role.

I do not think sanctions would work in relation to the Khmer Rouge. Sadly, I do not think that the application of force is a method to which the Khmer Rouge would positively respond. I understand that the door will be kept open for the Khmer Rouge to rejoin the peace process until about January of next year, being the last possible moment, because parties have to be registered, candidates accepted, roles finalised and so forth. It is my view that, consistent with the philosophy behind the Paris peace agreement that is based on a national reconciliation, that door should be left open as long as possible. I do not think that the Khmer Rouge will cooperate, and I have thought all along that it would not cooperate. However, if the philosophy of the deal is national reconciliation, then obviously the door has to be kept open.

The view seems to be accepted by everyone now—and it is also my view—that, with or without the Khmer Rouge, the election should be proceeded with, allowing those who wish to participate to do so and cover as much of Cambodia as possible. That is far from a perfect option, but one should look at the alternatives, one of which is to withdraw. After this commitment, I do not think that would be sensible in terms of the contribution that has been made by the international community, or fair to the majority of Cambodians who really do long for peace. I would rule out that option and there is the other option that I touched on a moment ago of giving the UN force some enforcement role to try to compel compliance with the deal. I do not think that option will work because it is philosophically inconsistent with the Paris agreement. As I said, one of the lessons of history is that the Khmer Rouge does not respond to that sort of force. The third option, and the only one that seems sensibly available, is to proceed with a far less than perfect outcome and at least give those Cambodians who do want to participate in a democratic process the opportunity to do so.

Further, I understand that Japanese and Thai officials are expected to meet with the Khmer Rouge in mid-October to pursue further the idea of an administrative consultative body to overcome Khmer Rouge concerns about the administration. I do not think that will work. It has been suggested before and they have been working on it for some time. It has not been positively taken up. I have no concerns with the fact that States want to continue to try to find ways to meet the Khmer Rouge objections.

I understand that a ministerial level meeting is likely to be held in Cambodia or Thailand at the end of November. That is to be a meeting that will include the SNC, and France and Indonesia will sponsor that. The Minister might provide us with further information during his participation in this debate.

What are the implications for this evolving situation, which is far different from what was anticipated in the Paris process? It seems that it will mean the UN peacekeeping force will have to remain at full strength up until the elections. We were expecting that the infantry would start to reduce from October to February down to about half its size, because the process of cantonment would have been completed and the need would simply not be there for the current large force.

The total peacekeeping force is over 15,000 at the moment, which is tremendously costly. If the force has to remain, there is a further cost implication apart from anything else. The Minister might tell us about that. The original budget was eventually settled at approximately US$1.56 billion. The estimate that I have been given is that, if the full strength of the infantry has to remain, that will be likely to increase to somewhere between US$2 billion to US$2.5 billion extra—money which of course has not been approved. In fact, I do not think the UNTAC budget has yet been approved beyond October and the Minister might bring us up to date in that regard.

The function being performed by the force would also change and that is vitally important. Its role would change to that of seeking to protect the election process in an environment where cantonment has not been successful and, therefore, there are still forces in the field. Clearly, forces of the Khmer Rouge remain in the field. There are those who have not complied with phase two of the agreement and have not met the obligation that they agreed to in France. Also, most of the other forces that have been cantoned have been released on agricultural leave and everyone accepts in any event that only a fraction of their armaments—particularly their outdated armaments—have been handed in.

We could well be looking at an election environment in which forces from various sections are still in the field who are armed. Whether any would seek to disrupt the process is something that we do not know. However, if they do disrupt the process, having the UN present to try to protect that process is obviously a very different security environment from that to which the Australian Government committed the Australian forces.

The only point I make in that regard is that I think we are entitled, as we were promised, to know exactly what the situation is from an Australian Government perspective, and so far we have not been told. If the role of the Australian force—although it is not an infantry component, nevertheless it is in support of the infantry components—has changed, then the Australian Parliament and the Australian people are entitled to know that as well.

In fact, we are entitled to know whether the cantonment process is now to be abandoned completely, and whether those who are still within the camps will be released or whether they will try to retain those who have not been let out on so-called agricultural leave within the camps. We are entitled to know whether there is to be any further disarming and, if so, how that is to be carried out and what is to happen to the weapons which have been collected. For example, what if the SOC now seeks to take back its weapons which it has handed in? What is the UN's and the Australian Government's attitude to that? Again it ups the security risk for our forces.

We are entitled to know whether the SOC military forces will be allowed to play any role in protecting the electoral process. Already there are suggestions from the SOC that it should have that function. Even 15,000 UN forces will be insufficient to protect the electoral process Cambodia wide. Will the Government of Cambodia be allowed to play any role in that regard?

I have not long, but I want to touch upon some of the other problems that are developing—the question of refugees for a start. I have to concede that the program of returning people from the camps has been very successful so far. One hundred and fifteen thousand people have been repatriated, but many have not returned to the places it was intended they go and they have tended to rapidly move to the cities. This is creating further problems of urban stress. They are without work and that creates difficulties. So concerns are being expressed about what is happening to the returnees rather than the process of returning them.

The law and order situation in Cambodia is deteriorating rapidly and that is a matter of distress. In fact, in many places political violence is now being replaced with what one might call civil violence, and that breakdown of law and order is affecting the whole process and morale. The environment is bad, particularly in the Khmer Rouge controlled areas. Enormous parts of the country are being exploited without any concern for the environment at all, and that is distressing.

The economy is collapsing and that is perhaps the greatest worry of all. Now the UN is being blamed because it has developed a dual economy—the local currency and the dollar economy on top of that. Some estimates of inflation are up to 130 per cent, so we are moving towards an electoral process in which the Hun Sen Government is virtually bankrupt. Some are even wondering whether it can remain in office in the period up to the election, so bad is the economic position.

What that means is that the international community is moving towards an election process not only in a situation inconsistent with the Paris agreement but also in an environment that has changed and deteriorated very rapidly—deteriorated in terms of the collapsing economy and the growing law and order problem.

What we may well see is an outcome in which an election process takes place which is more or less democratic involving some Cambodians. A fragile coalition government is the most likely outcome of that process—between factions that basically do not get on, against a background of economic collapse and deteriorating law and order problems and with the Khmer Rouge sitting on the outside waiting for that collapse to occur and the opportunity, therefore, to seize power.

I do not see any alternative to that, so I am not being unduly critical of it. The Minister raises his eyebrows, but what I am saying is that the Australian people are entitled to know what the picture is and the background against which we are making our commitments—and it is a very difficult background. It seems to me that the international community is going to be called upon for an ongoing commitment to nation building post-election. Any thought this would simply be a short term commitment on the part of the international community to help Cambodia through a difficult phase has now, I think, been demonstrated to be unreal.

If the Cambodians are to have any hope of long term peace, any hope of stability, any hope of keeping the Khmer Rouge out and avoiding the atrocities that occurred in the past, then there is no doubt in my mind that the United Nations and the international community generally are going to be called upon for a long term commitment of nation building. No doubt this will be at great cost, but we should understand that that is going to be the reality of the matter and that this electoral process that is taking place should be seen as but a phase in the total development of peace and stability and greater hope for the Cambodian people.

It is a very difficult picture. Certainly more of the country is at peace now than previously and that is something the majority of Cambodians commend. However, the picture for the future is highly uncertain and, in accordance with the undertakings that the Prime Minister and the Foreign Affairs Minister gave the Australian Parliament, it is time in my view that a full and comprehensive statement was again put down in this place setting out the background to the peace process and Australia's commitment in contemporary terms and what the role of the Australian force will be in the months between now and the anticipated elections in May. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make those comments on the Cambodian matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond briefly to the parliamentary statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on his visit to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia. The Australian Democrats welcome that statement. It is clear from the visit, as it is from this statement, that, in contrast to his former overseas trip to Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, the Prime Minister did not call into question aspects of our national identity in front of non-Australian audiences. This time, he decided that it was time to talk Australia up rather than down.

PARA.TAB: Much of the visit was concerned with vital issues of trade and the Australian Democrats are pleased to see that APEC has been given greater recognition in the region and that Japan is supporting it. Generally, we support the greater orientation towards Japan and the Asia-Pacific region that the Prime Minister has initiated, in part as a counterweight to the treatment we have received from the United States and from the European Community on wheat and other trade issues. If there was one message in those events, it was clearly that Australia needed to establish a different base from which to operate in trade areas.

However, there are also security issues involved in the Prime Minister's visit and in his statement. As the Prime Minister's statement says, the regional security outlook is generally favourable, but less predictable than before. As everyone knows, the region is no longer divided into two hostile camps each with its own commander. The Cold War has ended, leaving what some see as a vacuum of military power into which countries such as Japan and China might move.

I would be amazed to find that any other country in this region wants another Big Brother to dominate with military power. That is why the Australian Democrats are convinced that there is no alternative but to fill the vacuum and provide predictability with some new security arrangements. We do not need more military alliances and a continuing military build-up which invites future conflicts.

What we do need is an all-inclusive diplomatic forum to oversee the development of a cooperative security environment in which the threat of substantial conflict is minimised. This is not a romantic wish for regional peace and harmony. It is instead a hard-headed recognition that the prosperity of the Asia-Pacific region depends on resolving conflicts without bloodshed and reducing the criminal waste of resources on military forces.

We cannot afford to let regional security take the path of arms races and nationalistic campaigns for access to marine resources such as the Spratly Islands. We need to take control and set new directions. The Government has responded to this need only in the area of trade, and APEC, as I have said before, is laudable as far as it goes but more is needed. We do need a regional forum concerned with resolving and preventing conflicts and with a reduction of military forces.

The Government dabbled with this idea in 1990 when Senator Evans proposed a conference on security and cooperation in Asia. He was very firmly smacked on the wrist by James Baker, then President Bush's Secretary of State, and beat a hasty retreat with the help of the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. In the Democrats' view, it is time to refloat the conference on security and cooperation in Asia. We cannot afford to go on drifting in this sea of unpredictability. If we do not seize the opportunity provided by the relative calm we are now enjoying, it will be too late to seek a safe harbour when the inevitable storm blows up.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The visit by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia was very successful. This can be measured by the statements of foreign leaders while he was there, the reporting in the media, both in the countries he visited and that which came back to Australia, and in the subsequent feedback that I have been receiving constantly through diplomatic and related channels about the reverberations that the visit has caused and the very positive response that has been felt in the region.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of reasons for this. We have in Prime Minister Keating someone who both is and was perceived by his interlocutors to be someone who is very alert to the processes of change that are at work in the region. Both economically and in the larger security context that Senator Spindler canvassed, he is someone who is full of ideas about how to respond to these changes. He has very clear ideas about the role of both our country and the countries that he has visited in this respect.

Moreover, we have a Prime Minister whose personal style was greeted with great enthusiasm by the Asian leaders with whom he spoke, not only on this trip but on the preceding one to Indonesia as well. Mr Keating's rather legendary status as an aggressive parliamentary performer had undoubtedly created something of an advance reputation for him. But people were able to appreciate a side of Mr Keating that we in government in Australia are very familiar with but which has been perhaps less conspicuously reported in those countries, and that is of someone who is polite and deferential, who listens and who is very conscious of the very kind of personal relationships that are involved in developing not only a formal rapport but also a very genuine personal rapport with the leaderships of the country in question.

A third reason for the success of these visits is that the Prime Minister has been speaking on behalf of a country which is no longer perceived in the region as some kind of observer of regional events with its heart and emotions elsewhere, but a country that is genuinely committed to and engaged in the region and with a mounting track record of performance to prove it. I guess that the most conspicuous recent examples of that are our initiation of the Asia-Pacific economic cooperation process and the role that we played in producing the UN peace plan for Cambodia and its implementation.

I will also mention, with particular reference to Senator Spindler's remarks, the role that we have been playing in recent years as a promoter of ideas about the kind of shape that regional security might assume in the post Cold War world. In that environment, superpower relationships do not have the same kind of overarching significance that they used to. It is a much more fluid and dynamic environment and there is a much greater need for cooperative, interdependent, common security approaches to emerge and prevail. Australia's role in promoting that kind of dialogue on these issues, in particular through the forum of the ASEAN ministerial dialogue conference, has been widely recognised.

In Japan, the emphasis was on the economic relationship, but by no means only on the economic relationship. I will return later to the question of trade policy as one of the themes that ran through the entire visit and which is the subject of some further explicit remarks by the Prime Minister in his statement.

More generally, in Japan, the message very clearly emerged of countries that have an enormous amount to offer each other, not only in terms of the traditional commodity trade relationship, where the Australian supply of raw materials has been an absolutely crucial factor in the modernisation and industrialisation of that country and is recognised as such, but also, much more generally, a more broad ranging, mature and diversified economic relationship combined with a political relationship that really has a synergy about it. Japan is looking for ways of playing a role politically in the region and, indeed, in the world that is more commensurate with its economic authority.

Japan has been subject to a lot of misunderstanding in the region and elsewhere in the world. It is a country that values the kind of relationship that a country like Australia can have with it in terms of a number of commonly shared values and a willingness to address global and regional issues in a way that recognises the significance of Japan's role. It is anxious to find a way to exercise that role in a constructive way.

I will not go into all the chapter and verse of what this means in a specific policy context. I simply make the point that this theme is one that has been emerging, in my experience, in the dialogue process that we have been conducting at regular intervals with Japanese Ministers through the vehicle of the Australia-Japan Ministerial Council. This kind of theme was much more overtly on the table, as these things often are, as a result of the Prime Minister's visit. That is to be welcomed.

We have much to offer each other in terms of working together in multilateral forums—such as the United Nations conferences on disarmament and the OECD—vehicles, agencies and forums, both economic and political. We have much to offer by working closely with each other in regional forums such as APEC on the economic side and ASEAN-PMC on the security side. We have much to contribute to the health and prosperity of each other through closer bilateral ties. That is being increasingly recognised.

In Singapore, we have the consolidation of a relationship that has been traditionally one of the oldest and closest of Australia with the region, by virtue in particular of the Commonwealth tie as supplemented by arrangements such as the five-power defence arrangements, which have really created a very close working and policy relationship between the two countries. Mr Keating's visit symbolised the importance that we not only traditionally associate with that relationship but which we continue to attach to it in an environment where Singapore's growth and sophistication continue to be the real envies of the region.

Similarly, in Cambodia, the Prime Minister's visit, although short, served a very important symbolic purpose by demonstrating the degree of the commitment of Australia not only to try to resolve once and for all the appalling problem of Cambodia but also as a sign of our commitment to the region and our willingness to engage very actively in trying to help solve the region's problems. This is perhaps not the occasion to go into a very detailed discussion of the present Cambodian situation, as Senator Hill invites me to do, but I will try to respond to his invitation by summarising the situation in that country as the Prime Minister found it in his visit and as I would describe it following the very intensive series of discussions that I have had in the last couple of weeks in New York, in particular at the United Nations.

The consensus that presently exists in the international community or among those countries that are most closely involved in the resolution of the problem can be put as follows. In the first place, it is accepted that the UN already has a great many achievements to its credit in the operation of the UN plan. Notwithstanding some of the ongoing pessimism of the reporting about the situation in Cambodia, there are many good things to report. Senator Hill acknowledged some of them.

The repatriation program, which has now brought back 150,000, not just 115,000, people from the border camps into Cambodia, has been a conspicuous success. It is unfair to say that it has just resulted in people flooding into the cities. They have been going to many parts of the country, although certainly not to the outlying rural areas on the scale that had been hoped. That is something that has to be addressed over time if the balance of the whole economy is to be maintained, and that is acknowledged.

The organisation for the electoral process has been proceeding very well indeed, with the process well positioned to meet the April-May timetable next year, subject to constraints that I will come to in a moment. The administration to particularly promote, advance and protect human rights values in the country has been working, by all accounts, very well. The civil administration component of the UN Administration, one of the unique features of this whole current exercise, has been working reasonably well, if not to the satisfaction of all the factions within Cambodia or completely to the satisfaction of the international community. My own view is that a little more might be able to be done in that respect by way of a more visible and substantial presence of UN experts in the key ministerial areas. That is a matter that is currently under further consideration.

There are some aspects of the situation which are not so good. The economic situation is certainly very fragile, with inflation accelerating, and there are some very real concerns about the ability of the economy to hold itself together, particularly in the absence of major injections of funds from the international financial institutions which have been holding back, pending the resolution of some of the political problems that remain unresolved. There is an emerging law and order problem being dealt with very professionally by the civilian police, no more so than via the Australians of whom Senator Tate spoke today.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there is only a handful, isn't there?

—There is only a handful of them and there is a law and order problem of some emerging significance and that is a worrying aspect of it. Generally, none of this has dampened the general optimism that the Prime Minister felt when he was there and I certainly feel from continuing to talk to the key players involved. A lot has been achieved and much more can be achieved.

PARA.TAB: Militarily, not anything like what we had hoped would be achieved pursuant to the peace plan has been achieved by virtue of the non-cooperation of the Khmer Rouge, the Party of Democratic Kampuchea—the so-called DK—in that process. There has been quite a deal of cantonment. There has been quite a draw down in the numbers of troops that are still visibly in the field or in the cantons, owing overt allegiance to one or other of the factions, but it is not to be assumed that that situation will continue in perpetuity with the end of the harvesting season and so on.

Certainly, the military situation remains very uncertain, even though cease-fires have largely held. But more importantly, there is a reasonable degree of confidence that a full scale resumption of civil war or a full scale military assault by the DK as the ultimate way of expressing its non-cooperation is quite unlikely. That is the balance of opinion at the moment, based on an assessment not just of intention, which will always remain unclear, but also of capability. If that assessment is right it means that however else the process unfolds and whatever other hurdles we may have to jump along the way in keeping that process intact, it may be that we will not as an international community be confronted with the awful dilemma that would otherwise confront us if there were a full-scale military assault by the Khmer Rouge, raising the awful choice as to whether to simply pack up the UN peace plan and come home, there being no longer a peace to keep, or rather to seek from the international community a different kind of mandate—a chapter 7 Charter mandate in UN terms—which would enable the peacekeeping exercise to be turned into a peace enforcement one. It is not something anybody can contemplate with equanimity or confidence as being achievable. We simply have to continue to hope that the situation will not arise. I simply report to the Senate that at the moment, without going into details as to the basis of this assessment, there is a quite widespread and reasonable, in my judgment, degree of confidence that that situation will not arise.

To continue with this summary of the present situation, there is a general recognition by the international community most often involved that the situation cannot be allowed to drift. If the election timetable is to be met in April-May next year a number of decision points will arise along the way. For example, as Senator Hill said, we cannot contemplate having an election take place in the Khmer Rouge areas of the country if there has not been a cantonment of the military in those areas, an opportunity for the UN to enter in its civilian administration and for there to be effective campaigning by the other parties. That, for all practical purposes, means that we are talking about not much later than January as the decision point, in effect, for the Khmer Rouge to return to the process so far as those areas are concerned.

At some stage the financial situation will produce another kind of decision point because of the need, obviously, to keep UN troops there in full force so long as the military situation remains unresolved and the cantonment, demobilisation and disarmament are incomplete. That will create financial burdens of an unforeseen kind and that problem will have to be addressed. It does not have to be addressed right now because there is a significant budgetary underspend so far as the first few months of the operation are concerned for one reason or another. Transitional funds are, in that context and for that reason, available to take us well into next year before a crunch point arises in that respect and decisions have to be made about the draw down of the second tranche of the already agreed funding and before decisions have to be made about any increase in the overall global funding.

While there is a recognition that the situation cannot drift and that decision points will arise, that is accompanied next by a recognition that the Khmer Rouge cannot and should not be allowed to hold the whole process to ransom. There is a real determination on the part of the international community to finish the job that has been started and to take the process through to elections at the scheduled time in April-May next year, even if that means that those elections will, if the non-cooperation of the Khmer Rouge continues, have to take place only in 85 per cent of the country and not in the 15 per cent or so that at the moment represents a Khmer Rouge no go area.

At the same time again there is certainly a recognition that it would be manifestly desirable if the original plan were able to be adhered to to its full extent. To that extent, the international community is minded to hold the doors open for the resumption of Khmer Rouge cooperation as long as is possible. In that context it is acknowledged further that there may continue to be some areas of grievance expressed by the Khmer Rouge which are legitimate, looked at squarely and only from the point of view of the language of the Paris settlement. To that extent, the Japan-Thailand exercise in trying to identify some ways of accommodating Khmer Rouge concerns about the civil administration side of the process has been thought to be worth some further exploration.

There is finally a recognition, however, given all of these considerations, that some strong messages need to be sent. There needs to be some formal process set in train whereby some of these threads can start coming together. With that in mind, I would expect the UN this week in its resolution of the Security Council to be, in effect, formally initiating article 29 consultations by the Paris conference co-chairmen. I would be expecting them to identify a further date, perhaps some time later in November, when the Security Council would meet again to reconsider the whole situation in the light of the report coming from those co-chairmen and in the light of the experience in trying to resolve through Thai and Japanese good offices such legitimate grievances as the Khmer Rouge has.

I would expect there to be some acknowledgment, perhaps tacit, that when the Security Council does meet to reconsider the situation it will need to have at its potential disposal a whole range of policy options and possible measures to deal with that situation. It is in that context that the question of sanctions could perhaps be further looked at, although there are obvious difficulties in making a really effective economic sanctions regime work so far as that Khmer Rouge area of the country is concerned.

Finally, in the context of Cambodia, all of this is necessarily a step-by-step process. There is simply no point at this stage in trying to map out a complete blueprint of everything that might happen, every contingency, every fork in the road and every possible response to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will conclude what I was saying on the subject of Cambodia with just these words. It is very difficult at this stage of the exercise, despite the invitation from Senator Hill, to lay out a full blueprint of everything that might happen in the weeks and months ahead. Australia has been very anxious to encourage a sharply focused exercise in thinking about those alternatives by the international community. That, indeed, is exactly what I was doing in New York two weeks ago. But we do acknowledge that the process is uncertain. We have to feel our way. It has to be a step at a time, and I will do my best to keep the Senate informed of the steps that do unfold as we work our way, hopefully, towards a durable, peaceful solution in that country.

PARA.TAB: Finally, on the subject of trade policy, I will say just a few things in response to Senator Hill. The Prime Minister's statement very clearly spells out the trade policy issues confronting the country at the moment. It very clearly spells out also the options available to us. There is no real disagreement—I would have thought and hoped—as between the two sides of politics that those options are in fact multi-dimensional. We do have to be pursuing simultaneously a global approach to trade liberalisation and a regional or—that ugly word which is assuming currency—plurilateral, meaning simply more than bilateral, approach. We also have to adopt a bilateral approach, pursuing trade advantage wherever we can find it; pursuing trade access wherever we can find it; continuing to work away, whatever the larger regimes that might be potentially applicable, at getting access for particular commodities, such as beef, in Japan or Taiwan; and minimising the various restrictions or barriers of a tariff or non-tariff kind that might exist in the way of us achieving such access.

Any sensible, rational trade strategy has to adopt all of those three approaches simultaneously. However, I do find it most unfortunate that the Opposition and some other commentators continue to repeat the canard that the Australian Government has been preoccupied with one of those dimensions to the exclusion of the others; that we have put all our eggs in one particular basket, namely that of the GATT round of multilateral or global trade negotiations—the Uruguay Round. The latest repetition of that line was in Mr Greg Hywood's piece in the Australian Financial Review a few days ago. This is very well responded to by John Kerin in the Australian Financial Review letter column this morning. In his opening paragraph, he makes the point:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am sure that your American correspondent, Gregory Hywood, is capable of driving down 51st Street, listening to the car radio, thinking about whether Bush or Clinton will win on November 3, scratching his nose, and chewing gum—all at the same time.
He then goes on to make the point that, unremarkably, we too are capable of pursuing those particular options.

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounds like one of your expressions.
—I defer to Lyndon Johnson for the original proposition, and it was rather less delicately expressed than that.

PARA.TAB: But the point needs to be made over and over again that of course we are pursuing a multi-dimensional strategy. That element of multi-dimensionality is what clearly emerges from the Prime Minister's statement today. It is nonsense to say that there has been any degree of confusion or changing of tack in our approach to trade policy as the public debate has unfolded in recent weeks. Of course it is the case that the Prime Minister welcomed the Bush Detroit speech for what it said about trade liberalisation values and principles generally and what, in particular, it said about the virtue of that occurring in an Asia-Pacific regional context.

Where we took, and continue to take, issue with President Bush is with the notion that trade liberalisation objectives can be most sensibly pursued by a kind of hub and spokes approach—a multiplicity of bilateral agreements; in particular, bilateral agreements in which the United States is the single common party. We have made it clear over and over again that we do not think it is likely that Australia's national interests could be advantaged by such an approach.

The reasons are set out very succinctly in the Prime Minister's speech. I will summarise them. First, we are not at all sure, given the realities of the trade relationship and the domestic lobbies on key commodities in the United States, that we could negotiate a bilateral agreement in which the benefits to us would outweigh the costs; secondly, there is the geopolitical concern that any embrace of the United States in this kind of context would be perceived very widely around the region as turning our back on east Asia, despite the fact, as the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that it accounts for almost six times more of our exports than the United States

and, thirdly, there is the concern that any kind of hub and spokes model, while it might unquestionably improve trade access in the region for the United States, may well create additional difficulties for the countries at the end of the spokes in question.

PARA.TAB: What the Prime Minister has said is that we do have an open mind about the kind of trade arrangements which might have to evolve in a post-Uruguay Round or, worse, a post-Uruguay Round failure environment. We do acknowledge that there are options that we may have to consider in that context which are less desirable options when we look around us at the moment. We have an open mind about those options. We certainly think in a regional context that APEC is the perfect vehicle for trade facilitating agreements and we are actively encouraging the conclusion of such agreements. That is the very exercise which was set in train in Bangkok a few weeks ago.

We have to acknowledge that it is less easy to achieve a region-wide, APEC-wide preferential trade agreement of an extended NAFTA kind. Certainly, if such an agreement were to be in prospect, it is one which would have to satisfy a number of criteria—again, some of which are spelt out in the Prime Minister's speech—not least that it would not involve any kind of division within the region as between trade allies of Japan and the United States respectively. A region-wide agreement—whether of a trade facilitating or trade preferential kind, provided it was GATT consistent—is the preferred option. Sub-regional lesser groupings of individual countries or smaller numbers of them may be something that we have to look at. But there really are a number of considerations and criteria that we would need to take into account in any such exercise.

We would need to be satisfied of the sorts of things which Professor Snape is talking about in his report which is shortly to be released in its final form. We would need to be satisfied that such an agreement was genuinely trade creating rather than trade diverting; that it was open in character and capable of accession by other parties; that it had a large core of common, genuine free trade content; and that it was not simply a compilation of essentially restrictive, specific, difficult commodity arrangements between the countries that are party to such an agreement.

These are all complex issues. This is not the time to pursue them in any detail. It is the time, however, to make the point, as the Prime Minister does, that we are in a fluid and uncertain trade policy environment. We do need to keep our wits about us. We do need to keep an open mind about the kind of principled agreements that may be possible in our region and, indeed, in the world as a whole. What we do not need, however, is a puppy dog-like embrace of particular options which might be offered, or which we might perceive to be open, with particular allies—particularly those with whom we trade less than others. We do not want to roll over with feet waving in the air and pink tummy exposed in the way that Dr Hewson seems so inclined to do whenever he has opened his mouth in recent weeks on the subject of trade policy and a bilateral agreement with the United States. Our agenda is larger than that. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Senate on Monday 2nd December, 1991, Senator Jones asked a question of the then Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, in relation to an article that had appeared that morning in The Australian newspaper. Headlined "Politicians `in the grip of lobbyists'", the article quoted comments made by me when answering the writer's queries concerning aspects of my report, as Chairman, contained in the Annual Report for 1990 of the Advertising Standards Council.

Apart from my surprise at the vehemence and tone of Senator Tate's answer, I was also concerned that his answer also contained many errors of fact which would have had the effect of seriously misleading the Senate. (See Hansard, pages 3730 and 3731).

On 31st March, 1992, with the unanimous support of my Council, I wrote to Senator Tate setting out the correct facts and seeking a withdrawal of his remarks and an apology. The responses I made to the Minister on behalf of the Council and on my own behalf included the following specific denials of the views, actions and role which the Minister ascribed to the Council and to me as Chairman:

(a)I have not been cast in an adversarial role for many years, and did not make any caricature of lobby groups. I am not and never have been "hostile to representatives of the community view". My Council and I welcome expressions of genuine community views and also those of lobby groups.

(b)It is not my wish to "vet" those who might come from community groups and voluntary organisations as advisers and lobbyists to Ministers. I have always regarded the selection of Ministerial advisers as the sole responsibility and prerogative of each Minister.

(c)I have not tried to veto the Minister's nominations for appointments to the Alcoholic Beverages, Cigarette, Slimming and Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code Councils. While the Trade Practices Commission's report referred to in the Minister's answer made some criticism of the situation concerning nominations, it was based on incorrect facts, acknowledged by the then Chairman of the TPC, Professor Baxt. Unfortunately, the necessary corrections were ultimately not made to the report.

(d)The TPC did not make scathing comments about the lack of accessibility and timeliness in respect of the ASC and Media Council. Indeed the ASC, which operates totally free of cost to the taxpayer, is far more prompt, productive and effective in its work than comparable Government agencies or the Court system.

(e)While I am Chairman and from time to time spokesman for the ASC and have certain special powers within the ASC, it cannot be said that I "supervise" it. All 16 members of the Council have an equal vote except in a tied vote when I have a casting vote. It is not my function to supervise the advertising industry through the Media Council or otherwise. I certainly have no supervisory role in relation to the Media Council.

The Senator's reply of 30th April, 1992 was not only inaccurate, inadequate and unsatisfactory, but it also showed his complete unwillingness to make a further statement in the Senate to correct his misleading comments on 2nd December, 1991.

As I was sure that Senator Jones would not wish to be a party to the continuance of this situation, I wrote to him on 9th July, 1992 inviting him to again raise the matter in the Senate "and to seek from Senator Tate a response appropriate to the facts as you now have them." Senator Jones' reply of 3rd August, 1992 stated that "I have noted your comments and will take the matter up with Senator Tate.

I consider that Senator Tate's answer to Senator Jones had the effect of misleading the Senate, as well as being a serious assault on the status of the Advertising Standards Council and on the integrity of myself as Chairman.

SPEECH.PARA: DEFENCE LOGISTICS REDEVELOPMENT PROJECT—AIR FORCE ASPECTS OFFICE CONSTRUCTION AT THE CORNER OF ADELAIDE AND CREEK STREETS, BRISBANE

The Committee's seventh report for 1992 which I have just tabled concerns the Air Force Aspects of the Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project—the DLRP, which involves the implementation of a rationalised and centralised strategy of wholesale storage and distribution for the Australian Defence Force.

PARA.TAB: The Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre, the second major component of the DLRP, will be the subject of a separate report from the Committee later in these sittings.

This report concerns the provision of facilities required by the RAAF to implement the provision of facilities required by the RAAF to implement the relocation to forward bases of weapons systems spares as well as the rationalisation of associated property holdings. The Air Force aspects of the DLRP will allow the disposal of Defence property at Tottenham, Victoria; Toowoomba, Queensland; and Regents Park, New South Wales. The estimated cost of the proposed works is 25 million dollars. The proceeds from the sale of the properties will fund the construction of new and enhanced facilities to be provided.

The Committee's report on the Air Force aspects recommends that the works should proceed. The report concludes that the scope of the enhancement of warehouses at seven RAAF bases can be justified on the basis of improved efficiencies and increased effectiveness resulting from the storage of weapons system spares in them. The seven operational bases are Williamtown, Edinburgh, East Sale, Amberley, Richmond, Townsville and Pearce.

The Committee also examined the future uses of RAAF storage facilities at Regents Park and concluded that Warehouse 40, located there, is a valuable asset and should be retained by Defence as part of the National Storage and Distribution Centre. The land not required by Defence will be sold off and the Committee has recommended that Defence should continue discussions with Auburn Municipal Council and other planning authorities to ensure that the land which Defence proposes to sell will be used for purposes compatible with other adjacent land uses, including medium density housing.

The proposal examined by the Committee involves the relocation of No 1 Operational Support Unit to Townsville, and the Committee concluded that this will result in improved efficiencies and response times—Townsville is the home base of the Operational Deployment Force and the scope of the work can be justified on the basis of operational improvements which will result in having the two units in close proximity.

The Committee's inquiry into the DNSDC and the Air Force aspects of DLRP focused in part on fire protection measures to be provided. The Committee was advised that all upgrading of existing facilities will, as is economically cost effective, comply with the fire safety requirements of the Building Code of Australia and the Defence Manual of Fire Protection Engineering (FACMAN 2). Some fire safety standards required by FACMAN 2 are more stringent than the BCA because they address the very pertinent issue of strategic risk. The Committee has nevertheless recommended that Defence should provide the Commonwealth Fire Board with details of the fire protection measures for comment.
The property implications of the proposal have considerable ramifications, not only in terms of asset sales, but also job redundancies which will result from the closure of stores depots.

The Committee has concluded that the successful completion of the DLRP is dependent on the proceeds from the sale of surplus properties funding construction or refurbishment of warehouses and associated facilities.

The Committee therefore recommended that Defence should ensure that optimal prices are obtained from land sales.In relation to redundancies which will result, Defence advised the Committee that the recruitment of staff for the depots has ceased and this will provide scope for individuals to be retrained or redeployed where possible. Defence did, however, acknowledge that there will be some people for whom it will not be possible to find current positions.

The Committee's eighth report for 1992 relates to the construction of a Commonwealth office building on the corner of Adelaide and Creek Streets Brisbane. The 25 storey building will provide 25,000 square metres of office space and four basement levels. The building which will be known as Terrica Place, named after the 1920 building it replaces, will primarily accommodate the Australian Taxation Office.

The Australian Taxation Office is committed to 16,000 square metres of the building while the balance of the office space will be leased to other agencies and the ground level retail areas will be let as shops.In line with the fully commercialised nature of the office estate, all tenants will pay market based rents and will be required to enter into long term leases with Australian Estate Management.

The Australian Taxation Office has agreed to a 10 year lease term with two five-year options thereafter. Terrica Place will be built on portion of a Commonwealth-owned site, adjacent to the historic Anzac Square precinct, on which there are already two government buildings. The major one is Block A of some 17 storeys built in 1972 and the other is Block B of some 7 storeys built in 1934. Block B is listed on the Register of the National Estate.

In addition to ensuring the preservation of Block B the Terrica Place development will integrate the three buildings into a single complex around a landscaped plaza. The design of the new building meets the requirements of the Australian Heritage Commission.The construction of this building will enable the Australian Taxation Office to collocate its Brisbane central business district activity in the one building and will greatly enhance administrative efficiency.

The completion of the building will increase the proportion of Commonwealth owned office space in Brisbane from 27% to 42% of Commonwealth occupied space. The project will protect the Commonwealth from the strong rent increases expected in Brisbane at the time of completion of the project.

The Committee is satisfied on the basis of confidential information provided to it that the project is the most cost effective means of meeting the Commonwealth's accommodation requirements the Brisbane central business district.

The estimated out-turn cost of the project is $82m although the Committee was advised by Australian Estate Management that in the current extremely competitive tendering market it is confident of receiving a tender price below that figure. I commend the reports to the Senate.
