SPEECH.PARA: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to remove uncertainties about the enforcement of laws concerning truth in labelling of wine. In 1989, the Commonwealth Parliament amended the Australian Wine And Brandy Corporation Act 1980 to implement a wine Label Integrity Program. The wine Label Integrity Program was developed at the request of the wine industry and requires wine manufacturers to keep records to support labelling claims of the vintage, variety and region of origin of wine. These records and the stocks to which they relate must also be made available for audit upon request by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The aim of the Program is to ensure truth in labelling and so increase consumer confidence in the reliability of wine label claims. The Program also aims to ensure that all winemakers compete honestly amongst themselves in the marketing of wine.
The first Label Integrity Program inspections occurred in the Clare Valley of South Australia in 1990. No breaches of the record-keeping provisions occurred and no instances of fraud were detected.
However, practice in using the legislation where over two hundred audits have now been conducted has highlighted technical deficiencies which are likely to impair the enforcement of the legislation.

The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 requires manufacturers to keep Label Integrity Program records, but there is no requirement that the records be accurate and complete. Further, where the Corporation under section 42 of the Act requests a manufacturer to provide Label Integrity Program records the manufacturer must provide the records, even if they are self-incriminating, but the manufacturer is then protected from prosecution should the records disclose false labelling. Thus, there is some doubt whether a successful prosecution concerning false labelling could be launched under the present provisions of the Act.
This Bill aims to rectify these deficiencies.
This Bill does four key things.

First—where Label Integrity Program records are required to be kept under the Act, clause 39ZAAA makes it an offence to knowingly or recklessly fail to make and keep such records, or to make and keep false, misleading or incomplete records.

Second—section 42 of the Act, which requires a person to provide information to the Corporation on request and indemnifies the person from prosecution where such information is furnished is amended. The amendment removes the Label Integrity Program provisions from the ambit of section 42 but otherwise leaves section 42 unchanged.

Third—clause 39ZAA of the Bill provides that where the Corporation requests a person to provide Label Integrity Program records, the person may with reasonable excuse refuse the request. The Bill provides that it is a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse to provide Label Integrity Program records where they are self-incriminating. The aim of these amendments is to enable the Corporation to instigate a prosecution where Label Integrity Program records, provided at the Corporation's request, disclose false labelling of wine, while retaining the right of a person to refuse to provide such records where they are self-incriminating. Where a person chooses, with reasonable excuse, not to provide the records, the Corporation may still exercise its inspection powers to obtain Label Integrity Program records and will be able to use those records to initiate a prosecution. Thus the original intention of the legislation will be achieved.

Clause 39ZAC of the Bill enables the Corporation to retain Label Integrity Program records for 60 days or if a prosecution for a label offence is initiated within 60 days, until proceedings and appeals are concluded. A person will be able to inspect or copy the records provided to the Corporation.

The fourth change in the Bill honours a commitment made by the Government in 1989 to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The first of the two amendments involved will enable a person to copy evidence seized by a Label Integrity Program inspector. The second reduces the period of validity of an offence warrant from one month to a maximum of seven days. The Senate Committee had argued that a person ought to be entitled to copy records which were seized by an inspector and that the period of validity of an offence warrant of one month was too long and could unfairly infringe a person's privacy. The Government had agreed to consider the Committee's recommendations in the light of experience in administering the Act and to implement any necessary changes when it was next amended.
The Bill will not have any financial impact.

The changes proposed in this Bill are aimed at safeguarding the integrity of our wine industry and have the industry's wholehearted support. The success of our wine industry is reflected in its motto of purity, integrity, quality and economy. This Bill furthers this objective.

Australian winemakers have a 97% share of the domestic market for wine. Exports of Australian wine have soared from $20.5m in 1985/86 to $234m in 1991/92. The industry is aiming for $1 billion of exports per year by the year 2000. Continued export expansion is the key to future growth and prosperity of our wine industry and truth in labelling is the key to consumer confidence in our wines here and abroad.

Our wine Label Integrity Program legislation has drawn praise at home and abroad for underpinning the integrity of our wines and for providing the platform for fair trading in wine. The Label Integrity Program is seen as a tough and effective deterrent to fraud. The amendments proposed in this Bill will ensure the legislation can be enforced in the courts and will safeguard our hard-won international reputation for high quality, value for money, true to label wines.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
NATIONAL ROAD TRANSPORT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

This Bill is to amend the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991 to give effect to the Light Vehicles Agreement formulated at the Heads of Government meeting on 11 May 1992. The Agreement involves a regime for vehicles weighing 4.5 tonnes or less, their drivers, other road users and related matters. This will expand the powers and functions of the National Road Transport Commission to include regulation of all motorised vehicles and not just those vehicles weighing more than 4.5 tonnes. In addition, the Commission shall exercise responsibility for policy development for light vehicles, excluding the determination of charges.

When the National Road Transport Commission was formally established at the beginning of this year, it was hailed as a major step towards achieving fundamental and lasting reforms of road transport—reforms which would benefit all Australians as a result of a more efficient road transport industry sector.
In the short time the Commission has been operating, it has achieved significant progress towards the development of uniform charges and technical standards for heavy vehicles.

The Commission has earned a reputation for its independence and fairness through extensive formal and informal consultations with industry and Governments. The first recommendations of the NRTC in relation to heavy vehicle charges have been considered and approved by the Ministerial Council.

The charging determinations have received support from a convincing majority of States. The charges have also received overwhelming support from the road transport industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Transport Workers' Union.

The addition of light vehicles to the terms of reference of the National Road Transport Commission is another significant step towards creating a single national road transport regulatory environment.

Australians are one of the most mobile people on earth. The ability to move freely anywhere in the country is something we consider a fundamental right. Nevertheless, one of the most basic ways through which we enjoy our right of mobility on the ground is governed by a myriad of different regulations. Even to the basics of traffic rules.

In many places on State borders, such as in Albury/Wodonga, Tweed Heads/Gold Coast, and in the Canberra/Queanbeyan region, near neighbours and colleagues who have the same type of car, are subject to different registration requirements, different inspection requirements and differing on road requirements.

The management and development of the regulations covering light vehicles has meant duplication of work amongst the States. The National Road Transport Commission will play a significant role in facilitating and ensuring continued co-operation among the States and Territories to reach a solution to these problems. It will create the basis for a nationally consistent legislative framework which will streamline administrative processes in government bureaucracies across the country.

Our roads constitute a major asset to this country, but it is also an asset which requires constant maintenance and upgrading. An important function of the Commission will be to assist in the development of indicators which can provide better ways of assessing how we, as a Nation, are coping with this task.

The Commission will collect and publish information on important issues affecting road transport. Information will be assembled and published on the comparative assessment of the performance of road authorities and road systems. This will assist all levels of government by providing a better, more balanced view on the delivery of road funding programs.

In addition, the Commission will monitor the use of alternative fuels and publish information on road safety. The Commission will not pursue uniformity purely for uniformity's sake. In a number of specified areas, it must demonstrate that significant net benefits would arise before developing proposals.
I now turn to the individual amendments which are set out in the Bill.

The principal amendment in the Bill will provide for the inclusion of the Light Vehicles Agreement in a Schedule to the National Road Transport Commission Act. The proposed amendments will expand the terms of reference of the National Road Transport Commission to include a range of issues relating to light vehicles. The Commission will also assemble and publish information on road funding, the taxes and road related charges applying to light vehicles, the performance of our road systems, the effectiveness of road authorities, and on road safety.

The other amendments proposed within the Bill cover those areas which make specific reference to issues covered by either the Heads of Government Agreement on Heavy Vehicles or the Light Vehicles Agreement. These amendments do not affect the manner in which the Commission and the Ministerial Council operate, but are limited to clarifying which agreement is referred to.

The Commission is funded through contributions by the Commonwealth and the States based on shares approved by the Ministerial Council. The Commonwealth contribution is 35%. In 1992/93 this amounts to $1.1 million. The financial impact on the Commonwealth of the expansion of the terms of reference of the Commission will be minimal.

Successful and lasting reforms which facilitate a better, more efficient road transport environment has been a priority for this Government. The expansion of the terms of reference of the Commission to include light vehicles is certain to bring benefits to all Australians.
I expect all governments to continue to honour the commitment by Heads of Government to implement a uniform national road transport registration system.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are discussing the National Health and Medical Research Council Bill 1992. The aim of this Bill is to establish the National Health and Medical Research Council as a statutory authority. Established in 1936, the Council has become Australia's peak advisory body on public health, health care, health and medical research and health ethics. I join with my colleague Dr Bob Woods in the House of Representatives in offering my compliments to the NHMRC for the work it has done, in particular its promotion of medical research which has put Australia at the forefront of medical research in the world. I believe this is quite a feat, given the size of Australia's population and the size of our medical and allied health research fraternity. We only have to look at the newspapers to see some of the breakthroughs that have occurred in Australia in the area of medical research.

PARA.TAB: Arguments have been put for and against the NHMRC becoming a statutory authority. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council deals with issues that are of direct concern to all Australians in one way or another—from the food we eat to the air we breathe. These issues should continue to be dealt with expertly and impartially, and all citizens should be comfortable in the knowledge that the peak body for advising on these matters is beyond interference. Only statutory independence can ensure that degree of comfort and confidence for the community.

That is the Minister's point of view, but I do not believe that in his second reading speech he put forward a convincing case for that point of view. On the other hand, those who advocate for the status quo being maintained put forward the view that the NHMRC has operated as an Order in Council for over 50 years and has survived and served the country well; that the NHMRC has maintained a strong independence; and that it is very accountable, more so than many statutory authorities. It reports to Parliament twice a year through its session reports, and the sessions are open to the media. The NHMRC reports annually to Parliament on medical research activities as well. The flexibility of the Order in Council has allowed the organisation to evolve over time and to adapt to deal with new issues as they emerge.

PARA.TAB: The NHMRC in 1990 undertook an internal review of the Council and its activities. On page 2, under the heading `Organisation and Structure', the committee carrying out the internal review states:

SPEECH.PARA: At the request of the Minister for Community Services and Health the review paid considerable attention to the question of whether NHMRC should become a statutory authority. Proponents argued the needs for accountability and independence of a body such as the NHMRC could be met properly only through legislation. The review committee was not convinced that this was the case and considered disadvantages associated with becoming a statutory body, such as inflexibility and increased costs, outweighed the advantages.
That is the view of the internal review committee. I bet it laboured hard and long over the phrasing of this paragraph:
Accepting the Minister's intention to proceed with legislation, the review committee has proposed a model with the following main features:

One of the committee's roles was to review the whole body, and it was hamstrung by the fact that it had to operate within the constraints of accepting the Minister's intention to proceed with the legislation. I would love to have been a fly on the wall while they drafted that little paragraph.

PARA.TAB: That is the view of the internal review committee. But no, the Minister seems to think that it is much better if the NHMRC becomes a statutory authority. As I said, the internal review committee was not convinced that it should become a statutory authority, the Minister did not convince them, nor has he convinced the coalition.

The Council will still be dependent on the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, and it will still be subject to government intervention. I do not believe that the establishment of the NHMRC as a statutory authority will change this. The coalition is not convinced that legislation will lead to a stronger body. We believe it will lead to the continuation of potential conflicts of interest and other problems, especially in terms of the ethical committees of the NHMRC, and we believe that this issue needs to be addressed.

The Australian Health Ethics Committee is responsible for the ethical review of medical research and clinical practice and the formulation of related guidelines. There is a concern that there is a potential for conflict of interest in having an ethics committee as part of a body whose major function is to promote research. I do not think it takes much to understand that a body which is promoting research will have problems if the Ethics Committee has concerns about a particular approach to or direction of research.

I might just say here that I was undertaking some research at the Queen Victoria Medical Research Centre measuring foetal movements in pregnant mothers—I do not suppose you would measure them in anything but pregnant mothers, if you were doing human research—looking at the ways in which we might be able to detect foetuses at risk.I happened, by chance, to be at the Queen Victoria Hospital when some of the early IVF research was being undertaken there.

With my background in psychology I was concerned with the research on some of the projects that were being undertaken that really had not been scrutinised totally by the public. The person with whom I was working there, Professor William Walters, and I had long discussions about some of the research projects. His concern was such that it led him to write a book jointly about the ethics of IVF, and to raise some of the issues in the public arena.

I still have mixed reactions to some of that research. I think it is important that those issues, which are very complex, are not impeded by a conflict of interest. That debate should go on free and unfettered because it is really right at the cutting edge of our concept of what we see of ourselves as human beings. I saw people wrestling with that in that program at the Queen Victoria Hospital. In fact, some of them who are involved were challenged to argue to the roots of their intellect with themselves and with others about the direction that their research was going in. It was interesting to be there at that time, seeing that research starting off in its embryonic stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —One is always capable of being misrepresented here, Senator, but I think I understand what you are saying.

—I thank the Minister. Seeing the hassles and the challenges that they were facing in being at the forefront of that research, was a valuable experience for me. I could see the challenge that it also posed to the newly formed ethics committee at the Queen Victoria Hospital, and again, the problem with the hospital being involved in judging the research of its own researchers. I believe that it is vital for that process to be separated so that the debate can go on, as I said, as free and unfettered as possible.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill also called for the separate establishment of the Human Ethics Committee as a statutory authority. I believe Senator Tate, the Minister responsible for the passage of this Bill in the Senate, chaired that Committee.

We have referred to the Senate Community Affairs Committee the question of the separation of the ethical component of the NHMRC to a separate body, and whether it should be a statutory authority or whether it should take some other form. The coalition at this stage is of the opinion that it should be separate and completely independent. The Committee will be seeking information and evidence from a number of people who will make submissions to it on Friday. I guess that leaves that aspect of the Bill to the committee stage after we have met on Friday.

Before concluding my short speech on this Bill this evening I cannot pass over an article that appeared in the Australian yesterday, when we are debating the NHMRC. It is headed `Lab Labours Lost'. It is about a problem that has been identified in the current Budget where the Government thought it was granting a rise to medical research. I do not know whether the figures are right here—one should never believe everything one reads in the newspapers—but the article claims that because of the changes to employer-funded superannuation, the NHMRC has had to contribute an extra $1m for researchers, and that that money has had to come from the research budget. Mark Ragg's article also claims:

SPEECH.PARA: But far worse than that, a miscalculation in last year's allocation meant that the NH&MRC received more money than the strict formula used by the Department of Finance said it should. The NH&MRC, like both government departments, was unaware of the error. It allocated the money and committed scientists to ongoing projects.

One has to understand how the NHMRC works. It may grant a project for so many years, so you get all the researchers on line, employ the staff—especially young postgraduate research students—and the project is up and running. The article continues:

Now that money has been withdrawn from this year's allocation, leaving the NH&MRC obliged to support last year's grants and with significantly less money to distribute to new projects than in previous years. The result, according to eminent medical researchers, is a disaster.
It goes on to say:

Professor John Chalmers, a former chairman of the NH&MRC, past president of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians and currently dean of medicine at Flinders University, estimates that almost a third fewer new projects will be funded this year than in previous years.
He also says:

But because of this cut in funding, about 100 new research projects in heart disease, cancer, molecular biology, AIDS, infectious diseases, mental health, women's health and Aboriginal health are going to miss out.
Mark Ragg goes on to say:

Efforts to obtain a response from the Minister for Health, Brian Howe, for this story have been unsuccessful. But Howe is known to have written to the Minister for Finance, Ralph Willis, in an attempt to sort out the error. The letter is said to have been along the lines of "There has been a mistake and what should be a rise is actually a cut in funding. Can we sort it out?" It is believed that the NH&MRC will get an answer by the end of this week.

I hope the NHMRC gets an answer by the end of the week. We cannot afford to tinker and have errors like this amongst our medical research community. The calls to other countries, especially the United States—the lures that are held out to them—are very, very attractive. We are seeing some of our best medical researchers leave our shores because they cannot continue their research; because there is uncertainty in funding; because there is a lack of continuity; and because of these sorts of errors; and because of the lack of thinking through of the implications of the employer superannuation guarantee. It has left the NHMRC and the funding of medical research in a parlous state unless the Minister gets an appropriate answer from Mr Willis.

PARA.TAB: I call on the Minister here, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), to ensure that something is done to correct the problem that seems to have existed. I am sure that medical researchers and all of those of us who benefit from the outcomes of Australian medical research are concerned about these issues, and more concerned about them than whether or not the NHMRC is a statutory authority.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health and Medical Research Council Bill 1992 provides legislative recognition for the National Health and Medical Research Council and makes it into a separate statutory authority. At present the NHMRC exists by virtue of an Executive order, which is a fairly precarious basis for existence. Giving the NHMRC a legislative basis as a statutory authority puts it on a more secure footing but, perhaps more importantly, it also improves the ability of Parliament to scrutinise the Council's operations.

PARA.TAB: I find the Opposition's attitude a little confusing. On the one hand, it is arguing that there should be greater parliamentary scrutiny of the conduct of the Council—especially in the ethics area—but on the other hand, it does not seem to want to support legislation which provides the opportunity for that scrutiny. Certainly, the NHMRC should be independent and I cannot see that this Bill threatens or undermines that independence in any way. However, it is surely desirable for the Council to operate under an Act which can be scrutinised and, if necessary, amended by the Parliament.

There have certainly been many concerns expressed over the years from a variety of quarters about the way in which the NHMRC conducts its affairs. It is probably fair to say that the major criticism has been about the Council's lack of public accountability and also its unwillingness to accept that, alongside its medical research role, it also has a responsibility to the broader community.

But the climate at the NHMRC has changed and is changing.For a start, as this Bill confirms, representation on the Council is much broader and is no longer quite so heavily dominated by medical researchers or the medical and scientific professions. We now have nominees on the Council from: the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission; the trade union movement; tertiary education bodies specialising in health care training; business organisations; the nursing profession; consumer groups; social welfare organisations; and the environmental movement. In addition, following representations from the Public Health Association of Australia, the Australian Democrats advised the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services that we would move amendments to put on the Council a representative of organisations with expertise in broad public health issues.

The Minister, as he stated in his closing remarks in the House, indicated he was prepared to accept our amendment. However, I note that a very similar amendment was moved and passed in the House of Representatives and, accordingly, we will not be proceeding with our amendment here. So, basically, we now have a wide range of interests represented on the Council and this appears to be having the effect of ensuring that the NHMRC does not confine itself only to narrow medical and scientific concerns. Further, having such a broad range of experience on the Council also brings a much higher degree of community scrutiny to its work.

This Bill also contains provisions for a basic consultation process prior to the Council making any recommendations or issuing any guidelines. It also sets up a complaints process, including the establishment of a Commissioner of Complaints, in relation to decisions the Council makes about funding medical research. What all this means is that the NHMRC is becoming a much more accountable organisation. It is more open to input from the general public and community and consumer organisations and is no longer under the dominance of medical researchers. It is more receptive to broad public interests and ethical concerns.

I am aware that there are still critics of the Council who feel it remains beholden to industry, economic and medical research interests at the expense of wider community concerns. But I think it is also clear that the old days of the NHMRC are well and truly gone. We should acknowledge the changes that have taken place and congratulate the NHMRC on its progress towards improved accountability and better understanding of its community responsibilities.

I turn to three specific concerns that we have. No doubt these will be covered in far more detail on Friday when we reach the Committee stage. It has been suggested to me by several organisations and individuals that the Bill really falls down in providing adequate parliamentary scrutiny of the Council's activities. There is, of course, a need to allow the Council to function independently, set its own goals, make its own plans and develop its own strategies. However, there is also a need to ensure that the Council is accountable. After all, its work is of critical significance and it frequently deals with issues that are of great community concern and enormous community interest.

As I said earlier, there has been a great improvement in the way the Council operates, but I think we should examine whether there is a need for more formal parliamentary scrutiny within this legislation. For example, I note that any ministerial directions to be given to the Council under clause 9 of the Bill are not disallowable. Similarly, the Council's strategic plans are not disallowable, although they must be tabled in both houses of Parliament. Any guidelines the Council issues are also not subject to parliamentary approval or disapproval. There is a fine balance to be struck between giving an organisation like the NHMRC the capacity to operate flexibly and independently and subjecting it to parliamentary scrutiny.

It is, of course, true to say that Parliament—although in theory representing the community—is not necessarily an accurate reflection of community attitudes and it is certainly far from being the fount of all wisdom when it comes to medical and ethical issues. However, there is cause to look at improving the parliamentary scrutiny of the Council and this is an issue that I will be pursuing when the Committee examines the Bill on Friday.

The second area of concern I have is with the complaints process. It is certainly a step in the right direction, but it deals only with decisions about funding and I think there is some scope for widening the grounds for complaint. For example, it seems to me that it should be possible for the subjects of the NHMRC funded research to make a complaint about the way the research was carried out or how they were treated, or how the information they were given was relevant, and so on. I ask the Minister whether he will give consideration to that suggestion.

The third area of concern covers what probably is the most controversial area, that is, the ethics component of the NHMRC. The Bill confirms the Australian Health Ethics Committee as a principal committee of the NHMRC. The AHEC is charged with drafting broad ethical guidelines on matters which it can either initiate itself or have referred to it by the Minister, the general community or the Council. At present, we have a two-tiered approach to ethics, with the NHMRC Committee operating on the national level and various institutional ethics committees operating locally.

Over the years, there have been numerous calls to separate the functions of the ethics committees from the NHMRC and establish an independent ethics authority. I accept that there is some potential for conflict between the NHMRC's roles and I see that there are some very genuine concerns. However, I also feel very strongly that we should not eliminate the in-house ethical scrutiny of NHMRC projects. Even if we do establish an independent ethics authority, we still need to have an ethics body within the Council because there is quite clearly a need for medical and scientific research to maintain very close ties with ethical issues.

I must also say that it is far from clear to me just what people mean when they talk about an `independent' ethics authority. I suspect that some of them are just after a body that will represent their own views. Some of those who have not been happy with the AHEC and its predecessor, the National Bioethics Consultative Committee, are after something that reflects quite a different approach to ethical issues—perhaps on religious grounds, perhaps from some philosophical viewpoint. That is fair enough. I am not arguing that that is in any way improper. But we surely have to ask: who would be on such an independent body if these groups and organisations were to have the say as to who was to be appointed? After all, the calibre of the decision making of any authority or committee still relies upon the quality, beliefs, experiences and values of those people who actually make up its membership—the expertise of its members. There is absolutely no guarantee that a so-called `independent' ethics authority would be any better or any worse than what we have within this Council.

We also have to recognise that many ethical issues are simply not resolvable. The debate about them continues on and on, and we will not get to a situation where everybody is happy. They may be issues about which people have very strong views, based perhaps on their personal philosophy or, as I said before, on specific religious beliefs. These people will not change their views and they will not change their behaviour just because any ethical body tells them that they have to do so.

Some people who have commented on this Bill have also called for an independent authority to be subject to very close parliamentary scrutiny and control. Again, I understand this point and I accept it. But I have to say again that there is no reason to suppose that parliamentarians either have any better understanding of the issues than anyone else or, in this case, will accurately reflect the views of the community. It could be argued that medical research matters are running ahead of the community's understanding of ethical issues, and some issues would be far better looked at and more appropriately addressed by far greater community participation in the decision making process within ethics committees.

So, generally, I am far from convinced that the establishment of an independent ethics authority would take us any further towards a satisfactory resolution of the difficult ethical dilemmas facing us. However, I think the concerns being raised are valid ones and that the issue certainly deserves some more examination and exploration. As I said earlier, I think this Bill should be passed. The NHMRC should have an in-house ethics committee. I also believe that the Standing Committee on Community Affairs should look at these issues when it examines the Bill on Friday. It should also take into account the way in which appointments are made to the in-house ethics committee.

The Democrats believe that Parliament should be taking a closer look at the whole issue of the need or otherwise for an independent ethics authority. Therefore, I intend to move that the matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I will not read out the entire motion. Very briefly, the motion asks the Committee to look at the current relationship between the Australian Health Ethics Committee and the various institutional ethics committees throughout the country; the particular requirements for ethical guidelines in relation to the conduct of medical research involving humans; and the optimum legal structure for any such independent ethics authority, the membership of and the method of appointing people to such an authority, and the relationship between that authority and Federal Parliament.

I urge the Government and the Opposition to support this motion when it comes before the Senate. I shall defer moving the motion for a few days to give honourable senators time to look at the precise wording and to make sure that we have something that all parties are happy with and will agree to support.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats believe that this Bill correctly gives the NHMRC legislative backing. While we do want further exploration of the need for an independent ethics body, we feel that there also has to be an ethics body within the Council itself. For these reasons, although we do see that there is a need for some improvement to the legislation, the Democrats will be supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The key issue that is confronting this Parliament in respect of the National Health and Medical Research Council Bill 1992 is: do we believe that the ethical guidelines governing medical research promoted by a body named the National Health and Medical Research Council should be determined by that same Council? That is the key question that we are confronted with in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Any thinking, reasonable person—irrespective of religion, as suggested by Senator Lees—would say, `No, that is a conflict of interest'. It is not proper, it is not ethical, for the body which promotes medical research to be the same body that determines the ethical guidelines governing that research. Yet, it appears that Senator Lees is prepared to vote for this legislation, which does precisely that. That, in my view, is unethical; in my view it is undemocratic; and in my view it challenges the whole concept of equity and fairness in human endeavour.

Like Senator Patterson, I want to say that the National Health and Medical Research Council has done a number of very fine things. Much of its research has been properly and effectively targeted. Hundreds of people have been engaged over a long period in assessing applications for research funds. It must be borne in mind that the NHMRC is responsible for about, I think, only 25 to 30 per cent of the funds allocated for medical research in this country.

There have been occasions, however, when the National Health and Medical Research Council has seriously bungled and promoted certain types of research which were neither medical research nor research appropriate for that body to fund. I refer, of course, to the occasion on which the National Health and Medical Research Council funded to the tune of $450,000 over a three-year period a project at Monash University for the development of a philosophical approach to experimentation on human embryos and gametes. Might I say—and Senator Lees should listen to this—that that project failed to meet the scientific benchmark for the approval of applications that year; it failed to meet that standard. What did the National Health and Medical Research Council do on that occasion? It said, `We will fund it anyhow; we will fund it on a special initiative grant'.

In those years there were something like 300 applications which met the scientific standard, but were not provided with the funds. However, the project to which I referred was provided with $450,000 of taxpayers' money. The average amount of medical research grants is, I suspect, around $12,000 to $15,000.

It is most important to understand what we in this chamber are faced with. We are faced with the need to acknowledge that a conflict of interest arises where a body which promotes medical research determines the ethical guidelines for that medical research. On the one hand there is a commitment to the technological imperative and, on the other hand, there is the need to sit back and assess independently whether that medical research should take place. I will quote from Robert Moser, MD, who in The Technological Explosion in Medical Science had this biomedical credo, which is what we are faced with:

SPEECH.PARA: [The technological imperative] is the unquenchable spirit and relentless desire to explore and expand knowledge to the ultimate, to invent the uninvented, to discover the undiscovered, to create the uncreated. And the devil take the consequences. No power on earth can stop the mind of man. . . The single-minded dedication to pursuit of truth most often casts aside or ignores all external considerations. . . the scientist hot on the trail of new knowledge. . . is not inclined to reckon with the social or political or economic implications of his potential discovery. . . the Manhattan Project was accelerated by momentous historical events, but many scientists were fascinated by the chase, per se. For them the potential for a nuclear Armageddon was thrust aside as a momentary dark reflection. . . In similar vein, a like phenomenon is occurring in genetic engineering. The scientists who entered the fearsome lists of hybrid creativity paused only momentarily to reflect on the social, moral, and political implications. Then they. . . plunged ahead in their relentless pursuit of new biologic forms. Now the research is continuing with unprecedented rapidity. Efforts are abroad to sever all regulatory restraints. A few nervous religious ethicists continue to scratch their heads in concern, but. . . I suspect that even those anxious individuals. . . had ever joined forces to create laws to inhibit genetic engineering, the intellectual imperative would have prevailed; the laws would have been circumvented or violated, and the research would have continued. . . We can tether the giant of technology,. . . but we will never stop the inspired investigator. . . . He will defy politics and economics and threats of physical harm. He will work in basements and garrets. He will plead for or purloin equipment to pursue his star. . . to others he whispers: `We have no time for your puny politics or social concerns. . .

PARA.TAB: What do we do when faced with that situation? Should we continue the situation whereby the Australian Health Ethics Committee is a subcommittee of the National Health and Medical Research Council? Should that committee continue to make recommendations to the National Health and Medical Research Council and should that Council, whose primary purpose is the pursuit and promotion of medical research, be the organisation which establishes the ethical guidelines under which that research takes place?

Clearly, that cannot continue one moment longer. Yet, as I understand Senator Lees—unless I have heard her incorrectly—that is precisely what will happen. She has proposed today that we will discuss these ethics questions in a Senate standing committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate has already done that.

—Exactly. As Senator Patterson says, Senator Tate's committee has long since done that and I will come to that in a moment. Senator Lees is saying, `Let us send it off to another committee and have the report back on 30 June next year'. That is putting it on the long finger! I wonder who worked out the terms of reference. Senator Lees should be honest. Has she had discussions with the Government about this and is this the deal which will ensure Democrat support for this Bill? I believe this is more important than a party political decision. This is a matter for the individual conscience of each member of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the key question. Should the situation continue whereby the ethical guidelines governing medical research are determined by the same body which is promoting and funding that research? Let me deal with some of questions that have been concerning a number of people about the National Health and Medical Research Council, not least of whom are disabled persons. They are very, very worried about the current situation which has been developed by the National Health and Medical Research Council, namely, the guidelines for the establishment of registers of persons and families with genetic disorders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just seen medical records from one hospital all over the gardens this week.

—I acknowledge the point Senator Patterson makes. The issue of guidelines by the National Health and Medical Research Council for the establishment of registers of persons and families with genetic disorders is a very important one for the disabled. A person's family name can be on that register without his or her approval. Does anyone in this chamber think that is correct? Does anyone in this chamber deny that that is a violation of the individual's human rights? Given the rapid rate of information and research in this particular area, are we not on the verge of the brave new world?

PARA.TAB: How many of us read recently of a newly developed test to detect genetic disorders in human embryos merely days after conception? The test carves cells from four- or eight-celled embryos, to identify genes for cystic fibrosis, for the purpose of discarding individuals deemed to be imperfect. That was announced in the New England Journal of Medicine only last month.

This system of genetic screening is an ethical minefield involving questions of the genetic composition of future humans, questions of privacy, destructive experiments on human embryos and the status of the disabled. The disabled in fact have fought long and hard against discrimination and to be recognised as equal. We have recently been debating the second reading of the Disability Discrimination Bill. That Bill has been to a Committee. Would it not be ironic if we were to allow to continue the situation whereby the National Health and Medical Research Council can approve, without reference to Parliament, guidelines for the establishment of registers of persons and families with genetic disorders in such a manner where an individual can have his or her family name on that register without his or her permission?

The test to which I referred, and indeed which would be authorised by the National Health and Medical Research Council's guidelines on human experimentation, was done in America but could be done in Australia by scientists funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council under its own human experimentation guidelines. It can be done here. The development of that test to detect and eradicate the genetically unfit is an insult to the disabled. It has grave ramifications for their status in our society. It is about genetic discrimination.

There is a small group of powerful medical elite—I am certainly not tarring all with the same brush—who are about weeding out those that they deem imperfect. Where will it end? Will those deemed as having a genetic disposition to being fat or short-sighted be eliminated? Who will decide? It hit me when I read in an overseas report that a further investigation was being made to develop DNA probes which would be able to be used to detect in the early human embryo susceptibility of that individual to a whole range of disorders ranging from Alzheimer's disease to cancer. That really hit me because my first wife died of cancer and my mother had Alzheimer's disease. Once it is brought down to those specific individual examples, one sees how it can affect us all.

Some people might say, `It would be better off if he wasn't here'. That may have been a possibility if that particular test was developed a little over 50 years ago. So it has everything to do with the people of Australia and each individual person in Australia. Therefore, it is one of the key and important questions to be dealt with by this Parliament. We can deal with all sorts of things in this Parliament, but this is one of the key issues.

Under this legislation we are now saying that the Parliament has no say at all. The Parliament gives it over to the National Health and Medical Research Council's subcommittee, the Australian Health Ethics Committee, to recommend to the National Health and Medical Research Council the guidelines which are to be adopted for matters of crucial importance to society.

I believe we would be failing in our duty if we were not to challenge this and not amend this legislation or throw it out. It has been said by Senator Lees—echoing what Minister Howe said in his speech in the other place—that this Bill makes the NHMRC more accountable to Parliament. It does no such thing. Senator Lees can say, `If this is an Act of Parliament we will be able to amend the Act'. After 30 June 1993! She must be kidding. It would need the support of whatever Government is in power at that stage because no matter how we amend the legislation in this place, it has to be passed by the House of Representatives where the Government has the numbers. If the Government does not see fit to do anything, the legislation will not go through and Senator Lees knows that. It will not do anything to make that body accountable.

I will now foreshadow certain amendments to this legislation. I will ensure that Parliament has a say and that the Australian Health Ethics Committee is made accountable to this Parliament. I will propose an amendment that ethics guidelines be approved by the Parliament in a similar way that the rules in respect of nursing homes are required to be approved by the Parliament.

The second amendment that I will move is in respect of the last two clauses of the National Health and Medical Research Council Bill. The penultimate clause in the Bill entrenches in legislation the unsatisfactory guidelines established by the National Health and Medical Research Council in respect of human embryo experimentation. Those guidelines were considered—and I hope that Senator Lees is listening—by the all-party Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation.

The Democrat representative on that Committee, Senator Macklin, supported the majority view that the marker event determined in that ethical guideline had `no ethical validity'. Are we as a parliament now going to carry this legislation when our Senate Select Committee has indicated that the marker event in that guideline had no ethical validity?

My second amendment will be an addendum to ensure that that ethical invalidity is corrected and that the guidelines provide that there be no destructive non-therapeutic experimentation which frustrates the development of any human embryo. You, Madam Acting Deputy President, can see why I said that it is a matter for the conscience of every individual senator in this place, and it is.

I believe that we should not in any circumstances adopt this legislation as it is because it is entrenching the abhorrent situation that currently exists where the body which promotes and funds medical research is the same body which establishes the ethical guidelines governing that research. Anyone in our society will agree that that is unethical and that it must be remedied. If those amendments are not carried, this measure should be defeated in toto.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the National Health and Medical Research Council Bill 1992. This Bill raises some important and very complex issues, as my colleagues Senator Patterson and Senator Harradine have just laid out. It is a view of the Liberal and National parties that, firstly, the establishment of the NHMRC as a statutory body falls well into the category of failing a test that should be applied here to all legislation—that is, whether it achieves any necessary general benefit.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the Opposition believes, and it is supported in this attitude by many thoughtful and concerned people who are involved in the question of medical ethics, that it is essential for the Australian Health Ethics Committee to be separated from the National Health and Medical Research Council. That is basically the area that I want to address my remarks to tonight. There are grave concerns not just by some of us on this side of the chamber but by people in the community who are very much concerned about ensuring that there is a separation of the two.

Too often, more legislation is placed on the statute books and more statutory authorities are created for no necessary reason, with the inevitable consequence that eventually there is a greater demand on the public purse. Throughout this debate, the Opposition does not intend to cast any aspersions on the NHMRC, on its general record or on the competence and integrity of its personnel. That is far from the question that we are looking at this evening. I certainly want to make that point clear.

This in itself begs the question as to why this structural change is considered necessary, when the NHMRC has operated under an Executive order since 1936 and reports regularly to the Parliament. The onus is strongly on the Government to justify change when the review of 1990 concluded that the NHMRC should continue to be maintained by an order of Council.

The change to a statutory authority does not convey any real enhanced independence for or from government—the NHMRC will continue to be financially dependent upon the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services—nor will it have any greater accountability to the Parliament. While the NHMRC has worked well, there has been argument raised to the effect that, in the allocation of finance for research, there is a bias against originality because of decision making within a peer group. This argument may not be valid, but if there is a need for any restructuring of the NHMRC, it makes sense to delay any reconstruction as a statutory authority.

For these simple and pragmatic reasons, the Liberal and National parties oppose the main object of this Bill. Once again, in advocating that the Australian Health Ethics Committee become a separate institution from the NHMRC, we are not stating that this body has sought to act other than in accord with proper medical ethics; there is no question about that whatsoever.

However, serious questions have arisen as to whether there is not an inherent conflict of interest in having the regulation of medical ethics continue under the umbrella of the organisation that decides on medical research funding. That really needs to be clearly defined. It may well be the necessary function of the AHEC to apply some general brakes on aspects of research rather than simply guide it along agreed channels.

It is very relevant to this debate that the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation, chaired by the present Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, advocated such a separation of the peak body governing medical ethics from the NHMRC. Senator Harradine has already made mention of this Committee and its findings. Certainly there can be questions raised as to the effectiveness of the two bodies that preceded the AHEC when it was formed in 1991. The Medical Research Ethics Committee was formed in 1982 and the National Bioethics Consultative Committee was established in 1988 by the Australian Health Ministers' Conference.

The former came under criticism in January 1987 by Professor Hiram Caton for its attitudes towards the question of embryo experimentation, with a dogmatic denial of the humanity of embryos and for the fact that one member expressed indignation that parliamentarians should presume to somehow intimidate IVF researchers. The MREC was seen as having an underlying belief that it must not frustrate research. I suppose that is quite understandable. But the arguments so criticised by Professor Caton are entitled to be expressed within the medical and scientific world but should surely not be enshrined as accepted wisdom in determination of ethics. That is another area of concern and the basis on which a number of these decisions are made. It underscores the point that however well-intentioned, a medical ethics body that is closely tied to medical research will inevitably reflect the priorities and assumptions of researchers.

Again, the NBCC has failed to inspire confidence that it encompasses the full ethical range of the problems raised in genetic research. Thus, in its surrogacy report in April 1990 the NBCC actually dismissed the notion of core ethical values and stated that personal autonomy was the common goal of our society. To say the least, this is a debatable standpoint for any peak body in medical ethics. That is also of great concern to many people in the community. It is a valid point of view but, once again, I do not believe that it can be treated as accepted and received wisdom and therefore must certainly be questioned.

The NHMRC should be commended for its role in sponsoring medical ethics, and can point to the fact that in 1986 it insisted that funds would only be provided to institutions unless their research had been approved by an institutional ethics committee. This led to the institution of 120 such committees. It is not, however, denigrating this achievement in any way to say that it cannot stand as the end of a necessary process. Such in-house committees are inevitably limited by shared goals, assumptions and priorities and also cannot be expected to answer the big questions, even though their personnel will include people from outside the institution. We are looking at a much broader thing now than that which was looked at in the past.

Equally, a peak ethics body under the NHMRC umbrella will reflect certain assumptions of that body, praiseworthy as many of them will be. It simply makes sense for a greater distance to be set between the two. Whatever our own opinions, we must acknowledge that Australian society has come to grips with major ethical questions in the field of medical research. If one were to look back 10 or 15 years I believe that many people in the community today would never have envisaged what is going on in medical research. These include setting possible limits to reproductive technology and asking whether funding genetic engineering for the purposes of enhancement rather than the avoidance of major disabilities is ethical. Once again, I think there are many people in the community who have little problem with the question of the disability aspects of the research into biotechnology but they really do have serious and grave problems with just trying to get better and smarter people out of the process or whatever other type of formula or criteria they are trying to use.

It is well to remember that the science of eugenics, the breeding of superior human beings, was considered morally acceptable and desirable in the early part of our century, an opinion held by many leaders of quite intellectual opinion in Western society. But I believe that that has now changed. It took the experience of Hitler, strangely enough, to teach the civilised world what happens when eugenics are taken to their conclusion.

It therefore remains proper that strong independent ethical bodies should be in a position to sound the alarm should medical research, perhaps for the best of motives—I do not question that—take us down any such road. While it is true that modern society does not have the same corpus of shared values as occurred a couple of generations ago, there is still a consensus that Australia ought not disregard basic moral assumptions. There are tens of thousands of non-churchgoing Australians who have far from discarded the Judaeo-Christian ethic. Their beliefs should also be considered.

Australia needs a body to search for and state fearlessly ethical truth because that is particularly important in regard to medical and scientific research. They should be able to do that without fear. To do its job, it must be independent of other bodies, no matter how well-respected, and it must be directly answerable to the Parliament. I believe that those questions are the questions that we must be focusing on as we further consider this Bill. It is for those reasons that I believe it is essential that this Bill be examined thoroughly by the Senate Standing Committee with the assistance of informed witnesses and not proceed in its current form. I look forward to the contribution of those witnesses later this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was planning to speak in this debate and I apologise that I failed to get my name on the speakers list. Even if I was inclined to let it go, after hearing Senator Harradine I would not; no way. I am provoked by the parliamentary process. I strongly support this legislation. In my brief comments tonight I want to address the issues raised by Senator Harradine. Debating from moral outrage always leaves one wide open. I believe that Senator Harradine was left wide open.

PARA.TAB: To deal with the easier points, Senator Knowles said that she did not want to say anything nasty about the existence of the NHMRC to this point. But from here on in it would be a disaster if it happened to have an ethics committee as part of its main work. I ask Senator Knowles how she supposes it has been constructed since it got established. If it has been okay to have an in-house ethics committee up until now, what on earth will happen when it is turned into a statutory authority? It is a puerile argument and probably a tedious point that I score. But she cannot possibly say it has been doing all right until now and suddenly the world of ethics must be separated.

As for Senator Harradine, he wants to say that we may not have the ethics committee in the same organisation. It is a separate committee. I ask him what he says about hospital ethics committees. How can he possibly have a hospital ethics committee within a hospital?

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the legislation.

—I have read the legislation and I am totally unpersuaded by Senator Harradine's point. The ethics committee of the NHMRC is not the only ethics committee addressing ethics in this community. It is also separately constructed and it is also properly able to address these issues. Senator Harradine mentioned reasonable thinking people. They are the people who will be on the ethics committee. He also said there is no way it is open to public scrutiny. He clearly has not read the legislation either. The committees and the council have to come to the public as a process; they have to indicate and outline what they are proposing to do. They have to publicly consult at the outline stage. Having heard those submissions, and even given advice and advertisements on how to actually make the submissions, there is no way they could overlook allowing the community an opportunity to speak. Having done all of that, they take account of what the public has said. For the first time the NHMRC is seriously going to the public, and Senator Harradine wants to say that the ethics committee cannot be in there doing the same thing. It is absolutely the wrong timing and he is making the wrong points. The moral outrage is no weighty argument at all.
—You are doing well.

—I am delighted to hear that I am doing well, but I am terribly troubled if Senator Harradine says I am. The ethics committee of the NHMRC has been carrying the responsibility of trying to define what are the ethical considerations for concern for medical researchers or the NHMRC. It has also come up with guidelines over time and they have been modified as public view changes and as other information comes to bear. It is important to note that it is not the only ethics committee under which medical research is done. It is not the only ethics committee under which ethics in our community are talked about. For the record, I am pleased to say that I was on that aforementioned committee. I also note, Senator Harradine did not say it, that I was certainly one of the two dissenters. I have no reason to change my mind on anything I said then and I am not about—
—What about the genetic registers?

—If Senator Harradine would only be quiet, I will come to that in just one minute. Talking over him is like shouting over broken glass. He should give me a go. The ethics committee of the NHMRC has drawn up guidelines over time. It has taken references from itself, the community or the Minister to look at the need to modify those guidelines from time to time and indeed was tackling the very challenging issues of ethical guidelines for medical research before it became a matter of serious public debate. One of the reasons that I am very interested in looking at this matter is that when I chaired the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, although we took our terms of reference very seriously, we realised that we could not properly examine them without putting the whole debate about the costs of health in the proper context. We realised that it was time for the community to address the ethical questions of how much health costs. We recommended that the NHMRC take responsibility for a public debate about the ethics of health costs.

PARA.TAB: If everybody in the community knew that it cost $75,000 to maintain a baby in a humidicrib, would the community say we need more of them, fewer of them, or about the same number? If the community knew how much it cost for major surgical procedures and highly technological health care, would the community want to have a say about it? By and large I discovered that the community does want to have a say about it. There are different voices, and how one actually concludes what might be the reasonable outcomes of those deliberations, I think, is a matter of great sophistication. But I believe that the ethics committee of the NHMRC has done it in the past, and it has been challenged to do it. Indeed, if one reads the report of the 113th session of the NHMRC, which was tabled in this place last week—and I spoke to it then—one sees that it actually refers to the responsibilities given to it as a result of the recommendation from our Committee.

As to genetic registers and such things, Senator Harradine sort of stretches his eyes and sucks his breath in and that somehow seems to be a kind of argument. I do not find it persuasive at all. If we did not have genetic registers, Senator Harradine would be in here recommending them. If we had no ethics guidelines for the NHMRC, Senator Harradine would be in here recommending them, too. I do not know why Senator Harradine would possibly want to take issue with a structure that has dealt very honourably with the challenge of trying to define the parameters for medical research and suddenly say `This is an appalling process; we must get rid of it'. It has been behaving itself very well over time, it has been given a different set of definitions, it has a different responsibility to consult with the community and to take submissions, it has a different set of definitions to deliberate on all of those things before it actually proceeds to make its recommendations, and it is set up separately from the other committees. I do not quite know how much more difference Senator Harradine wants spelt out for him. This is a form, a design, that continues the importance of having ethical considerations as part of medical research, but it is strengthened in terms of this separation, its requirement to consult with the community, and the reports to this place that will be required either independently or under the legislation.

The register of genetic disorders may be one thing that people would want to discuss, but the question is: where will the registers be held? Senator Harradine is wonderful at leaping into the future with fear and loathing and absolutely no sense of what the facts or the conditions are. If Senator Harradine were to ask me what people in the community are concerned about, he would find that they are concerned about genetic disorders—massively so. What we are trying to do is set up genetic counselling. I would not have thought that it was unreasonable to suggest that there should be a proper list or understanding of where those genetic disorders exist in the community so that, with the proper respect and privacy that have always pertained to things in the medical arena, they will have that extra knowledge and the benefits of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What nonsense.

—It is not nonsense at all. If Senator Harradine is not talking about the fear of someone dialling a hospital and saying, `I'm falling in love with Mary Jane; can you tell me whether she has a genetic disorder?', what kind of fear is he talking about? Is he suggesting that people with genetic disorders will be sterilised? What kind of nonsense is he talking about? Senator Harradine's usual `fear' argument is a nonsense.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to go into all of those things. We are addressing this legislation here. Senator Harradine is introducing very spurious points of fear and worry when they are of no real worry to the legislation or to the point that he has raised.

There is no reason why an ethics committee, as constituted under this legislation, could not properly deliberate on all of the issues and many more that we have not even thought of yet. But, if registers of genetic disorders are the only concern, I am quite sure that the medical ethics committee, the bioethics committee and the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in this place can look at that. Any number of bodies can look at those. Senator Harradine knows that full well.

The interesting question is: what constitutes ethics for Senator Harradine? Over the years I have been much more worried about the sexism of medical research. This is a matter of major ethics. In one of the health journals in this country—I note that Senator Harradine did not cite my article—there were some instructions as to what to do to help a spouse returning home after a heart attack. It was stated that this person returning home would be ably assisted by his spouse. She would see that he had the right amount of rest. She would see that he had the right amount of exercise. She would see that he was properly fed and that his food was adequately cooked and so on. The question is: what happens to her when she goes home after a heart attack?

I do not think Senator Harradine could rely on the honourable gentlemen of the community up until that time to necessarily provide all the care that the journal judged as good health care. But who gets up here and says that sexism is an ethical consideration to worry about?

I received another piece of paper in my home last week telling me that, if I dialled a clever little cardboard dial, I could work out the state of cardio respiratory health. The data was based on the examination of 350,000 men, which honourable senators will be pleased to know is properly correlated to take account of women. I do not know what the correlation is, but it would have to be a very clever one! Senator Harradine has never raised the ethical considerations of sexism in the allocation of the medical research dollar. I would have thought that it is equally a matter of ethical consideration. If we want to know how women have babies, if we want to know about—

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about? I know what it is like.

—I have never heard Senator Harradine raging about this ethics committee talking about sexism. Senator Harradine does not worry about all the ethical issues; he worries about some of them. I do not think selective ethics is the way to justify arguing against this Bill.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of issues of major concern. There is a proper need for an ethical deliberation about the allocation of research dollars to NHMRC, the sorts of inquires it makes and the research it does. Indeed, there has been a very big fight within the NHMRC over the years to get any allocations away from so-called hard, scientific medical research and into the arena of public health where the broad considerations of promotion of good health and prevention of disease were not getting the allocation that certainly the sponsors of that research felt were justified. I think the newly constructed membership of the NHMRC reflects an agreement that at last those are valid areas of inquiry too. Is that an ethical question? I think that the good health of the community certainly is.

I know that the question of the allocation of medical research dollars along sexist lines is an ethical consideration; certainly an equity one, which is another of Senator Harradine's points. I find that I cannot possibly be persuaded by his arguments because of his selected morality and because the principles of an ethics committee, separate from but charged with reviewing the questions of the allocation of research done by the NHMRC, seems to me entirely proper. As I say, I am quite sure that, if the committee was not there, Senator Harradine would be standing up to amend the legislation to set one up. I think the arguments are insufficient and very limited. This Bill should stand supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the National Health and Medical Research Council Bill 1992, and the question is how it ought to be established and how it ought to function within Australian society. There is no doubt that in its continuing role as a peak advisory body to the Australian community in relation to matters of public health, health care, health and medical research, and ethical issues relating to health it is a body of great significance whose various decisions—whether it be as to funding a specific type of research or a particular project, or as to the ethical guidelines which it considers to be proper to require funded institutions to abide by—are of extreme importance.

PARA.TAB: It is because of the great importance of the National Health and Medical Research Council that the Government has considered it proper to give it a statutory base and therefore an independence from executive government, and to give its members from time to time, whoever they may be, an assurance that the Parliament considers that the task which is undertaken by the Council on behalf of the community is indeed very important and deserving of special recognition as to its status by its creation by parliamentary statute.

I believe the various functions of the National Health and Medical Research Council have been well canvassed during the debate and, indeed, are a matter of very common knowledge. The real issue is about the way in which ethical guidelines are to be promulgated for the conduct of research within various institutions—or not merely research, but also I suppose the practice of medicine within various institutions.

It has been a mark of the work of the National Health and Medical Research Council that in so many of the institutions which provide health care and medical research throughout Australia there have been established institutional ethics committees which have a role in ensuring that within a particular institution consideration is given to the ethical parameters which should accompany the care or research being offered or undertaken. This has been a very significant move within the Australian community and, whatever its limits, I believe it is to be greatly welcomed.

Certainly, the question of who or what body ought to issue the sorts of guidelines about which we are speaking will be of critical interest to those who engage in the debate in the committee stage of this Bill's passage through the Parliament—whether in the Friday sitting or the Committee of the Whole. I believe it is important to the Australian community that it be able to have great confidence in the body which issues the guidelines.

I am not persuaded at first blush—although I have not had the benefit of a consideration of any actual terms—by Senator Harradine's proposal that, in general and as a matter of course and as a matter of the common operation of the issuing of the guidelines, that be done by the Parliament by way of affirmative vote—that is, that both chambers of this Parliament should, in effect, become the issuers of the guidelines covering a vast range of matters. That is the way in which the guidelines are to be issued, as I understood Senator Harradine to be suggesting.

I would not—and would never—deny that there must be occasions where this Parliament or a State or Territory parliament, depending on the jurisdiction involved, ought to take responsibility in relation to a particular matter. I do not think that can ever be excluded from the proper deliberation and consideration of a body of elected representatives of the Australian people when it is asked to decide a question of the ethical parameters within which certain research or care ought to be undertaken or offered. I do not think there can be any permanent abdication of that role; that would be a grave dereliction of our duty. But I believe that would be an uncommon situation rather than the general way in which guidelines ought to be promulgated. I think the Australian community would lack confidence in that sort of process. It would think that it could become very highly politicised in relation to a whole range of issues and I think it would prefer to see the issuing of guidelines in the general way being the work of a committee of eminence.

The Government has structured this Bill so that the Australian Health Ethics Committee is such a body which, as a principal committee within the National Health and Medical Research Council structure, obviously has a very persuasive and critical role in the formulation of the sorts of ethical guidelines which should govern the matters with which we are concerned. I believe that in going in that direction the Government's Bill, as presented to the Senate, indicates the way in which this matter ought to be resolved—that is, by an eminent committee issuing the guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't issue the guidelines; the National Health and Medical Research Council does.

—I am choosing my words very carefully and the honourable senator should be a little patient. I believe the structure of integration and consultation between the Australian Health Ethics Committee and the National Health and Medical Research Council is a good principle. I do not say that a complete divorce of the two is a more desirable option than has been put forward in this Bill. I think there is a case for a linking up of the principal committees to the NHMRC in something of the way and structure which is envisaged in this Bill. That linking up can only reinforce the consideration of ethical issues by the NHMRC and, indeed, by the other principal committees of the NHMRC.

PARA.TAB: So I see the various correlations, collaborations and cooperations which are envisaged and, indeed, required by this Bill as being very worth while indeed. I believe it is proper for the Senate to endorse the Bill, as a structure, in its second reading. I think its general interlinking is to be welcomed and the questions which Senator Harradine and others in the Opposition parties have foreshadowed can be properly considered in the committee stage.

I believe the Bill should receive the endorsement of the Senate in the second reading stage in order to indicate to the Australian community that the National Health and Medical Research Council is of such fundamental importance that it should have the protection and safeguard of a statutory foundation for its very existence and activities. Within those activities, the question of the issue of guidelines can, and will, be further discussed in the committee stage. I will be most interested to see what amendments are brought forward. But there is no doubt that this Bill deserves the support of the Senate in its second reading and I commend it to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 19 August 1992, the National Health and Medical Research Council Bill 1992 stands referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for consideration and report on or before 3 November 1992.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992.
