The coalition is not opposing the passage of this Bill, which makes amendments to a total of eight different Acts. However, there are three of concern to the Opposition that I wish to refer to: firstly, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975; secondly, the Freedom of Information Act 1982; and, thirdly, the Judiciary Act 1903. Amendments relating to the other Bills in this omnibus package are, in our view, of a minor policy or technical nature.

PARA.TAB: Dealing first with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Bill inserts a new section 27A which provides that, subject to some specified exceptions, a person who makes a reviewable decision must take reasonable steps to give notice to all persons affected by the decision of the making of the decision and also of their right to have the decision reviewed. It is also provided that failure to take such steps to give notice will not affect the validity of the decision.

The exceptions where notice need not be given are set out in proposed subsection 27A(2). They include a decision not to impose a penalty, a decision to adjust the level of periodic payments to a class of persons, and a decision which determines a person to be in the most favourable of several categories of entitlement to a monetary benefit. Notice of the decision in these cases need not be given provided it does not adversely affect the interests of any other person. Nor need notice be given where another piece of legislation provides for notification of the right of review.

`Reviewable decision' is defined in proposed new section 27A as a decision that is reviewable by the AAT or those decisions which are made in the first and second instances which would ultimately be reviewable by the AAT. Proposed new section 27B empowers the Attorney-General to write a code of practice to facilitate the giving of notice.

I understand that the Government is to move an amendment to address concerns raised by the Australian Securities Commission, which apparently fears that proposed new section 27A would impose on it an unduly onerous obligation. The coalition intends to support that amendment.

The second Act is the Freedom of Information Act 1982. This Bill inserts new subsection 7(2)(2AA) into that Act to provide that corporate bodies established under legislation listed in part III of schedule 2 are exempt from the operation of the Act in relation to documents about their commercial activities. The legislation listed in new part III of schedule 2 is primary industry related and includes the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980, the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991 and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. Corporations so exempted are in fact already exempted in respect of their commercial activities in part II of schedule 2. The Bill deletes them from part II and inserts them in new part III. This represents a change in form rather than substance, as it seemed to be a tidier way of achieving the same result.

The Bill also inserts provisions relating to the Attorney-General's Department, the Australian Government Solicitor and the Australian Pork Corporation into part II of schedule 2 to allow exemption from the requirements of the FOI Act so far as documents relating to their commercial activities are concerned.

The coalition is concerned in relation to the exemptions for the Attorney-General's Department's and the Australian Government Solicitor's commercial activities that these exemptions could be used to refuse bona fide FOI requests. Therefore, I take this opportunity in the second reading debate to foreshadow for this reason that on behalf of the coalition I will be moving amendments in the committee stage to delete from the schedule the provisions relating to the Attorney-General's Department and the Australian Government Solicitor.

The third Act affected in this Bill is the Judiciary Act 1903. This Bill makes a number of amendments to that Act. I understand that there will be further Government amendments to its own Bill. The first amendment to the Judiciary Act 1903 is to include a reference to the Attorney-General of the ACT under subsection 40(1). This will mean that he or she will have the same power to seek the removal of a cause of action involving constitutional issues to the High Court as the other Attorneys-General. The Opposition will support that amendment.

The second amendment to section 55E will authorise the Australian Government Solicitor to practise as and have all the rights and privileges of a barrister, solicitor, or barrister and solicitor, in any court. Under section 55E as presently drafted, the Australian Government Solicitor may only practise as a solicitor in any court.

Section 55 is further amended by both the Bill and the Government amendments to it to provide for definitions of AGS lawyer and Attorney-General's lawyer. AGS lawyer and Attorney-General's lawyer are both defined to mean a person whose name is on a roll referred to in subsection 55D(1), which is the High Court roll or the Supreme Court roll of a State or Territory.

The amendments provide that such persons are entitled to practise as and have the same rights, privileges, duties and obligations as barristers and solicitors, or barristers and solicitors, in the courts and tribunals in courts in which they appear. This applies whether or not they are entitled to so practise apart from these provisions.

The coalition believes that government lawyers should be subject to the same practising requirements as lawyers in the private sector. We are concerned that this is not clear in the amendments and that the effect of these amendments will be to give government lawyers the right to practise in circumstances where a private practitioner would not be able to. Therefore, I will be moving a second reading amendment on behalf of the Opposition noting this concern.

I also note that in line with the Department's move towards a user pays system, this Bill authorises the Australian Government Solicitor to charge for services rendered and disbursements incurred in the course of acting for a client. The Government amendments to the Bill also authorise the Commonwealth to charge for the provision of legal professional services by the Attorney-General's lawyer.

In conclusion, the coalition is supporting most of the amendments proposed in this omnibus Bill. However, we anticipate a Government amendment to the provision relating to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act and I reiterate that I intend to move an amendment in the committee stage in relation to the Freedom of Information Act. With respect to the amendments to the Judiciary Act—the point that I have just raised about the potential advantage which may be given to government sector lawyers by proposed sections 55(E)(10)(B) and 55(G)(2)—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate is of the opinion that lawyers in the government sector should be subject to the same regulatory requirements and regulatory costs as lawyers in the private sector".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate tonight is debating the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992. The Bill is an omnibus Bill which proposes to amend a number of Acts falling within the Attorney-General's portfolio. The proposed amendments are of a minor policy nature. However, some of the amendments will have an important effect upon existing and future legislation.

PARA.TAB: In particular, there is an amendment to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 which has been initiated in order to obtain the agreement of the States and Territories to supply data from their land titles registers to the Commonwealth. This data will then be stored and accessed through the proposed Law Enforcement Access Network, commonly known as LEAN, which is to be operated by the Attorney-General's Department. There has been some concern over the establishment of such a network and I will return to this issue a little later.

There are four main pieces of legislation which this Bill seeks to amend. These are the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Judiciary Act 1903 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. There are also some minor amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. I was pleased to see that today both parties rejected the statements by Mr Morgan who thought that this particular Act should be repealed, otherwise we might have had cause to debate that a little more tonight.

The main amendment to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act is to insert a new section 27A into the Act to provide, subject to certain exceptions, a requirement that persons affected by decisions which are reviewable by the AAT be notified of the decisions and their rights of review. This amendment substantially gives effect to the recommendations contained in the Administrative Review Council's Report No. 27 entitled Access to Administrative Review Stage One: Notification of Decisions and Rights of Review.

The Australian Democrats have always argued that individuals should be afforded adequate protection of their rights within the legal system. The introduction of this notification process ensures that persons affected by administrative decisions are notified of the decision and of any further review process which they are entitled to pursue. It reflects a recognition that a review is of no assistance to a person who does not know that such a right exists. The only disappointing aspect of this amendment is that it was not introduced way back in 1975.

I also seek clarification from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) on a matter related to this amendment. It concerns proposed subsection 27A(2)(c)(ii) which is one of the exemptions to the section 27A(1) notification requirements. Proposed subsection 27A(2)(c)(ii) exempts a person who makes a reviewable decision from complying with section 27A(1) notification requirements if it is a decision adjusting the level of periodic payments to be paid to a person as a member of a `class of persons'.I would appreciate clarification as to whether this exemption would have the effect of excluding, for instance, a group of AIDEX demonstrators. Would they be grouped as a class of persons or are they simply a group within that class, and will every member of that group receive notification?

Since the drafting of the Bill, the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Tony Hartnell, has publicly raised concern over proposed section 27A and its effects upon the ASC. This concern was reported in an article in the Age on 10 August this year. The article reports that Mr Hartnell wrote to the Attorney-General on 3 August complaining that the proposed section 27A would force the ASC to reveal confidential applications made during company takeovers.Acting on this concern, I understand the Government will be moving an additional amendment to this Bill to overcome any possible adverse consequences.

The thrust of this amendment will be to defer the application of section 27A to decisions under the corporations law for six months to enable an assessment of the extent to which permanent exemption from the notification of decision and review rights requirements may be justified. After that time, the ASC will be required to comply with those requirements unless the regulations provide that particular decisions should be exempt.The Democrats will be supporting this amendment. I add that the Australian Democrats and, possibly, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee may not be totally happy with the regulatory framework which allows for exemptions to be created by regulation. However, as these are subsequently disallowable, we would agree that this is desirable at this stage.

The next piece of legislation to be amended by this Bill is the Freedom of Information Act 1982. An important amendment to this Bill is a proposal to insert a new subsection 12(1)(ba) into the Act which extends the categories of documents which a person is not entitled to obtain access to under the Act by including documents forming part of land titles registers maintained by each State and Territory. The reason for this amendment was explained by the Minister, and obviously is designed to protect the revenue of the States and Territories.

The establishment of LEAN arose as a direct consequence of the Government's acceptance of the 1987 recommendations made by the paper entitled Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth. The Government argues in the LEAN briefing paper dated 12 June of this year that it has a responsibility to protect the community from those who break the law and attempt to rip off the taxpayers through welfare cheating, tax evasion and other fraudulent means. The briefing paper goes on to say that it is recognised that there are privacy implications of the program. However, all governments have to balance those interests with the very clear benefits to the community.

The LEAN briefing paper states quite clearly that LEAN will only contain data publicly available from company and land records. This is fair enough. However, the concern must be that in other situations the material that is available on record and can be accessed has been excluded. We only have to look at the extended use that is being made of the tax file number to realise that.

The New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties has questioned the value of creating this LEAN database on the ground that its cost to operate outweighs any benefit obtained from the consolidation of publicly available information onto a single database. Ministerial comment on this point may be appropriate.

Finally, I have very strong reservations about the adequacy of the Privacy Act 1988 and the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914 to effectively deter any illicit trading of the confidential information contained in the LEAN database. My concern is highlighted by the recent findings of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption which confirmed longstanding anecdotal evidence of the multi-million dollar trade in confidential government information. Again, the Minister may wish to address that point.

Another amendment to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 is a proposal to exempt both the Attorney-General's Department and the Australian Government Solicitor from the operation of the Act in relation to documents in respect of commercial activities they undertake. I understand that the coalition is concerned about these proposed exemptions being used to restrict bona fide FOI applications and views the exemptions as too broad in their scope when considering the other exemptions already available under the Act.

Section 42 of the Act exempts documents which are subject to legal professional privilege. In addition, there is provision in section 40(1)(d) to exempt documents where their disclosure would have a substantial adverse effect on the proper and efficient conduct of the operations of an agency. The Australian Democrats have prepared an amendment which seeks to narrow the scope of these proposed exemptions to documents relating to the terms, conditions and charges applicable to the provision of legal services by the Department.

However, following further discussion with the Government, the Democrats have decided not to move that amendment. In particular, we acknowledge that there is a need to permit information relating to specific clients which does not attract legal professional privilege—client profiles, client needs analysis and other matters of this type—to be not disclosable. The same can be said about information on the expertise of particular staff, opinions, legal research that is prepared and similar information. On that basis, as I said, the Democrats will now not be moving that amendment.

The third piece of legislation to be amended by this Bill is the Judiciary Act 1903. The amendments to this Act will enable all lawyers who carry out work of a legal professional nature within the Attorney-General's Department to deliver legal services under a user-pays system. The amendments will also enable the Department to recover the costs for legal services which it has provided.

The Minister has stated that the user-pays system will enable the Department to consolidate its existing in-house expertise by making it available to all clients so that the Commonwealth's expenditure on counsel's fees will be constrained. There might also be the hope—and it may be a forlorn hope—that it might work generally to contain the charges made by the legal profession. However, if we look at the two-airline policy we can see that that sort of constraint by a government corporation operating in the market certainly did not have that effect.

There has been some concern that the proposed changes to section 55E of the Judiciary Act 1903 do not ensure that all lawyers in the Attorney-General's Department who carry out work of a legal professional nature—and not just those lawyers performing work for the clients of the Australian Government Solicitor—have the rights and obligations of a legal practitioner and can charge for the provision of legal services. I understand that the Government will be moving additional amendments. The Democrats will not be opposing these amendments. However, we will oppose Government amendment No. 4 and we will move an amendment to remove a minor inconsistency.

The final piece of legislation to be amended by this Bill is the Sex Discrimination Act. The amendment proposes to substitute a new subsection 41(4) into the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to require insurers, where requested by a client, to provide access to the actuarial or statistical data on which sex discrimination in an insurance policy is based. Obviously, this is a useful and necessary provision. The Australian Democrats will support the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate the great importance which the Government attaches to the passage before 10.30 this evening of the Law and Justice Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992. I believe that the Bill is in a form which is familiar to senators in this chamber. It is a most comprehensive piece of legislation, embracing as it does amendments to various statutes and thereby achieving a multitude of objectives. Each objective is relatively uncontentious, though it is quite clear that the change in the status of those who operate within the Commonwealth as barristers-solicitors is of interest to senators. No doubt, this can be the subject of debate at the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: While we appreciate that the exemption would apply only to documents with respect to the competitive commercial activities of the Department and the AGS, it seems to us that it is simply too broad to make the exemption available to the whole Department and the AGS. TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I have chosen to make a contribution on the adjournment debate because a number of issues have been raised in the last 24 hours which need some clarification. The first relates to a speech that was given yesterday by Hugh Morgan at the Australian National University in which he slammed the Mabo decision of the High Court.

PARA.TAB: Most of us know Hugh Morgan's philosophy. He is entitled to his views in this society. However, there are a couple of points that require very definite clarification. First of all, he is talking about the law and about the High Court. It would be wise for him to get his facts right. Firstly, he makes the claim that the High Court decision somehow affects individual property rights in this country. I suggest he gets some legal advice about that matter and a formal description and analysis of the High Court decision. If he does he will find that in no way are individual property rights challenged by the recognition of native title within the common law of Australia.

Secondly, it might be wise if he had a look at the precedent of recognition of native title. The recognition of native title within Australia may be only a few months old, but native title has been part of the common law in North America since 1763. It has been part of the common law in New Zealand since 1840. I am sure that you would agree, Mr Deputy President, that we do not see a great wave of protest from North America about the fact that their property rights have been taken from them, nor indeed from New Zealand. That is the second point I wish to clarify.

The next thing that really disturbs and disappoints me—whilst recognising that Hugh Morgan's philosophy and mine are somewhat different—is that his statements relating to Aboriginal culture were very insulting. I would not even repeat them in this place. Hugh Morgan should remember that he is insulting perhaps the oldest and most sophisticated culture yet studied by anthropologists. He should think twice about making sweeping statements about that culture. It is one thing to ignore the High Court; it is another to dismiss Aboriginal culture.

Further, he fails to know anything about international law and international precedent. Perhaps the best thing Hugh Morgan could do—if he wants to continue to represent elements of the mining industry in Australia—would be to go to Canada quick smart. He will discover that in Canada the mining industry has readily accepted native title, because it is not something new in Canada. It has accepted a whole range of decisions relating to the rights of ownership of the land by Canada's indigenous people and it works closely with indigenous people and takes it as a fact of life.

Eventually we will have a similar position in this country. Indeed, I have great faith that various sections of the mining industry are already perfectly prepared to work with Australia's indigenous people and negotiate what is appropriate within that industry. I do not believe that Hugh Morgan's statements of yesterday are at all typical of the mining industry.

This brings me to a question asked by Senator Tambling today of Minister Collins in my absence. I left the chamber a little earlier than I perhaps should have. I wanted to clarify what my position is in relation to self-government for Australia's indigenous people. Forms of self-government already exist in regard to community councils in Queensland and the Northern Territory. Forms of self-government are already accepted by governments—this Government, governments in other States and governments on both sides of the political spectrum.

I am not quite sure why certain people get so nervous when one talks about self-government in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We already have a form of self-government at the local level. It was certainly recognised in the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody that if we are to seriously address many of the social issues which were focused upon in that report, then we have to take seriously the rhetoric that we have used for a long time, but have been less vigilant in actually implementing, in regard to this question of self-determination or self-government—call it what you will.

We are not talking about sovereignty or secession from Australia; we are talking about people in this country having the right to self-determination and appropriate forms of self-government, yet to be determined in terms of debate and consultation over the coming years. There are particular parts of Australia—the Torres Strait is a classic example, but also perhaps the Kimberleys and Arnhem Land—which do appear to lend themselves to a greater degree of control by the indigenous people, in negotiation, consultation and all those words of consensus with other Australians.

If this sounds a little different or even a little radical to some people, I suggest that precedents exist overseas and they exist in Australia. In Canada the House of Commons Special Committee on Indian Self Government of 1983 recommended that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government establish a new relationship with Indian first nations and that an essential element of this relationship be recognition of Indian self-government. The Committee recommends that the right of Indian peoples to self-government be explicitly stated and entrenched in the Constitution of Canada. The surest way to achieve permanent and fundamental change in the relationship between Indian peoples and the Federal Government is by means of a constitutional amendment. Indian first nation Governments would form a distinct order of government in Canada, with their jurisdiction defined.

While the Committee has concluded that the surest way to lasting change is through constitutional amendments, it encourages both the Federal Government and Indian first nations to pursue all processes leading to the implementation of self-government. . .

In recent years Canadian debate has focused more directly on constitutional reform. At the present time a Canadian Royal Commission is examining, firstly, the history of relations between Aborigines, the Canadian Government and society as a whole and, secondly, the recognition and affirmation of Aboriginal self-government, its origin, content and strategy for progressive implementation.

PARA.TAB: I had the good fortune to visit Canada and talking about self-government for Canada's first nation peoples is as normal as asking, `Would you please pass the salt?'. People do not get upset and start screaming about black rule or takeovers or say, `What is this going to mean for us, the majority?'. Australians will have to face these issues with a greater degree of maturity—dare I say—than that exhibited in Hugh Morgan's speech yesterday.

Noting that that kind of debate has been going on in Canada for some time now and that that policy direction seems well ahead of Australian thinking, perhaps we should have a look at a Queensland Government discussion paper. It is only a discussion paper but, nevertheless, it raises a number of these issues in an informed way for debate and consideration. It was released in August 1991 and advocated self-government legislation consistent with the following four principles:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)There be a recognition of the pre-existing rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to self-government in the preamble, and the body of the proposed legislation;

(2)Minimum powers should be provided to Aboriginal and Islander communities to control their local and internal affairs, their physical and cultural survival and development, and their economy and resources;

(3)These powers and their exercise should not be subject to government, ministerial, or departmental veto except according to clear and precise criteria stated in the legislation, and any such veto should be subject to review; and
(4)Unless a community indicates otherwise, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community should have the jurisdiction to resolve disputes between themselves.

This was a discussion paper not to implement legislation tomorrow, next week or next year, but to highlight the fact that these issues are on the agenda. The momentum for change is there and I believe we have to address these issues with a degree of intellectual sophistication.

PARA.TAB: Some people would dismiss both these examples and say, `Canada can do what it likes; we have to concentrate on what we want', and that is fair enough. I would never suggest that Australia has to slavishly follow a Canadian model, a United States model or a model from anywhere else. But I think we can learn from them, adapt and adjust according to what overseas experience presents us with.

Similarly, of the Queensland discussion paper people will say, `It is only a discussion paper and there is certainly no sign of it going into legislation in that State at the moment'. But let us look at something that happened back in 1979—the Norfolk Island Act of that year. I am sure Senator Bjelke-Petersen will remember that Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister at that time. This Act was the initiative of a Liberal-National coalition. The Norfolk Island Act gave a mere 1,500 residents the right to elect their own Government with many of the powers of State and Federal governments including education, health, taxation, immigration, law and order and social welfare.

The Norfolk Island Act noted that there was a good reason for this legislation. It was not establishing a precedent; there was just a very special reason. The reason was `the special relationship of the Pitcairn descendants with Norfolk Island and their desire to preserve their traditions and culture'. Speakers on both sides of the chamber advocated that there be a special status for recognition of self-government because of that distinctive feeling that the people of Norfolk Island have—that uniqueness and that sense of belonging to Norfolk Island. That was recognised in 1979. Another speaker said:

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot avoid the question of Norfolk Island being part of Australia, yet at the same time we cannot be seen to be preventing the people who have lived there for so long from continuing to live in the way they have for so long.

If we are not very careful we will be guilty of an enormous double standard. If we can so readily accept self-government for 1,500 residents of Norfolk Island—I do not begrudge them their self-government; I would vote in favour of it if the proposal were to come before this chamber in 1992—why is it different for the indigenous people of Australia in certain parts of Australia? I am not proposing it for the heart of Sydney or in the country towns of Queensland, but in quite distinct, specific areas of Australia where it may be very appropriate.

PARA.TAB: There are no signs to date from either of the major political parties that these sentiments and action of more than a decade ago are about to be redirected to the Torres Strait, the Tiwi Islands—Elcho, Bathurst and Melville Islands—the Kimberleys or Arnhem Land. However, the momentum for reform is gaining strength. For the time being we are focusing—by `we' I do not just mean government, but all parliamentarians—our attention on a 10-year reconciliation process leading up to the centenary of Federation.

The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation has already acknowledged that the High Court decision has brought forward that particular debate. Constitutional reform is already being discussed with suggestions that the rights of indigenous people could perhaps be enshrined in an amendment which recognises the historical and cultural rights of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in determining their futures. Power and decision making will need to be shared if reconciliation is to take place.

At a recent conference on the impact of the Mabo decision—it was a conference held by the Cape York Land Council at Yarrabah—one of the speakers said that it was time for Australians to put their brains into reverse if they were really going to come to terms with the implications of the High Court decision. I very sincerely hope that we can put our brains in reverse, that we can think afresh on a number of these issues related to the rights of indigenous people, that we can think creatively and keep an open mind.

We need not feel that just because there might be some new ways of addressing these issues we have to have screaming, threatening headlines such as those Hugh Morgan has unfortunately introduced into this debate. That kind of polarised debate will get us nowhere. I believe it is unfortunate that someone like Hugh Morgan has bought into the debate in such a way, not because he does not have the right to buy into the debate, but because he has done it without his facts and without a real knowledge of the very significant issues involved. I believe it does not assist the reconciliation process.

I hope that next time the issue of land rights or self-government for indigenous people in this country is debated in this place we can debate it calmly, coolly and without feeling threatened. Why should we, representing as we do indigenous people and a population that of course is primarily non-indigenous, feel so threatened by Aborigines reclaiming their history and culture? We do not have anything to feel threatened about. We should be able to go into the debate in a mood of tolerance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very rarely speak in adjournment debates in this place, but this evening I want to raise what is considered a matter of urgency by a number of parents in the Toowoomba region. They are concerned about the increasing use of pornography in our electronic media.

PARA.TAB: I have been approached, as have my colleagues Senator Ron Boswell and Senator Bill O'Chee, by St Theresa's Parish Council in Toowoomba. The Council writes that it has had complaints from people of all ages who feel that, primarily, the Australian electronic media is acting to destroy all forms of decency and morality. I will quote from their letter, which is a direct plea to politicians to act now to stop what they see as the decay of moral standards in our society. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We are writing to express our disgust, horror and sadness at the endorsement of promiscuity that continues to decay our society.
The letter goes on to say:

The electronic media has an enormous power over the public, especially the young and impressionable. The escalating problem of unemployment of our young people leaves them very little self respect and decency;
In these days when there is a lot of unemployment perhaps young people might have too much time to sit at home and watch a lot of television. The letter continues:

When they see that the Australian media paint a picture of an immoral society it is seen by our young to be the accepted standard. Recently, television was advertising a newly released cassette/compact disc—all the tunes on the disc were very suggestive and each one supplied accompanying vulgar visual clips. This was advertised on prime time which we find is unacceptable. The moral standards of our young are being undermined in an effort to sell the particular product.

The Nine Network screens the weekly series "Sex with Sophie Lee" at 8.30 pm. Firstly, we feel that the time slot should be 9.30 pm. The visual displays are disgusting and the fact that most people interviewed appear to be teenagers, promotes out of control promiscuity amongst our young adults.

When our society has been crippled with the AIDS epidemic which is spread by promiscuous irresponsible lifestyles, television stations, advertising censors will then realise that events have escalated out of control.
We believe—
say the writers from Toowoomba—

our sexuality is a gift from God and the sex act expresses commitment and love which is essential for a happy family life. However, television shows such as "Chances" depict sex as temporary and lustful. The pornography market flourishes in Canberra, condoned by the irresponsible attitude of our current Government to such material.

The permission granted by the Minister for Communications to telecast X rated pornographic and R rated violent material on the proposed "Pay T.V." in Australia further adds to our anxiety for the declining moral standards within Society.
Surely—
they add—
there must be a number of politicians, T.V. producers, programme co-ordinators with young families who share the same concern for our families and young people. We want you—
they say—
to . . . Respond to our concerns, change the worrying focus of pornography and reduced family emphasis in television and this will provide moral leadership for families into the 21st century.

As a mother and a grandmother, any issues which affect women and families rate the highest priority with me. This issue should be of the highest concern to all women and, indeed, families throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: This Government has made a sham of looking after families. It has given in to yet another minority, the peddlers of pornography, in an industry which makes money out of exploiting women and which caters to the more perverse elements in society.

Honourable senators opposite talk about civil liberties—the rights of people to do what they wish and to pursue a normal successful life to the best of their ability. I ask honourable senators—not that there are too many here at present, but what could be a greater infringement on the rights of the majority of average Australians than the sort of dangerous material that we are talking about this evening? What could be more harmful to the pursuit of those aims?

Decent families, church groups, women's groups and many other organisations have been crying out for firm action to be taken to stamp out this smut. All these organisations feel very concerned that action has not been taken to stop the proliferation of pornographic and sexually explicit material. I am sad to say that Canberra is the porn capital of Australia.

There is evidence readily available to show that this type of material has a detrimental effect on our society. I dispute the spurious arguments put by supporters of pornography that a ban on such material would drive it underground. That is a hoary argument put up by people who deliberately do not want the best for the community. We should remember that murder is done in private. Does that mean that we should legalise murder so that it can be brought out into the open?

Many of us here this evening are parents. We realise that, as parents, it is difficult to control what our children watch and see during their daily activities. I am very concerned that many young people watching explicit sexual material as well as violent material may come to believe that such behaviour is acceptable. They might think that, because they have seen it on a television show or on a video, it cannot be all that bad. I sometimes wonder whether so much violence in our society today is due in no small measure to the R-rated videos and even the violent films shown on television.

Sometimes when we watch the news at night time, we find that the first three or four items on television contain violence. This is also a real problem. More recently, we have been seeing the abduction at gunpoint of people sitting in their motor cars. One just begins to wonder where the young people who do these things get their ideas.

While one can have some form of control in cinemas, control of access to television and video viewing is impossible. Governments have a responsibility to protect minors and others in the community from seeing material of a violent or sexual nature that would disturb them. I accept that parents have a responsibility as well, but parents, regrettably, are not always there to exercise control over television or video viewing. We cannot be too sure that those people over 18 years of age who see these videos are not adversely affected by them.

I conclude my contribution by saying that I am concerned at the proliferation of what can only be described as anti-family behaviour and material in today's society. I have stood up for the family many times in this chamber, but I do not think that I have ever been more worried about the future of families in Australia than I am today. Families are the cornerstone of society. They form the basic structure on which we build our lives. In order to maintain our way of life, health, safety and order, we must protect the interests of the family. That is why I have brought the concerns of the council members of St Theresa's parish in Toowoomba before the Senate in this adjournment debate tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —In June this year I drew the attention of the Senate to what I termed a longstanding and outrageous abuse of human rights that was perpetrated by Australia Post on one of its employees. In that speech, I detailed a catalogue of actions that are a public disgrace. Shortly after I left on a parliamentary delegation to Brazil, Senator Knowles found it necessary, in my absence, to comment rather forcefully on some aspects of what I had said, to condemn me for abusing parliamentary privilege, as she saw it, and exaggerating a case against somebody she held was merely doing his job.

PARA.TAB: It gave me no personal pleasure to say what I did at that time, but I believe it had to be done. Subsequently, proof of both the justice and the content of my remarks and of the necessity of making them was contained in a letter I recently received from the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I have obtained the permission of the Ombudsman's office to quote the letter in full tonight. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Bell,

You will recall your speech to the Parliament on 3 June 1992 in which you referred to the case of Mr "Y" and his difficulties with Australia Post in relation to his employees' compensation entitlements.

We recognise the case, of course. We had been investigating Mr Yeatman's complaints about a specialist's video-taping an interview with him, and Australia's Post's refusal to provide certain documents to him on the grounds of legal professional privilege. However, when I read your account of Australia's Post's dealings with Mr Yeatman I placed the investigation on a formal basis, widened it to include the full scope of Australia Post's actions in the matter, and required it to provide all the relevant files to me.

The files bore out your criticism. On 3 September 1992 I wrote to the Managing Director to voice my grave concerns about Australia Post's treatment of its former employee, and I asked for urgent action. I am pleased to report that the Managing Director responded very promptly; Australia Post has apologised to Mr Yeatman and has paid him a substantial solatium; and Mr Yeatman has been assured that there will be no further reviews of his entitlement to compensation.
There remain substantial issues arising from the investigation, but I thought I should let you know at once the favourable result of your initiative.
Yours sincerely
Alan Cameron
Commonwealth Ombudsman

My office is still in regular contact with the aforementioned Mr Yeatman. Although the events following my speech in this place have gone part way to vindicating his longstanding complaint, Mr Yeatman nevertheless remains deeply scarred emotionally, as well as being financially disadvantaged by this experience. Having followed this case myself, I can understand his distrust, suspicion and continuing distress. As I quoted, the Ombudsman has reported that a substantial solatium was paid to Mr Yeatman as a gesture of apology. Nothing could begin to recompense him for the emotional pain and the financial hardship he has suffered over a considerable period.

PARA.TAB: I trust that Australia Post will review its actions and properly compensate Mr Yeatman for the damage that has resulted from its callous and wilful wrongdoing. I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate the assurance contained in the letter that there will be no further reviews of Mr Yeatman's entitlement to compensation. Copies of correspondence that I have received make it easy to be less than convinced of such assurances from Australia Post. I can well understand why Mr Yeatman remains fearful that in a year or so somebody in Australia Post will find an excuse to revisit that assurance. There has been at least one previous occasion when a similar assurance to another employee was overturned a few years later, despite stating in previous correspondence that it had not proposed to take any further action then or in the future.

The General Manager of Australia Post in Western Australia appears to have given a firm undertaking that no further reviews of Mr Yeatman's entitlement will take place. That manager's letter quite clearly gives this undertaking. I wish to note this assurance on the public record so that Mr Yeatman may also be able to accept it.

In addition, I would also like to acknowledge and pay tribute on the public record to the actions of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. This is one occasion when his role and function have been spectacularly demonstrated to be essential for achieving justice and fair play.

Finally, this is an all too rare instance of a very unpleasant and distressing story having at least the possibility of a happy ending. This possibility comes about in great part as a result of the care and persistence of my staff and of the Democrats in general. In bringing this matter to the attention of the Senate, I point out that the role of the Senate as a forum for the airing of these kinds of issues has been vindicated and, I hope, strengthened. We can only hope that the injustices perpetrated against this man that I have raised in this place are speedily addressed and, further, with the watchful eyes of other honourable senators, Australia Post will never again behave in this way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 14 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Department of Primary Industries and Energy conduct national surveys of pesticide and other residues; if so, for surveys conducted between 1988 and 1992:

(b) How frequently was this produce tested? and
(c) Does the department intend to publish the results of these surveys; if so, when; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, The Department of Primary Industries does conduct a national survey for pesticides and other residues. The survey is known as the National Residue Survey (NRS), a broad based monitoring program for chemical contaminants in agricultural food commodities. A pilot survey for fisheries products, prior to their inclusion in the NRS, is also currently underway. The NRS is administered by the Bureau of Rural Resources within the Department.

In response to part (a) of the question during the period 1988 to 1992 the NRS included export produce from within the following commodities; meat and offal, grains, fruit, vegetables, dairy products, eggs and honey. The meat program included samples from cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, deer, buffalo, horses, kangaroos and rabbits. The grains program included wheat, barley, oats and sorghum with some testing of miscellaneous grains and grain products. A diverse range of fruit and vegetables were also included.

PARA.TAB: The results of the NRS are published in reports available to the public. In response to part (c) of the question the results for 1987 and 1988 were included in a report published in January 1990. The report for the results for 1989 and 1990 are now being printed and should be available on 12 October 1992.

It is also important to note that in the context of export products, the results of the NRS meat program and the proposed program for the forthcoming year are made available to importing countries such as the EC and the USA for their approval. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The value of imports of crude oil and other refinery feedstocks for the last five fiscal years is shown below.

As well as producing petrol and diesel, these feedstocks are used to manufacture a range of other products such as aviation gasoline, aviation turbine fuel, fuel oil and, in particular, lubricants and bitumen.
Value of Imports of Crude Oil and Refinery Feedstocks ($A millions)

Although part of our domestic petrol and diesel is manufactured from imported feedstocks, a principal technical reason for their use in Australian refineries is to meet domestic demand for bitumen and lubricants which are not available from Australian crudes.

In presenting the information above, it should be noted that the Australian refinery system is technically about 100 per cent self-sufficient in our petrol and diesel requirements. That is, current levels of indigenous production of oil and condensate in Australia, and the refinery capacity needed to process these, are sufficient to meet domestic demand for petrol and diesel without the need to import either the finished products or the basic feedstocks for their manufacture.

However, the commercial and technical environment in which the Australian oil market operates takes account particularly of the de-regulated crude oil market that now exists, as well as principles of economic efficiency and practical considerations, and these are reflected in an overseas trade pattern in which both the export and import of crude oil and refined products occurs.

PARA.TAB: Note: Assumes value of Australian crude oil exported is $A30 per barrel, fob, and that the crude oil would have been refined into petrol and diesel with 5 per cent losses in the refinery.

The net effect on the economy would, however, be negative, since the cost of producing ethanol in these quantities (estimated to be between $A0.55 and $A1.20 per litre) is considerably higher than the cost of production of petrol. The cost of producing ethanol at an average, say, of 85 cents per litre, at the 10 per cent substitution level would be around $A2,300 million per annum compared to the export value of $A508 million for the crude oil saved (with no 5 per cent loss).
The uneconomic production of ethanol would have diverted investment from areas where it has better potential to earn additional income.

Significant levels of ethanol production could also raise land use issues. A 1979 CSIRO study indicated that if land not then in use was used to grow crops for ethanol production it could supply up to perhaps 20% of petrol and diesel requirements. Use of a similar area of land today would

ANSWER.PARA: raise a number of land use issues including conservation and biodiversity.

PARA.TAB: Diversion of existing farming lands for ethanol production would mean the loss of production in other areas.

If waste materials, eg starch effluent or forest residue, could be used economically, there would be essentially no impact on existing land use. However, the quantity of ethanol available from these sources is limited, perhaps less than 5% of petrol and diesel requirements. Furthermore, the technology for producing ethanol from forest by-products is not well established and raises other questions about increasing use of forest resources.

(4) No funds have been allocated for research into ethanol substitution in the past five years. Between 1978 and 1985 $A7 million was allocated by the Governments of the day to ethanol research and development. A 1985 review found that further research was unlikely to reduce costs and that the barriers to ethanol use as a transport fuel were economic rather than technical. Little has changed to alter that view.
